North Korea Warns U.S. In Standoff Over Weapons
North Korea warned of an "uncontrollable catastrophe" unless the U.S. agrees to a negotiated solution to a standoff over the North's nuclear energy and weapons programs. The statement was a warning to other countries that their efforts to mediate would be futile. A1

Hussein Denounces U.S.
President Saddam Hussein used the occasion of his holiday greetings to Iraq's Christian minority to denounce the United States, saying the weapons inspections would show that Washington merely seeks a pretext to seize Iraqi resources. A16

Iran to Continue Nuclear Plant
The president of Iran said that his country would continue construction of a Russian-assisted nuclear power plant and that the nuclear waste would be taken to Russia for safekeeping. A5

China Releases Prisoner
China released its most prominent pro-democracy prisoner, sending him to exile and medical treatment in the United States. The release signaled China's strong desire for good relations with the United States. A1

Rethinking Venezuela Oil
Venezuela's chief oil official, Ali Rodriguez, said that as a result of a national strike that has battered the state-owned oil company, he would consider layoffs and hiring outside specialists, steps aimed as much at cutting costs and increasing efficiency as they are at making the company less vulnerable to future political storms. A14

Hong Kong Ignores Objections
The Hong Kong government ended a public comment period on plans for tough internal security laws, brushing aside objections. The government said it would introduce legislation with the goal of winning final passage by July. A6

Somber Holiday in Bethlehem
The celebrations in Bethlehem began amid widespread proclamations of despair. A year that included the city's off-and-on occupation by Israeli troops and the takeover of the Church of the Nativity by Palestinian militants left little to remember and less to hope for. A9

Karzai Finds Stability
Hamid Karzai is looking stronger now that the country has found a degree of stability under a year of his stewardship as leader of Afghanistan. But violence persists. A1

Spanish Musicians Protest
The success of a reality television show that manufactures pop stars has prompted a campaign by more than 100 Spanish musicians and critics against the program, "Operacion Triunfo," or "Operation Victory." A17

East Germans Moving West
Nearly one in seven eastern Germans have left for the western part of their country or moved abroad since 1990, when the two Germanys were formally reunited, federal statistics show. In Rostock, unemployment stands at 18 percent, almost double the national average. A3

NATIONAL A18-21

Maine's Drug Program Rejected by Federal Court
State efforts to provide prescription drugs to low-income people suffered a setback as a federal appellate court struck down a program established by the State of Maine that forced drug makers to give discounts of 18 percent to 25 percent. A1

U.S. Plans New Land-Use Rules
The Bush administration is adopting a property-dispute rule that it says will provide the government protection from lawsuits but that critics describe as a way for national parks and forests to be opened to mining, drilling and other development. A18

Arab-Americans Sue Ashcroft
A coalition of Arab-American groups sued Attorney General John Ashcroft and the Immigration and Naturalization Service in a Los Angeles federal court after hundreds of immigrant men were arrested and detained last week while trying to register with federal authorities. A16

Storm Brings Snow and Damage
A winter storm rolled through the Southwest and Central sections of the United States, causing at least 15 deaths and bringing an unexpected white Christmas to parts of the country that seldom see snow. A20

'Phantom' Decisions Cited
About 80 percent of decisions issued by the federal appeals courts do not establish binding precedents and may not be cited, but the prohibitions against these so-called unpublished decisions may be easing. A21

Growth for the Girl Scouts
National membership in the Girl Scouts has hit a 20-year high of 2.8 million while the Boy Scouts have been embroiled in a controversy over its ban on gay members. A1

Indians Fight to Regain Land
A foundation has been dedicated to reassembling lands signed over to the United States Government in exchange for money and returning them to Indian control. A18

HEADLINE: Bush Seeks Increase in National Debt Limit 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
The Bush administration asked Congress today to approve another increase in the limit on national debt, saying it will run out of the authority to borrow money by late February.
 The deputy Treasury secretary, Kenneth W. Dam, in a letter to the House speaker, J. Dennis Hastert, cited the cost of combating terrorism and the economic slowdown for the government's growing indebtedness. 
 The federal government, which enjoyed a budget surplus as recently as two years ago, had a shortfall of $157 billion this year and is expected to have a larger one in 2003. 
Congress raised the government's debt limit in July by $450 million, to a total of $6.4 trillion, but administration officials predicted even then that they would need to raise the limit again by some time next year.
Though today's announcement was no surprise, it highlighted the sharp deterioration in the government's financial condition and provided fresh ammunition for Democratic lawmakers who want to thwart President Bush's plan to push additional tax cuts through Congress early next year.
Mr. Dam said the government's debt had been swollen by needs for the Social Security and Medicare trust funds, the costs of fighting terrorism and the economic slowdown.
But he made only oblique reference to the contribution made by the tax cuts that Mr. Bush pushed through last year, referring to the cost of "restoring economic performance."
Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota and the senior Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee, seized on today's request to denounce Mr. Bush's campaign to make permanent last year's tax cuts.
"By raising the debt ceiling to pay for the president's tax cuts and his other spending, the Bush administration is wanting our children and grandchildren to pay our bills," Mr. Conrad said in a statement.
Treasury officials would not say how much they want to increase the debt ceiling, which will be subject to negotiation with Congressional leaders as the deadline approaches.
The negotiations will have to take place at the same time that Mr. Bush will be campaigning for his next package of tax cuts aimed at stimulating the economy. Mr. Bush is expected to outline his package either in or before his State of the Union address in late January. Many people expect him to call for measures costing as much as $300 billion over 10 years.

HEADLINE: A Career as a Window to the Future 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH and DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
Since the White House's recent nomination of John W. Snow, the 63-year-old chairman of the railroad company CSX, to replace the ousted Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, analysts and economists have been trying to figure out what his future stewardship will mean for the country.
 But in railroad circles, the question is more parochial: Was he good for CSX, its employees and its shareholders? 
 Certainly there were problems after Mr. Snow was promoted to chief executive of CSX in 1989. During a long rough period in the 1990's, fatal accidents on the company's rails prompted a federal audit and raised concerns over whether CSX was more focused on cost-cutting than on public safety. 
More recently -- after CSX's stock soared through the mid-1990's -- the shares have been pounded along with other railroad stocks. What has particularly riled shareholders is that, as their stake shrank since 1997, Mr. Snow's compensation continued to grow handsomely. Last year he received $10.1 million, 69 percent more than in 1997.
But Mr. Snow's performance has pluses as well. The company's safety record has improved markedly in recent years. And analysts say Mr. Snow's time at the company will be recalled as the era when an unfocused transportation conglomerate was transformed into the Eastern United States' largest rail carrier, with 23,300 miles of track. (Only Union Pacific and Burlington Northern Santa Fe, both operating in the West, have bigger rail networks.) 
In September, CSX lowered its third-quarter earning forecast, but most Wall Street analysts see CSX as poised for growth when the economy rebounds.
Critics recall that Mr. Snow's $8.4 billion bid to acquire Conrail in 1996 devolved into a battle with the better financed Norfolk Southern that drove the price up to $10.2 billion. The two railroads ended up dividing up the spoils, with CSX eventually paying $3.9 billion for 42 percent of Conrail's tracks, burdening it with a huge debt. The company's current debt of $5.8 billion is more than double its $2.4 billion debt in 1989, when Mr. Snow became chief executive.
CSX, through a variety of legal techniques, also managed to avoid paying federal income taxes in three of the four years from 1998 to 2001, when it earned a total of $934 million in profit, according to data in its reports to shareholders first disclosed by Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-backed group whose figures are widely accepted. CSX received $164 million more in refunds than it paid during those years, it told shareholders.
CSX's operating profit margins have grown since 1989, even as its revenue shrank as CSX withdrew from the container-ship, logistics and barge businesses. The company made a profit of $387 million on revenue of $8.1 billion in 2001, and has earned $287 million on revenues of nearly $6.1 billion in the first three quarters of this year.
"The Conrail merger will be John's greatest legacy at CSX," said Jill K. Evans, a transportation analyst at Morgan Securities.
For many people, a big question is how much direct credit, or blame, Mr. Snow deserves for the company's record under his watch. With his nomination as Treasury secretary still pending, Mr. Snow declined to be interviewed for this article. But by many accounts, he has been more a strategist and lobbyist for CSX than an active operations executive.
"I can't say whether he brought benefits to CSX, but he sure was a visionary when it came to deregulation," said Robert E. Gallamore, director of the Transportation Center at Northwestern University and a former strategic planner at Union Pacific.
Many analysts and rail buffs say that Mr. Snow left much of the actual running of CSX to Michael Ward, the president, who was widely expected to succeed Mr. Snow as chief executive next year even before the Treasury nomination was made. "CSX won't miss a beat in the transition," said Charles L. Hill, director of research at Thomson First Call.
Mr. Snow, who has a law degree and a Ph.D. in economics, started out as a University of Maryland economics professor and then taught law at the University of Virginia. His early advocacy of deregulating transportation industries brought him to the attention of senior railroad executives and in 1977 won him a job as vice president of government affairs with the Chessie System and an invitation to put his theories into practice. When CSX was formed in 1980 from the merger of Chessie and Seaboard Coast Line Industries, Mr. Snow became a senior vice president at CSX and began moving up in the company.
CSX's operations are based in Jacksonville, Fla., but Mr. Snow has worked from Richmond, Va., as chief executive, using the CSX "air force," as company people call it, to ferry himself by jet to Florida and often by helicopter to Washington, 100 miles to the north.
Although railroads have been free to set their own rates since 1980, the federal government still regulates many aspects of the rail industry, including safety. And Washington was familiar turf for Mr. Snow, who had worked as a transportation official in the Ford administration before joining Chessie. 
Both critics and admirers agree that Mr. Snow is polished at courting politicians and would almost certainly be more politically effective as the Treasury secretary than Mr. O'Neill was. Among other prominent posts, he served for two years in the mid-1990's as chairman of the Business Roundtable, a lobbying organization for chief executives of large corporations, and was active in the Business Council, another influential group.
At CSX, Mr. Snow led an aggressive cost-cutting campaign. That first won him applause from Wall Street, but later opened him to widespread accusations of emphasizing fiscal health over public safety. Critics say track maintenance suffered and contributed to 19 deaths and more than 100 injuries in a spate of derailments, crashes and other accidents involving trains on CSX tracks between 1991 and 1996. 
Five major accidents in 1995 alone prompted an audit by the Federal Railroad Administration that accused the company of intimidating workers who raised safety concerns.
CSX, like the other major freight railroads, carries Amtrak passenger trains on its rails. Under federal law, Amtrak is solely responsible if any of its trains have accidents, even if the fault lies with the freight railroad's tracks, switches and signals. 
Thomas M. Downs, who was president of Amtrak from 1993 to 1998, said that he repeatedly met with Mr. Snow to express his concerns about safety on CSX's line.
"My experience was pretty uniformly unsatisfactory," said Mr. Downs, who said he felt that Norfolk Southern and other railroads had kept their rails safe. "I expected a different level of commitment to safety from his railroad. It was a constant disappointment."
On Feb. 17, 1996, before the federal audit was finished, a Maryland commuter train ran through a poorly maintained CSX signal and crashed into a Chicago-bound Amtrak train killing 12 and injuring 20.
The crash helped galvanize the auditors, whose subsequent report said of CSX, "Employees were not reporting injuries due to fear of reprisals, such as formal hearings or harsh discipline for minor unsafe acts or mistakes." 
The report also said supervisors were spread too thin to do their jobs and that a fifth of tracks had not been properly inspected. The audit noted the role of top management, saying that "only through a true commitment to safety at every level in the organization" would dangerous practices end. 
CSX denies it ever took chances with public safety. "What is important is how CSX responded to that audit,"said Adam Hollingsworth, a CSX spokesman. He said that Mr. Snow adopted "every recommendation" of the audit, including a zero-tolerance policy for intimidating workers who raise safety questions.
"Safety always has been and always will be CSX's top priority," Mr. Hollingsworth said, "and John Snow and the management team of the railroad have been and always will be committed."
Two years ago, CSX added 125 new inspectors and began spending more on maintaining the rails. As a result, CSX now ranks No. 2 in the number of train accidents and reported injuries -- behind only Norfolk Southern, which has ranked as the safest railroad for more than 20 years.
In the view of some employees, the cultural changes that benefited safety also improved working conditions more generally, creating an environment where workers now have a greater say in how things are done.
"Snow's legacy is that he is the only railroad executive who tried to break the militaristic culture of railroad managements," said Frank Wilner, the spokesman for the United Transportation Union, which represents about 8,000 CSX workers.
Whether Mr. Snow's management style was hands-on or arm's-length, his biggest business bet was his decision to make a takeover run at Conrail in 1996. At the time of the Conrail deal, the common wisdom had also held that Norfolk Southern would be able to more quickly and fully absorb its piece of Conrail.
"A lot of us thought Norfolk Southern had more bucks in its back pocket and a better managerial culture," Mr. Gallamore of Northwestern University said. "But in fact CSX did every bit as well."
Shareholders are not necessarily as upbeat. Many are smarting from their losses in the company's stock, particularly in light of Mr. Snow's increasingly rich compensation. 
Last year Amalgamated Bank, which holds about 82,000 CSX shares in its LongView index funds, introduced a shareholder resolution that would limit some of the lucrative severance payments built into CSX's executive employment contracts -- particularly the "poison pill" provisions that called for top executives to be paid handsomely in the event of a change of control at the company.
Melissa Moye, Amalgamated's chief economist in charge of trust and investment services, said that 30 percent of CSX shareholders voted for the resolution. That was not enough to pass the measure, but it was a strong enough showing to indicate investors' displeasure with management, Ms. Moye suggested.
"This is just not a well-governed company, and this stock has not done well," she said.
Many financial analysts choose to take a longer view, saying that CSX and Norfolk Southern, after some early stumbles, stand to benefit nicely from the Conrail acquisition. "Both railroads have turned out to be very good operators," Ms. Evans at Morgan Securities said.
And by one key measure for a freight company, CSX has grown increasingly proficient. In 2000, only about half of CSX's trains departed and arrived on time. Now, more than 90 percent are on schedule -- a record that has enabled CSX to pick up more shipments of perishable goods, like produce.
In the final analysis, that may be the best way to assess whether Mr. Snow's method was any way to run a railroad. As noted by William D. Zollars, chairman of the Yellow Corporation, a big trucking company that often carries goods to and from CSX's rail yards: "They're getting the trains there on time, with everyone's goods on them."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Officials Said to Urge Bush To Cut Taxes on Dividends
White House officials are urging President Bush to propose cutting taxes on corporate dividends for shareholders by about half, according to administration officials and Republicans close to the White House. The proposal, likely to be a crucial part of Mr. Bush's tax-cutting plan, is intended to stimulate the economy and reduce what many economists say is an incentive for companies to avoid paying dividends and to run up debt.
 While many economists think it would do little to bolster the economy quickly, they say the proposal would give a lift to the stock market. The plan would cost the Treasury more than $100 billion over 10 years, and the tax benefits would overwhelmingly flow to the wealthiest taxpayers. Page A1. 

The administration asked Congress to approve another increase in the limit on national debt, saying it will run out of the authority to borrow money by late February. C3.

EM.TV Sells a Part of the Muppets
EM.TV and Merchandising has agreed to sell 49.9 percent of the Jim Henson Company and its Muppets to an investment group led by Dean Valentine, the former president of the UPN network. C4.

Oil Chief Details Response to Strike
Venezuela's chief oil official, Ali Rodriguez, said that he would begin a series of changes -- including layoffs and the hiring of foreign specialists -- in response to a strike that has battered the state-owned oil company. A14.

Court Bars Maine's Drug Discounts
A federal court struck down a Maine state program that provides prescription-drug discounts to low-income residents. The program forced drug makers to give discounts of 18 percent to 25 percent. A1.

India Is Regaining U.S. Contracts
After slowing after the terrorist attacks, outsourcing by American companies to Indian concerns or to their own Indian units has begun to pick up. World Business, Section W.

Airline Confirms Jet Purchases
China Airlines, the government-controlled carrier of Taiwan, confirmed that it had concluded large contracts to buy jets from Airbus and Boeing. World Business, Section W.

Durable Goods Orders Fall 1.4%
Manufacturing stumbled in November as orders to factories for big-ticket goods dropped, the Commerce Department reported. The agency reported that orders for durable goods, costly manufactured products expected to last at least three years, fell 1.4 percent in November from October. The drop came after a 1.7 percent rise in orders in October and was the weakest showing since September. C3.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell 45.18 points, to close at 8,448.11. The Nasdaq dropped 9.22 points, to 1,372.47. The Standard & Poor's index declined 4.91 points, to 892.47. C5.

No Shortage of Advice in Japan
Japanese policy makers have never been at a loss for ideas on how to clean up the nation's debt-laden banks. In recent months, several international agencies have also raised loud alarm bells. World Business, Section W.

Fire Delays a Mixed-Use Project
Fire delayed the opening of an upscale project in San Jose, Calif., but its effects on the development -- and its cash flow -- left analysts feeling vindicated. They had often criticized the project. Commercial Real Estate. C4.

Markets Are Closed for Christmas
Financial markets in the United States and in most countries overseas are closed today in observance of the Christmas holiday. The American markets will reopen tomorrow; many foreign markets will remain closed.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: KARZAI'S PROGRESS; 
Afghans Mark Year of Slowly Growing Stability

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
It was a year ago that Hamid Karzai took over the business of governing Afghanistan, a ruin of a country he and his government inherited after the collapse of the Taliban and have tried to guide through its first year relatively free of war in two decades.
 A united Afghanistan with a functioning multiethnic army remains a desire, not a reality. Yet despite violent incidents -- a narrow escape from assassination, the killing of two of his ministers and continued clashes among rival warlords in the provinces -- Mr. Karzai is looking stronger now that under his stewardship the country has found a degree of stability. 
 That was underscored today when a former president, Burhanuddin Rabbani, who last year opposed the United Nations plan to make Mr. Karzai president, voiced unreserved support for him and the central government at a ceremony marking their first year in office.
Speaking to an audience of high-level government officials at the ceremony, Mr. Karzai acknowledged some failures of his government, namely security and disarmament, and vowed to tackle those issues more energetically in the next year.
In a sign of progress made, American forces based in Afghanistan have been contemplating moving from combat operations toward development activities, deploying larger teams of civil affairs officers in 8 to 10 provincial centers to give a boost to economic development.
The battle against the Taliban and Al Qaeda has been drawing to an end, and the effort to win the peace and help the government establish its control countrywide is the new target, American military officials and diplomats have said.
Rocket and grenade attacks against American forces -- and recently suicide bomber attacks -- have continued and even increased in recent weeks. Yet they remain small in scale, and any concerted organized opposition to the presence of about 9,000 United States troops has failed to materialize.
The economic situation in the country remains precarious, however. Of the population of 20 million, nearly two million are recently returned refugees struggling to find a way to survive their first winter back.
Some 1.3 million people will be relying on food aid this winter, the World Food Program says, and more than half a million displaced people are considered vulnerable and in need of shelter and relief assistance, according to the United Nations refugee agency.
Although several nations pledged more than $4.5 billion in aid this year, not all of that money has arrived. The United States gave about $588 million this year, and expects to contribute a similar amount to the roughly $2 billion pledged by various nations for 2003, the State Department says.
Regional leaders continue to flex enormous power, running their own armies, collecting their own taxes and customs and to some extent running their own foreign policy. Armed clashes have continued, as regional commanders seek to consolidate their local power or defeat rivals.
Mr. Karzai, determined to avoid further bloodshed for his exhausted and traumatized people, has chosen to win over the warlords by persuasion -- a tactic that so far has won at least their verbal support for his government.
The list Mr. Karzai gave today of his government's undeniable achievements and the cheering he received from police and military officers who filled the auditorium spoke for themselves.
Among those achievements is Mr. Karzai's success in binding together a disparate cabinet that includes veterans of the guerrilla war against the Soviets, Western-educated Afghans who returned after 20 years abroad and representatives of ethnic groups that had been fighting one another. 
In a striking gesture of support, his defense minister, Marshal Muhammad Qasim Fahim, warned regional commanders in his speech today that they must give up some of their power and bow to the authority of the central government. It was the strongest sign yet of the Marshal Fahim's readiness to move against the powerful warlords, several of whom are his own supporters and source of power. 
Marshal Fahim, probably the most powerful man in Afghanistan thanks to his control of the bulk of the country's heavy weaponry and men under arms, has been slow to dismantle the forces loyal to him and make way for the civilian authorities. 
The president signed a decree this month to create a multiethnic, regionally diverse national army, which envisions disarmament and demobilization of the various armed militias that fought the Taliban.
Trying to separate political and military powers, Mr. Karzai further ordered military commanders to relinquish political positions and regional leaders or governors to give up their military positions.
Marshal Fahim has been involved in creating the plan for the national army, but his commitment to real change remains to be tested. Without his cooperation, Mr. Karzai's decrees are worth little, since his practical power does not stretch much beyond the capital.
But in his comments today, Marshall Fahim called for sacrifices in order to create a strong central government. 
"We should have a powerful central government according to the wishes of our people, and to achieve this aim, we should make some sacrifices," he said. "We should give up some positions. It is very necessary that we come under the command of the central government, so let's put an end to local military power bases."
Mr. Karzai, as often before, promised constitutional reform and preparations in the coming year for Afghanistan's first democratic elections in more than 20 years. "You will have the right to choose whomever you want," he told the audience.
Speaking in the hall where he was inaugurated on Dec. 22 last year, Mr. Karzai noted with typical understatement that there was still fighting between different groups in some areas, "and in this point, we have not been completely successful."
Disarmament started in some provinces in the last month, but it needs to move faster, he said.
"Although the general security situation is good, sometimes theft, robbery and killing occurs," he said. "Sometimes it is carried out by people who are linked to authority figures working in the government."
In his frank look back over the last year, Mr. Karzai remembered particular low moments -- the killing of over 40 civilians in Deh Rawud, in southern Afghanistan on July 1, during a raid by American-led forces hunting for terrorists; the car bomb that killed 30 men and women in central Kabul on Sept. 5 (on the same day, there was an attempt on Mr. Karzai's life in Kandahar); the assassination of his vice president, Haji Abdul Qadir, on July 6; and the killing of two students in demonstrations in Kabul last month, for which he blamed ill-trained policemen.
But he also talked of moments of joy and optimism, when during visits to the provinces he encountered ordinary and poor people who had given him their support.

HEADLINE: White House Aides Push for 50% Cut In Dividend Taxes 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
White House officials are urging President Bush to propose cutting taxes on corporate dividends for shareholders by about half, according to administration officials and Republicans close to the White House.
 The proposal, likely to be a crucial part of the tax-cutting plan Mr. Bush will announce in January, is intended to stimulate the economy and reduce what many economists say is an incentive in the current law for companies to avoid paying dividends and to run up debt. While many economists think it would do little to bolster the economy quickly, they say the proposal would give a boost to the stock market. 
 The 50 percent cut would cost the Treasury more than $100 billion over 10 years, and the tax benefits would overwhelmingly flow to the nation's very wealthiest taxpayers. Mr. Bush is in favor of some kind of reduction in the tax on dividends, a White House official said, but has not settled on an amount.
President Bush's entire tax package is expected to provide as much as $300 billion in reductions over 10 years. It is almost certain to speed up both tax cuts that were supposed to take effect over the next several years and corporate write-offs for investment in new equipment. Officials are also considering measures that benefit middle- or lower-income families, like a more rapid increase in the child-care tax credit.
Administration officials contend that reducing dividend taxes would immediately increase the underlying value of companies and lower their cost of capital. The short-term political appeal is its potential effect on the stock market, because it would instantly make shares of any company that pays dividends more valuable than before.
The long-term benefit of a cut in the dividend tax, the officials say, would be to greatly reduce the market distortions of taxing dividends twice -- once as corporate profits and once as dividend income to shareholders -- while granting tax deductions on debt interest payments. For shareholders, dividends are now taxed as ordinary income at rates of up to 38.6 percent. By comparison, the maximum tax rate on capital gains -- the profit made from the increase in value of shares or other kinds of property -- is 20 percent.
Many economists are skeptical that a cut in dividend taxes would provide much immediate stimulus to the economy, which has been Mr. Bush's most important justification for new tax cuts. It would be at least a year before shareholders see any extra money, and the measure would not leave extra money in corporate coffers.
"One wouldn't think of this as the first or second or even third measure to stimulate consumption or investment," said Alan Auerbach, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley who has studied the issue for years. 
While the tax on dividends has been a focus of White House discussions, there have been many proposals on how such a reduction could be structured. A White House official cautioned this week that Mr. Bush has not yet decided on exactly how much to reduce the tax on corporate dividends, but the official said advisers agreed in principle on the most logical proposal. 
As envisioned, a person would be able to exclude a substantial share of all stock dividends -- probably about half -- from taxation. There would be no upper limit on the dollar value of dividends that would be tax free, which means that most of the relief would flow to the largest investors.
The Urban-Brooking Tax Policy Center, a research center here, recently calculated that, if the government completely eliminated taxes on corporate dividends, 42 percent of the tax benefits would flow to the wealthiest 1 percent of all taxpayers.
Republicans close to the White House said there were several reasons why officials were attracted to the idea of letting taxpayers exclude about half of all dividend income from taxes.
Eliminating all taxes on corporate dividends would drain so much money from the Treasury -- about $300 billion over 10 years, according to some estimates -- that President Bush would have no room for other tax cuts.
Reducing dividend taxes by about half, to about 20 percent for people in the top tax bracket, would not only reduce the drain on revenue to the Treasury but also bring dividend taxes in line with those on capital gains. 
Tax analysts said that would eliminate one imbalance in the current tax system that favors fast-growing companies like Microsoft that pay no dividends but attract investors with the prospect of big increases in their stock prices.
Administration officials have looked at ways to reduce dividend taxes that would primarily benefit small investors, but White House advisers say those would do little to correct distortions in the current system.
One option would be to eliminate taxes on the first $1,000 or $3,000 in dividend income. But White House officials think that approach would do little to reduce the distortions in the system because it would not change incentives for the big investors who actually reap most dividends.
Many outside economists agree. "There is a fundamental tension between the distributional effects of these measures and the incentive effect you are trying to achieve," said James Poterba, a professor of economics and public finance at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
That the tax cuts themselves would flow overwhelmingly to the nation's wealthiest taxpayers is a fact that Democrats are sure to cite as evidence that the administration wants to cut taxes only for the rich.
Democratic lawmakers are pushing for tax measures that would benefit lower- and middle-income households, like a temporary "holiday" from Social Security taxes or a temporary exemption for the first several thousand dollars in taxable income.
Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a research group backed by labor unions, said the entire complaint about "double taxation" was dubious because corporations make such heavy use of legal tax shelters and loopholes.
Although the top corporate tax rate is 35 percent, the average tax rate is only about 15 percent, Mr. McIntyre has estimated on the basis of analyzing corporate tax data.
"Don't worry about the double tax," Mr. McIntyre said. "Worry about the half tax."
But business groups have themselves often been lukewarm about cutting dividend taxes as well, pushing harder for more direct benefits like faster write-offs on new equipment or reductions in overall corporate tax rates.
This year, business lobbyists say they support a cut in the dividend taxes -- but not at the expense of other measures that would cut business taxes more directly.
If President Bush has his way, the dividend tax cut will be a permanent change to the tax code. The only reason Mr. Bush may settle for less is that the Senate's complex rules on filibustering make it easier to pass a tax measure that has time limits.

HEADLINE: Venezuela's Oil Chief Says He Will Make Big Changes 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
Venezuela's chief oil official, Ali Rodriguez, said today that he would begin sweeping changes -- including laying off workers and hiring foreign specialists -- in response to the national strike that has battered the state-owned oil company for most of the month. 
 In an interview with American reporters, Mr. Rodriguez, president of the national oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, acknowledged that the strike, aimed at forcing President Hugo Chavez to resign and call new elections, had brought the company close to collapse. Crude exports have plummeted, he said, from more than 2.5 million barrels a day to fewer than 2 million barrels this month, and refineries, wells and tankers are all but unmanned and inoperable. 
 The crisis here has pushed crude oil prices to more than $30 a barrel.
When asked about the lines of cars that stretch for miles outside most Venezuelan gas stations, Mr. Rodriguez, who was appointed by Mr. Chavez, acknowledged that the country had come close to chaos. He blamed strike leaders and said they would be prosecuted for conspiring to overthrow the government.
Openly beleaguered and outraged, Mr. Rodriguez offered a stark contrast to the demeanor of Mr. Chavez, who routinely plays down the effects of the strike.
Mr. Rodriguez, who once took part in guerrilla movements and later became the president of OPEC, saved his most bitter remarks for the oil executives he said were leading the strike and trying, in his eyes, to use oil to take over the country.
Speaking in his office, Mr. Rodriguez said he had suspended several striking oil executives. He also said the government was preparing to sue some strike leaders for $1.3 billion in damages and, in some cases, pursue criminal prosecutions.
"They have begun to use oil as a political weapon," he said. "In Venezuela, a group of managers, taking advantage of their positions, decided to use Venezuelan oil as a political weapon to impose their will on the state and on society."
However, Mr. Rodriguez contended, the strike organizers failed. He said that the government, which has had the support of the armed forces during the conflict, had begun to regain control of the facilities and that operations would quickly return to normal. 
He pledged that Venezuelans would have fresh gasoline supplies by next week. He also urged Venezuela's international clients to stay patient and said exports would climb to normal levels by next month.
"I would say, in the month of January, we will have completely normalized the flow," he said. "I'm talking about the exports of crude. It will take time to restart the wells and to equip the plants."
Privately, supporters of the strike said they had underestimated Mr. Chavez's ability to keep gas and oil flowing for this long, though at critically low levels. Political experts said the conflict between Mr. Chavez and his opponents had reached a kind of stalemate.
However, opposition leaders pledged to keep up the strike. Most also dismissed Mr. Rodriguez's expectations for the quick recovery of the nation's oil industry as pipe dreams.
"Starting the refineries is simply impossible in one month," said Horacio Medina, president of a leading oil workers' organization. "Supposing that in January the workers -- not some, but all -- returned to work, restarting the industry would take at least four months."
The interview with Mr. Rodriguez today provided the government's most frank assessment of the devastation at Venezuela's oil wells and refineries since the start of the strike, which was called by Mr. Chavez's opponents. Combined with several small victories by the government in recent days, Mr. Rodrguez's comments signaled that Mr. Chavez had gained momentum in the struggle to survive his latest and most dangerous political challenge.
When workers abandoned their posts at the state-owned oil company, they cut off the nation's lifeblood. Oil generates 80 percent of the government's export revenues and most of the money it needs for social programs and other obligations.
Mr. Rodriguez predicted that economic aftershocks of the strike would be felt through the first trimester of next year. He said operations were closed at the refining complex at Paraguana, considered one of the world's largest.
Shortages of gasoline, Mr. Rodriguez said, have forced Venezuela to begin buying imports for the first time since the 1940's. He added that the state-owned oil industry had defaulted on international oil commitments for the first time since the beginning of the last century.
Strike planners, Mr. Rodriguez said, had delivered a crippling blow. "The plan this group had was to paralyze the distribution of gas internally," he said. "These people know the business well, and they understood that if they paralyzed the distribution of gas it would create total chaos. It would generate a situation of anarchy that would show the government was incapable of guaranteeing the stability of the country, and provoke its overthrow."
Meanwhile, he said, the company's remaining workers face a "titanic effort" in trying to lift up a fallen giant. His strategy, he said, is to stabilize fuel supplies for domestic consumption, strengthening the government ability to ride out the strike while weakening an increasingly divided opposition.
He said he would seek the advice of foreign and national experts for a restructuring of the company that would cut costs and increase efficiency as well as make it less vulnerable to political storms. He gave few details on exactly how the company would be restructured but indicated that there would be worker layoffs and that some company-owned related businesses would be sold off. 
Mr. Chavez secured the support of the military and asked it to provide security at oil installations. On Sunday, Venezuela dispatched a ship filled with 500,000 barrels of crude to the United States, and another had begun loading 370,000 barrels headed for Chile. Replacement crews also began to recover and move tankers that had been under the control of striking workers. A few had begun delivering fuel at domestic ports.
Mr. Rodriguez said the company had begun rebuilding its labor force, with nonstriking workers, retirees and other former oil workers called back to service. Fewer than 20 percent of the management ranks had returned to work, Mr. Rodriguez said. But he said the passage of time had begun to shift attitudes among the rank and file. He also predicted that "the majority" of oil workers would be on duty by the second week of January.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
How the West Was Measured, One Chain at a Time

BYLINE:  By RICHARD EDER 

 BODY:
MEASURING AMERICA
How an Untamed Wilderness Shaped the United States and Fulfilled the Promise of Democracy
By Andro Linklater
Illustrated. 310 pages. Walker & Company. $26.
 "Measuring America" begins at the Point of Beginning, the name designated in 1785 for a stretch of border between Pennsylvania and the uncharted Ohio territory to the west. 
 It was the starting point from which the surveyor Thomas Hutchins struggled to map the territory in mile-square sections. Under more competent but equally struggling successors (who encountered swamps, cliffs, gulches, mosquitoes, hostile Indians and settlers), these squares would eventually extend as a checkerboard across the continent.
For air travelers who decline to lower their shades for the movie, these squares may evoke the Jeffersonian vision -- overtaken even then and long since obliterated -- of a United States of sturdy farmers, each living on a section or part-section of republican independence and yeoman virtues.
Jefferson, Washington, Madison and Hamilton wanted the mapping done by decimal measurement. The flood of settlers and speculators already spilling westward meant that there was no time to work out the new and still disputed system. Measurement would be made by a device already in use for some 150 years: the surveyor's chain, 66 feet long and 80 chains to the mile.
In "Measuring America," Andro Linklater tells us all about the chain: its history, method of use and particular advantages. He has the talent not just to let us know how things work, but to make us want to know. Discussing this and other technologies with an enthusiast's detailed passion, he engages himself in a great deal more.
Scarcely four pages into the book he is tackling the notion that for most of history, up to Tudor England perhaps, it was the use of land and not land itself that was considered a possession. It might be individual, as a hereditary feudal right derived ultimately from the monarch; or collective, as with the right of American Indian tribes -- derived from the spirit-given nature of things -- to wander, plant and hunt. Mr. Linklater points, by contrast, to the magic that Hutchins would introduce into the Western lands, the transformation of the wilderness into property.
"The wand that would make it possible was there in the first sentence of his report. The land would be measured in chains and links. In most circumstances, a chain imprisons; here it released. What it released from the billowing, uncharted land was a single element -- a distance of 22 yards."
Later he will express some reservations about the constraints that followed upon release. There was the rolling treaty-breaking displacement of the Indians; there is to this day an American ethos extreme in its adherence to the private over the public.
Here, though, his point is that the very possibility of property depends on measurement and that commerce as well as science is inconceivable without it. Next to language, measurement is the most fundamental agent of social exchange, he argues.
How much is your bushel? the buyer asks, confident of knowing how much is in the bushel. Mr. Linklater gives engaging examples of the much longer history of measurement unsettled. New York City traders, taking advantage of the rube-grown grain floated in by the new Erie Canal, would use a bigger bushel for buying, a smaller one for selling.
(Today, of course, we get less and less coffee in a same-priced can. Fundamental or not: the measure of all things may define man, but something there is in man that does not love it.)
Mr. Linklater encloses his specifics inside generalities inside universals, as if they were nested Russian dolls. The core is America's parceling out. Apart from the original 13 colonies, the vast expanse of what would become the United States consisted of great tracts acquired by treaty or war (the Louisiana Purchase and California, for example). 
From Jefferson on, the government's policy was to pass along most of this land -- one billion acres -- from national to individual ownership. "In economic terms alone, it has represented the greatest orderly transfer of public resources to the private sector in history," the author tells us.
He writes of the strains between the Jeffersonian vision of the small farm owner and encroachment by the huge speculator, often helped by political connections. Many individual farmers did get land; on the other hand, there was John Cleves Symmes, who persuaded the Continental Congress to sell him a million acres west of the Point of Beginning for $82,000. His backer was John Dayton, soon to be speaker of the new Congress. He received four of Symmes's townships; one of them is now Dayton, Ohio.
Part of the payment was in military warrants, issued in lieu of cash to members of the Continental Army. Their price dropped to 10 cents on the dollar, but they still bought their full value in land. Symmes and others snapped them up.
Mr. Linklater writes in a detail that can become reiterative as he goes from territory to territory. More characteristically, though, his book tends to shoot out in all directions and, seemingly, all of them at once. This confuses, but it also provides a magical mystery tour that leaves the reader both mildly footsore and exhilarated by unexpected connections.
His account of the battle for the metric system, set in France, England and the United States, is a high point. French revolutionaries shared with others a passion for decimals, but carried it further, wanting to decimalize days of the week and months of the year. Americans decimalized currency from the start; miles and pounds popularly resist kilometers and kilos to this day. A Canadian supermarket was observed selling frozen turkeys by the kilo, fresh ones by the pound.
Even in a metric Europe there is local resistance, and the author thinks he knows why. The ell, a former English unit of measure, was, after all, the length of an outstretched arm; the yard the length of a pace back when journeys were walked. "The metric system forced people to separate the measure from the activity altogether and deal with an abstract unit," he writes. "What underlay the popular dislike of the metric system was a very modern anxiety, the sense of alienation from the natural world."
Throughout the book, Mr. Linklater has allowed his humans wonderfully to subvert his measurings.

HEADLINE: At the America's Cup, A Battle of Boat Sheds 

BYLINE:  By WARREN ST. JOHN 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand 

 BODY:
IT wasn't so long ago that America's Cup bases were simply forts disguised as boat sheds. In an event notorious for espionage --scuba-diving spies have inspected rivals' keels -- protecting millions of dollars' worth of yacht design secrets always took precedence over playing host to corporate sponsors, to say nothing of the public. Bases were windowless boxes ornamented with chain link and razor wire.
 But glasnost has arrived, if creepingly, at the America's Cup, thanks mainly to the need for sponsors to support the monster budgets of the current campaigns, some of which have exceeded $100 million. For their millions, corporate donors like BMW, Computer Associates and UBS Warburg expect more than team hats and sweatshirts: they want to be near the action. 
 As a result, a few big-money teams have turned their boatyards -- cranes, sail lofts, sheds, corporate offices and mess halls big enough to feed 140 employees -- into architectural statements with grand rooms for entertaining honchos. 
In the case of Alinghi, the Swiss syndicate, there are even exhibitions and rides designed to draw the public: the first such attractions in America's Cup history. 
"You have to have your fans, and your sponsors feel that they're involved with the team and that you're not perceived as being untouchable," said Joanna Ingley, a spokeswoman for Oracle-BMW. When the cup is over in March, the bases will be torn down to make room for more luxury apartments on Auckland's Viaduct Harbor, a decrepit fishing wharf rebuilt into a shiny new restaurant-ringed marina for the last America's Cup, in 2000. Contracts with the government agency that runs the America's Cup village in Auckland require the teams to leave only parking lots when they depart.
For now though, nine bases line a quarter-mile stretch of Halsey Street, with their backs and docks facing the water. Each base reflects the personality of the syndicate it houses. Almost all are built of corrugated steel, which is to New Zealand what stucco is to Southern California.
The base of the Swedish team Victory Challenge is a model of Nordic practicality. It has a black facade painted with the yellow cross of the Swedish flag, and the interior is a minimalist aggregation of particle-board and metal shelving. Larry Ellison's Oracle-BMW team has a huge crescent-roof barge tied up in front of its base, the kind of glass-and steel-entertainment center you might expect from a Silicon Valley corporation. OneWorld, the Seattle syndicate financed by Craig McCaw, dedicated its campaign to the oceans. Its base is covered in environmentally safe paints and has a large rooftop funnel to collect rainwater for washing boats.
"The philosophy was to create something that was completely functional, economically practical and environmentally sensitive," said Bob Ratliffe, the executive director of OneWorld.
But the most ambitious base is that of Alinghi, the Swiss syndicate, which looms over the harbor like a cloud and looks more Epcot Center than a boatyard. The syndicate, which is financed by the pharmaceuticals mogul Ernesto Bertarelli, rented twice as much space as other teams, and its base has not just a plan but a plot.
In 2000, Mr. Bertarelli hired away two New Zealand heros to sail for his landlocked nation: Russell Coutts, the skipper who won the America's Cup twice, and his tactician, Brad Butterworth.
The defection of the local stars went over in Auckland the way Walter O'Malley's decision to move the Dodgers to Los Angeles went over in Brooklyn. Imagine if O'Malley had had to build a pavilion at the 1964 World's Fair, and you'll get a sense of the predicament Alinghi faced when it came to town. The syndicate held a competition and awarded the base to the architect Ugo Brunoni, best known for the round Ste.-Trinite church in Geneva, and gave him a mandate to take the public inside the base. Michel Hodara, an Alinghi spokesman, said the open base was meant to generate good will with a nation whose citizens would prefer to see the Swiss boat sink.
"If you do something nice for the people, if you show them you can do something for them, their emotions are tempered," he said. "If they come in here and see all these Alinghi people, they'll say, 'I don't like them, but O.K.' "
The result is the ultimate multipurpose dwelling. The building is sided in two layers of translucent corrugated plexiglass with a sheet of light-permeable foil in the middle, which blocks out heat while allowing sunlight in, just as the roofs of United Parcel Service trucks do. As a result, it is possible to work in Alinghi's two boat sheds in natural light. Even the material, Mr. Hodara said, was intended to carry a message to a skeptical public. "It's transparent because we want to be transparent as a team," he said.
Half of the building is for the public. There's an "interactive plaza" with computerized sailing games and a ride that simulates the experience of being a bowman on an America's Cup boat: the yachting equivalent of a mechanical bull, it jerks and bobs, and it heaves visitors onto thick foam mats. Upstairs there's a cafe, sleekly decorated in the team's gunmetal gray and red, with views of Viaduct Harbor and large-screen television sets and computers for watching the races.
The rest of the structure is for the syndicate -- part office building, part urban gym and, of course, part boat shed. Design and business offices are on the second floor, behind locked doors, to keep the public out. The area for the sailors is laid out to accommodate their daily routine seamlessly. The gym opens onto the locker room and showers, which lead to a dehumidified drying room for foul-weather gear. Sailors pass through a door into their mess hall and from there downstairs to their briefing rooms, the sheds and eventually the docks. The layout, Mr. Hodara states, makes the base not just a fancy shed but a "tool for victory."
John D. Barnitt, an Alinghi crewman, said that along with offering the team everything it needed, the souped-up building was another chit in the subtle psychological warfare between teams. Not surprisingly, it has given rise to a new Cup phenomenon: base envy.
"I've never been to this level of facility," Mr. Barnitt said. "Before, the bases were made of porta-cabins stacked one on top of the other. Here the gym is integrated, the boat-building and modification facilities are amazing, and we have the designers in-house. Launching and covering the boats takes half the time."
The old paranoia surrounding the bases has not completely abated. When Larry Ellison's Oracle-BMW team docked its barge at the end of its base, its next-door neighbors, the Italian team Prada, sued, charging the barge was a ploy to peek over the walls and get a glimpse of Prada's secret goings-on. (Prada withdrew the suit when it was reminded that taking the competition to court was against the rules.)
The principle design problem facing the architect of any America's Cup base is how to let the public feel welcome without letting it see anything that actually matters. While guests can see the boats being launched in the morning and hauled out in the afternoon, they are not permitted to enter the sheds, where top-secret modifications to the hull and rigging are conducted throughout the night.
"Certain parts of the base are out of bounds, partly for sensitivity and partly for safety," said Ms. Ingley of Oracle. "We're not going to allow access within the boat sheds."
But for a sport that can seem exclusive, if not hopelessly obscure -- the races take place in the Hauraki Gulf, far out of sight of Auckland -- the corporate hospitality suite of a cup base is as close as many people will ever get to the action. 
As Mr. Hodara of Alinghi put it, "If you want to open the sport of sailing to a greater number of people, you have to give them more than just the game."

HEADLINE: One-Word Shoppers' Lexicon: Price 

BYLINE:  ByCONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Like many shoppers, John and Mary Salkowsky like to float across the retail landscape, alighting in department stores like Macy's, discounters like Wal-Mart and hybrids like Kohl's. They are interested in quality, but the deal maker is the price tag.
 So last week, as the Prescott, Ariz., couple vacationed in Monroe, N.Y., they had their collective eye out for bargains. Inside the local Kohl's, they were considering whether to buy an electric shaver. Did they want it? Did they need it? It all came down to whether the price was right. 
 "There are always sales," Mr. Salkowsky said. "Why pay retail when you can get it on sale?" 
That attitude may have played a big part in a holiday retailing season that saw many stores, particularly department stores, report dismal results. A decade ago, consumers were more loyal to certain stores and certain kinds of stores, attracted by atmosphere, assortment, customer service and price. To buy brand names, one usually had to shop in a department store, and that alone carried cachet. To be a discount shopper meant being lumped with the proletariat.
Today, the notion that a person can be measured by where he or she shops has gone the way of the pneumatic tube, and the once-mysterious ways of merchandising have been reduced, in most places, to a single element: price.
"You could be at a dinner party on Fifth Avenue and millionaires will be talking about what they got at Wal-Mart," said Marshal Cohen, co-president of NPD Fashionworld, which tracks retail sales. 
In dozens of recent interviews, shoppers said that their economic status did not determine where they shopped. They just did not want to pay a lot for that muffler. Or that sweater, or that digital camera. 
"People know, with the discounters around, that instead of buying something at Macy's, they can get many of those things at Target or Kohl's," said Craig Johnson, president of Customer Growth Partners, a research firm in New York and New Canaan, Conn. "Consumers are much better educated now than they ever used to be." 
Certain products, particularly in electronics and housewares, have become commodities that play into the retail strategies of discounters in particular. With shoppers already familiar with a product, say a DVD player, no-frills retailers can "stack them high," as the saying goes, and sell them cheap, with no extra investment in sales help. It has helped trim away the differences between specialty retailers and discounters in many cases, and all but eliminated the reasons many people once shopped at department stores. 
The exodus from swell department stores to bare-bones discounters has accelerated in the last five years. In 1994, people polled by Mr. Johnson's firm spent 41.5 percent of their money in department stores. By this year, through September, that number had fallen to 16 percent. Meanwhile discount stores, which accounted for 41.4 percent of spending in 1994, have risen to 55 percent. Most of that growth has taken place since 1997, Mr. Johnson said.
The stores themselves have also moved closer together. Kohl's appears to be a department store, with wall-to-wall carpet and orderly displays. But it is known for discounts and tries to make shopping easier with grocery carts for people to fill with stuff. There is a single checkout point at the front of the store, like a Kmart. 
Kohl's has grown so rapidly that other retailers, including Sears, Roebuck, are borrowing from its example. Sears is reconfiguring stores to include front checkouts; the chain already has shopping carts. 
Wal-Mart Stores, meanwhile, which built its early success by catering to low- and middle-income shoppers in rural areas, is increasing its big-ticket offerings in hopes of attracting more well-to-do shoppers. For example, 150 Wal-Mart stores are selling $3,000 plasma TV's.
In some cases, people who need things simply go to the store nearest them, without feeling any particular loyalty to it. "You see more name brands in Toys "R" Us," said Mary Beth Lindberg, a mother of two who was loading toys into her car outside the Monroe Wal-Mart the other day. But the Wal-Mart is closer, so she goes there. 
"It's not even a money issue," she added. "It's convenient, and why spend twice the amount?" She said she rarely went to discount stores before she moved to Rockland County from Queens three years ago. 
And while they say they want quality as well as price, many shoppers are willing to bend a little on one in favor of the other. Bill Chapman, an industrial maintenance manager from Crawfordville, Ga., likes Ralph Lauren golf shirts. He shops the sales, and finds them "plenty of times at half price," he said. He will buy colors he wouldn't normally choose, he added, if they are priced at 50 percent off. 
Some department stores are trying to play by the new price rules. Macy's, a unit of Federated Department Stores, was offering deep discounts on sweaters at its Union Square store in San Francisco last weekend. "They send a card in the mail for another 10 to 15 percent off and another coupon, and you can put them all together," said Kevin Cope, one satisfied shopper. "There are $80 sweaters that I walked out with for 18 bucks." 
Not only have changes taken place in where people shop, but also in when they shop. Instead of descending on stores the day after Thanksgiving, more shoppers have taken to waiting until the final weekend before Christmas. Dec. 26 is also a big shopping day. 
Merchants have shifted the shopping schedule with their promotions. "Ten years ago, you would never think about seeing something on sale before Christmas," Mr. Cohen said. "But five years ago, retailers started having a tougher time, and their assortments were sort of homogeneous. They started to promote, and things would go on sale just before the holiday if they weren't doing well."
That was the pre-Christmas sale, for those down-to-the-wire shoppers. And then, about a year ago, the stores crossed into a new frontier. "Now you see promotions even before Thanksgiving," Mr. Cohen said.
Most shopping for Christmas presents still takes place in December. Yet retailers no longer have huge proportions of their yearly sales in December. Some categories, like books, ring up 15 percent of their sales in December, but very few handle more than that, Mr. Johnson said. "Nobody packs 25, 30 percent into a single month, not even in December."
The other big change in shopping, of course, has been the advent of the Internet. 
All kinds of things are available online. Shane Ottosen, an auto mechanic from Dane, Wis., is buying nitrous oxide for his friends this year from a source he had not used until a few months ago: Ebay. The discounts make economic sense, he said, even though he does not know whom he is buying from. (He is not sending his buddies laughing gas; they use the nitrous oxide for drag racing, where it makes the cars go faster.)
Then there is the electronic form of discount shopping. Scott Krasik, a retail analyst in Manhattan for C. L. King Associates, worked through most of his Christmas list online this year, mainly using Walmart.com. Mr. Krasik said he bought 15 or 20 presents for relatives and his girlfriend's family, spending less than $1,000.
The big advantage, he said, was being able to avoid "the aggravation" of shopping in stores. 
"I've been out in the Willowbrook Mall on the Sunday before Christmas, and that's not a pleasant experience," he said, referring to the shopping center in Wayne, N.J. "But it was like I was wandering through a mall on Walmart.com. I had a list of people I was going to buy for, but not a single present I knew I was going to buy." 
After about two and a half hours of Web surfing, he wound up with selections like bird feeders and clock radios. And then he had to go to stores with his girlfriend anyway. 
"We spent 10 hours on her shopping last weekend," Mr. Krasik said, "and she likes that."

HEADLINE: Ivory Coast's Raging Conflict Draws France In 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
As the United States rushes to complete its war preparations against Iraq, France is becoming more deeply enmeshed in a conflict on a much different battlefield: Ivory Coast.
 The complicated dispute in France's former colony -- once the most stable and prosperous country in West Africa -- is France's largest and most precarious military commitment in Africa in almost two decades. 
 Although it has received scant attention in the United States, it has dominated conversation in the corridors of power and news reports in France since rebels tried to overthrow the government three months ago.
France has more than 2,500 troops, including members of the Foreign Legion, in Ivory Coast. The most recent deployment of 300 troops, accompanied by helicopters and light armored vehicles, will be operational by next week. 
Their stated mission is twofold: to serve as a buffer between government and rebel forces along a cease-fire line until a multinational West African force takes over and to protect French and other foreign residents living in the country.
But little by little, the French troops have been drawn into what may become a long war that could spiral into anarchy.
The situation deteriorated on Monday after Ivory Coast's three rebel factions warned French troops that any military attack on rebel positions would be considered a "cause for war." The rebels also began discussing forming a coalition, a move that could significantly increase their power.
Those developments followed a clash last Saturday in which French Foreign Legion troops equipped with light tanks fired on a rebel group. The rebels had opened fire on French soldiers as they approached the strategic town of Duekoue from the northeast after bypassing government troops, according to a French army spokesman.
The French troops initially fired in the air but then responded to the attack. Three four-wheel drive vehicles belonging to the rebels were destroyed, and rebels said the assault had killed six people.
The Ivory Coast conflict has it origins in bitter ethnic and religious divisions that have built steadily since the death nine years ago of Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the country's longtime autocratic ruler. 
A succession of presidents from the Christian south have worked assiduously and often unscrupulously in the intervening years to deny power to Alassane D. Ouattara, a popular leader from the more heavily populated and predominantly Muslim northern region. He was barred from the election in September 2000 that brought Laurent Gbagbo, Ivory Coast's current president, to power.
Disaffected northern soldiers rose up against President Gbagbo in a coup last September.
About 400 people were killed in the uprising, which has shattered the reputation the Ivory Coast as a country with a stable government, a vibrant economy and an infrastructure that works. Since then, two other rebel groups have emerged and tens of thousands of people have been forced to flee their homes. 
The conflict has been complicated by rumors of the involvement of foreign powers and mercenaries, the discovery of two mass graves believed to hold up to 200 bodies and human rights abuses reported to have been committed by both government forces and rebels.
French troops intervened initially to protect foreign civilians caught in the fighting. But as rebels from different factions began to advance toward the country's largest city, Abidjan, French troops have increasingly been put in the position of keeping them away from the government-controlled part of the country.
The rebels, and even some French newspapers, have accused France of trying to prop up the increasingly unpopular government, and they warn against a deeper involvement.
"The French are not invincible," Guillaume Soro, a leader of the main rebel group, said on Sunday. "They lost in Indochina. We can at least make sure there are families mourning in France as well as in Ivory Coast."
"France has found itself in a trap," said Bernard Conte, a political economist who is an expert on Ivory Coast. "France's intervention started out as humanitarian, and now it is preventing the rebels from advancing. So it is gives the impression that it has taken sides."
A recent editorial in Le Figaro said, "By choosing what side it is on, Paris is taking a huge risk." An editorial in Le Monde said, "In terms of realpolitik, Ivory Coast, where only bad things can happen, holds no interest for anyone, not for France, not moreover for the United States."
The rebels have called the foreign troops an army of "conquest and occupation," a charge that France has denied.
"There is no question of our setting off to reconquer Ivory Coast or engaging in offensive operations," the chief of staff of the French Army, Gen. Henri Bentegeat, said on Sunday during a visit to Abidjan.
Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa grower, was once the jewel in the French colonial crown, and Abidjan was called the Paris of West Africa. Even now, 20,000 French citizens live in the country, and French corporations are involved in public works and utility projects.
President Jacques Chirac is determined that France play the lead in bringing restoring order.
But President Abdoulaye Wade of Senegal, the current chairman of the Economic Community of West African States, said recently that regional troops could not be sent until the rebels and the government reached a political settlement.
That means that French troops may have to stay. France "can leave 2,500 men in Ivory Coast for some years if need be," General Bentegeat said on Sunday, if that is required to negotiate a political solution.

HEADLINE: Michigan to Drop Minimum Sentence Rules for Drug Crimes 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 25 

 BODY:
Karen Shook was sentenced to 20 years in prison in 1993 for arranging a drug deal for a man who turned out to be an undercover police officer. But Ms. Shook, a former bank teller, could be paroled 10 years early under legislation expected to be signed by the governor in the next week to eliminate mandatory minimum sentences for drug crimes. 
 Michigan is one of several states revising mandatory minimum sentences. Connecticut, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Missouri, New Jersey and North Carolina are also considering eliminating such rules, said Laura Sager, executive director of Families Against Mandatory Minimums, a Washington group. 
 Michigan Department of Corrections officials do not know how many of the state's 49,296 inmates could be eligible for parole under the legislation, which would take effect March 1. But supporters of the legislation said the state's skyrocketing prison population made the law necessary.
Critics of Michigan's mandatory minimum sentencing guidelines have pushed for changes for years, but economic difficulties may ultimately have led to their elimination.
The state, facing a $1.5 billion general fund deficit in the coming fiscal year, spends about $1.4 billion a year on its prison population, or an average of $28,000 for each inmate, said Russ Marlan, a spokesman for the Department of Corrections.
This month, as the Legislature struggled with the state budget, it approved eliminating mandatory sentences. The departing governor, John Engler, a Republican, supports the move. 
Laurie Quick, Ms. Shook's sister, said her family did not know about the state's strict sentencing guidelines until Ms. Shook, now 49, was arrested.
"It's been a nightmare," Ms. Quick said. "She has seen murderers and other convicted felons come and leave since she's been there. It's cruel."
Although the Michigan legislation would make some offenders eligible for early parole, a decision about their release is ultimately up to the parole board. Drug offenders have the highest rate of parole, at 72 percent, Mr. Marlan said.
Nearly 62 percent of other nonviolent offenders receive parole when they are first eligible, followed by violent offenders at 40 percent and sex offenders at 15 percent, he said.
The legislation requires judges to follow state guidelines when sentencing criminals to prison. But eliminating mandatory minimums will give them much more discretion.
"The time had come to make the change," said David Morse, the Livingston County prosecutor. "The idea of stiff severe penalties for drug kingpins was a problem because we weren't getting those kingpins. We were getting people who were carrying on behalf of kingpins."
Under current law, Michigan judges are allowed to deviate from the mandatory minimum guidelines only in extraordinary circumstances.
Now, the law requires a sentence of at least 10 years and up to 20 years in prison for a person convicted of possessing 50 to 224 grams of narcotics or cocaine. The legislation would allow the judge to impose any sentence up to 20 years.
