HEADLINE: G.E. Research Returns to Roots; 
Management Again Gambles On Costly Long-Term Ideas

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

DATELINE: NISKAYUNA, N.Y. 

 BODY:
Anil Duggal is 37 years old, but he looks like a mischievous boy as he turns his office lights low. He hits a button and grins gleefully as the flat panel he holds generates a white glow bright enough to light the room.
 The panel is made from thin sheets of specially treated plastic on glass that seems to generate almost as much light from a small jolt of electricity as an incandescent light bulb running on standard current. 
 If Mr. Duggal and his team of researchers at the General Electric Global Research Center in this small town not far from Schenectady can figure out how to dispense with the glass, they could be a short hop away from developing super-thin lighting and energy sources that could be rolled off printing presses like newspapers. And that could usher in an era of cheap, clean-burning lights, batteries, solar cells -- and the beginning of plastic-based electronics. 
These days, Mr. Duggal's laboratory, where he specializes in light and energy, is a regular stop for Jeffrey R. Immelt, G.E.'s chief executive, as well as the heads of G.E.'s businesses. Mr. Duggal reassures them that his project is a question of when, not if, and that he is meeting research milestones. But he does not promise a new product any time soon, and no one pressures him to do so.
"People used to ask for quarterly progress reports, and I had to struggle to get funding renewed," said Mr. Duggal, who joined G.E. in 1992. "Now I feel I have at least two years before I have to show progress."
For G.E., that change is nearly as radical as the science being pursued. John F. Welch Jr., Mr. Immelt's predecessor, spent two decades pushing the Niskayuna lab to churn out profitable products. Now Mr. Immelt is letting it return to the mission that Charles P. Steinmetz, a G.E. engineer who set up the lab, laid forth more than 100 years ago.
"Steinmetz did not want this lab to worry about next quarter's product," said Scott C. Donnelly, senior vice president for research. "He wanted it to work on the next big idea, even as G.E.'s businesses were refining the last one."
The numbers reflect the shift back to those roots. Two years ago the central lab spent $28 million, or only about 10 percent of its $286 million budget, on long-term projects. This year, $91 million of the center's $344 million budget has gone to such research; next year, the center's team expects to direct $104 million -- almost 30 percent of its $349 million budget -- to long-range projects.
Some of the money comes from G.E.'s business units. But it is not used to improve whistles or polish bells.
"When Aircraft Engines wants a turbine blade, or Medical Systems wants a CT scanner that does thinner slices, we say 'Hey guys, you are capable of doing that yourself,' " Mr. Donnelly said. "We use the central lab to study things that require major technological breakthroughs."
The business leaders have bought into that idea. "I come up regularly to make sure that the stuff they are looking at will make a difference in the marketplace," said John G. Rice, president of GE Power Systems. "It just doesn't have to make a difference in three or even five years."
Some projects will be dead ends. On others, G.E. may be beaten to market by one of the start-ups carving niches in biotechnology, nanotechnology and other modern-day sciences.
But G.E. must take the gamble. Its industrial businesses are suffering in the sluggish economy and its insurance units are still reeling from losses associated with last year's terrorist attacks. Competitors like Siemens, Royal Philips Electronics and United Technologies are all stepping up long-term research. And G.E.'s executives know that if they are first to introduce innovative products, they will grab customers not just for equipment, but for the lucrative contracts to service that equipment.
"Jack Welch won the socket wars, the battle to stay ahead with tangible products," said Nicholas P. Heymann, who follows G.E. for Prudential Securities. "Jeff must now use R.& D. to win the value-added wars."
According to Mr. Immelt, G.E. is "incubating" service-heavy businesses in security, water treatment, oil and gas and other areas that cannot be bolted onto existing G.E. units. It is even doing research into hydrogen energy, which some see as a way, first, to turn fossil fuels into clean energy and ultimately as a means to replace petroleum.
"I'd be surprised if, a bunch of years down the road," Mr. Immelt said, "we aren't into businesses that require new names."
In the meantime, Mr. Immelt is trying to recreate Niskayuna's glory days. It was here, in 1913, that William Coolidge invented the X-ray tube, eventually giving birth to the diagnostic imaging industry -- and to GE Medical Systems. Now, his intellectual descendents are using information from the human genome project and similar efforts to develop molecular imaging techniques that could probe each bodily cell -- and spot diseases before any symptoms occur.
Lexan polycarbonate, the first super-strong heat resistant plastic and the precursor to the whole family of so-called engineered thermoplastics, was born here in 1953; it became the underpinning of GE Plastics.
Today, G.E.'s nanotechnology researchers are studying why nature can turn calcium carbonate into lustrous, strong seashells, while human beings can only wrest chalk from the same substance. If they crack that mystery, the result might be heat-resistant ceramic materials that are as light as dinner plates yet as strong as steel. GE Power Systems and GE Aircraft Engines could use the materials to make more durable and efficient generators and turbines, and GE Plastics could probably find a host of outside customers.
In one sense, G.E. is catching up with its competition. Gerard J. Kleisterlee, chief executive of Royal Philips Electronics -- a rival to G.E. in medical equipment -- insists that each of his company's five divisions sponsor research with a three-to-five year time span. "We were giving our business units too much autonomy on how their research money should be spent," he said.
But G.E. has a problem that Philips does not face. When G.E. failed to acquire Honeywell International last year, its portfolio of businesses was left top-heavy with financial services. Even during the best of times the shares of financial services firms trade at lower multiples of earnings than those of advanced industrial companies. G.E. stock, once a Wall Street favorite, is trading at $25.33, about $16 below its level a year ago. 
Clearly, Mr. Immelt faces different challenges than Mr. Welch ever did. Mr. Welch, who rose up through G.E. Plastics, concentrated on paring a bloated management and whipping operations into shape. Research did not escape his baleful glare.
Until Mr. Welch became G.E.'s chief executive in 1981, the central lab had run primarily on corporate dollars and had let researchers follow their instincts. Mr. Welch insisted that the researchers petition G.E.'s business units for funds. He figured -- correctly -- that the units would not pay for projects that just satisfied intellectual curiosity.
"Jack thought the lab operated too much like the old Bell Labs, and they never did much for AT&T," said Noel M. Tichy, a professor at the University of Michigan Business School. "Jeff is nudging the pendulum back toward the center."
Mr. Immelt, who rose through GE Medical Systems, one of G.E.'s most technology-dependent units, established himself as a salesman-cum-technophile early on. He was the first G.E. business leader to apply Six Sigma, a quality control method, to product design. He often asked customers for wish lists, and turned them into work orders for researchers. Now he wants all of G.E. to think -- and act -- along those lines.
"Superior technology is the only route to consistent growth without declining margins," he said.
The researchers say a heavy weight has been lifted. Tony Dean, a mechanical engineer who specializes in propulsion, spends most of his time leading experiments in pulsed detonation, a process in which fuel is ignited in hundreds of thousands of tiny explosions every second, instead of in a continuous burn. 
Mr. Dean, who has worked for G.E. for 10 years, is certain the nascent technology is more efficient, and he and his people are tinkering with it on engines. If they get the kinks out, they expect to derive jet engines that use less fuel at all speeds, and "afterburners" that enable older engines to fly at supersonic speeds. 
But the first pulsed detonation engine is unlikely to show up for at least five years. In pre-Immelt days, Mr. Dean said, he could have wrested just enough money from headquarters and from the government to justify spending a day a week on the project. "I'd have had to juggle five projects at once," he said.
Mr. Immelt is also giving researchers better operations. He is spending $81 million to build technology centers in Munich and Shanghai, and is pumping $100 million into updating the 525-acre Niskayuna complex. Generic laboratories are being torn down, replaced with "wet" labs tailored for biotechnology and chemistry.
The 1960's-era auditorium that sat upward of 300 people is being replaced with a wired room that seats about 165 -- but in which attendees can plug in laptops and interact with one another. A lodge that can sleep 35 people is also going up.
The need for a lodge is itself a sign of changing times. Mr. Welch rarely dropped by the lab; Mr. Immelt holds meetings here twice a year. Those who run G.E.'s business units used to visit Niskayuna only when the mood struck; Mr. Immelt insists they come four times a year. 
Even more startling for the once insular G.E., outsiders are welcome. For example, scientists from GlaxoSmithKline, the pharmaceutical company, often visit, interested in the work on molecular imaging. That research could lead to non-invasive diagnostic tests, which are G.E.'s forte, but also to new drugs, which G.E. does not make but Glaxo does.
"We write secrecy agreements, but it makes sense to have technology-sharing arrangements," said Joseph M. Hogan, chief executive of GE Medical Systems.
Word of G.E.'s new openness is spreading. Rick Snyder, chief executive of Ardesta, a new company specializing in technologies that operate at the size of the human hair and smaller, said he plans to call the G.E. lab soon. "I could see us joint venturing on research now, and development later," he said.
The G.E. businesses are chipping in for research outside their primary areas, too. GE Capital is paying for research into artificial intelligence, which could help it with such tasks as setting prices for service contracts. GE Aircraft Engines is paying for most of the pulsed detonation research, but GE Power Systems is kicking in, too. And nearly every business is supporting nanotechnology -- the study of tiny molecular structures that could lead to such things as ceramics that withstand high heat, magnets that yield sharp X-ray images, and security systems that play color against particle size.
"Shared R.& D. makes total sense," said James N. Kelleher, who follows G.E. for Argus Research. "Companies want to eliminate duplicate efforts in all kinds of back-office operations, so why not in research?"

HEADLINE: Chrysler May Add 3rd Shifts at Most Plants 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Dec. 25 

 BODY:
The Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler may add third shifts at most of its assembly plants to meet its goal of selling four million vehicles a year, its chief executive said in an interview.
 The automaker's North American unit sold 2.9 million Chrysler, Dodge and Jeep vehicles in 2001. It has said it wants to sell four million a year by 2011. 
 Chrysler is actively considering opening a new assembly plant in Windsor, Ontario, but will not meet the sales goal through a series of new plant openings, said Dieter Zetsche, the president and chief executive of Chrysler. 
"In general terms, it is very clear that executing this four million goal is not about adding capacity," Mr. Zetsche told The Detroit Free Press. 
Adding third shifts to most of its existing assembly and components plants will not translate directly into a 33 percent increase in jobs, he said. 
"We intend to improve our productivity to the level of Nissan and Toyota in four or five years," Mr. Zetsche said. He said the higher productivity will let Chrysler build more vehicles per employee, "and at least a portion of the growth we are heading for would compensate for those productivity gains." 
In October, Chrysler announced a third shift at its Warren, Mich., truck assembly plant, creating 1,000 new jobs. 
Chrysler will decide by the end of June whether to build a new Windsor assembly plant and where to build a new engine plant, Mr. Zetsche said. 
Higher exports will account for more than 200,000 units toward the four million goal, he said. Chrysler now sells about 185,000 vehicles annually outside the United States, Canada and Mexico. Mr. Zetsche said he expected to increase that to around 400,000 by adding new models and improving Chrysler's foreign sales networks. 
Chrysler hopes to increase its sales by building new types of vehicles and putting a new emphasis on commercial vehicles, he said.
Chrysler has already chosen two-thirds of the products it needs to reach its four million sales goal, Mr. Zetsche said. He said decisions on the remaining vehicles would come in the next one to two years. 
Most of the sales increase will come from innovative new vehicles like the PT Cruiser and the coming Chrysler Pacifica 6-seat all-wheel-drive crossover, he said. 
"We sure hope he's right," the Canadian Auto Workers Union president, Buzz Hargrove, said of Mr. Zetsche's plan. "We could sure use some good news." 
David L. Littmann, the chief economist at Comerica Bank in Detroit, said the sales goal was well within Chrysler's reach. 
"My bet is they can do it in less than five to 10 years," Mr. Littmann said. "There's no doubt they'll achieve it, maybe in as little as three or four years."

HEADLINE: EYES ON 2004 VOTE, DEMOCRATS FAULT U.S. TERROR DEFENSE 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Democratic contenders for president are beginning to challenge President Bush's record on terrorism, arguing that Mr. Bush has failed to do enough to prevent another fatal attack on American soil and that the nation is barely safer than it was before Sept. 11, 2001.
 The expressions of concern about the nation's safety by Mr. Bush's prospective challengers, voiced in interviews, speeches and television appearances over the last three weeks, suggest that the focus of the Democratic White House candidates in 2004 will go well beyond the traditional Democratic fare of education, the economy, jobs and health care. 
 While so far the criticisms lack many specifics beyond asking for more money for police agencies or the creation of an additional intelligence force, campaign aides said these early challenges on terrorism signaled what they expected to be a central theme in 2004. They argued that Mr. Bush was potentially vulnerable on the issue that Republicans view as a pillar of the president's political strength. 
"It's time for us, without regard to party, to say what every American knows: Washington is not doing enough to make America safe," Senator John Edwards of North Carolina said in a speech on domestic security in Washington last week.
Mr. Edwards added, "If the administration continues to do too little, it will be too late again."
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut said the "American people are only slightly safer today here at home than we were on Sept. 11, 2001."
Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts said in an interview that the administration had squandered a year since the attacks, by failing to make "the preparations necessary to properly deal with an obvious problem of growing terror and the threat at home."
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont said Democrats "have a real opportunity here," noting in particular what he described as the administration's bungling response to the rash of anthrax attacks.
Mr. Lieberman said: "With the possible exception of the aviation systems, we have not raised our guard sufficiently. This administration has been slow and inadequate in the response to the terrorist threat here at home."
White House officials described this line of attack as risky and unorthodox, with some suggesting that it would make the candidates appear willing to exploit American fears for political gain.
"Any candidate who suggests that when the enemy attacks, the blame lies with the United States and not with the enemy does so at great peril to their own political future," said the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer.
Still, it is becoming increasingly clear that the dialogue of the coming presidential race will be unlike any other White House campaign in years, as a direct result of the attacks of Sept. 11.
Several Democrats predicted a fundamental shift in the way presidential candidates would have to present themselves in the 2004 campaign. They said polls showed that the voters would now consider a presidential candidate's ability to protect them from terrorism at home in much the same way voters in a big city might now consider a mayoral candidate's ability to stop crime in their neighborhoods.
"This is clearly going to be one of the cornerstones of the 2004 election -- I don't think there is any question about it," said Steve Jarding, a senior adviser to Mr. Edwards. "Every campaign cycle, you see candidates talk about education, talk about health care. And I guess for better or worse, terrorism is going to be a part of that dialogue from now on."
The contenders have offered a few, though not many, details on what they would do differently. Mr. Edwards, for example, urged creation of a domestic intelligence agency with the specific directive to work against terrorism at home, making up for what he asserted were the now-demonstrated weaknesses of the F.B.I. and C.I.A. 
Mr. Kerry and Mr. Lieberman assailed the administration for holding up $1.5 billion in antiterrorism aid to local police departments and emergency agencies allocated by Congress this year, and Mr. Lieberman said the White House should move aggressively to improve protection of borders, ports and transportation systems, which he described as vulnerable to attack.
None of the Democrats have suggested, for example, further incursions on civil liberties or immigration, in some cases arguing that the administration has gone too far.
In a reflection of these difficult times, aides to the contenders said they were planning their campaigns with the assumption that another terrorist attack could happen at any moment and discreetly trying to assess what that might mean for a continuing contest.
"If something else horrible happens, does the nation instinctively rally around the president?" asked a senior adviser to one contender, who did not want to be identified because of the delicacy of the subject. "Or do they say: 'It's this guy's job keep my family safe. He's had two years to prepare for it.' "
Along those lines, aides suggested that some statements by the White House and the Democratic candidates were intended in part to position the campaigns in the event of a terrorist attack over the next 24 months.
Mr. Kerry, for example, declared three weeks ago on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that there were "enormous gaps and deficits in the preparedness level of our country," while Mr. Bush and his aides have repeatedly warned that another attack is possible.
Former President Bill Clinton pointed the way to this new Democratic line of criticism in a speech in New York a month ago, in which he said the Democrats needed to directly challenge the Bush administration on terrorism. Mr. Clinton is in regular touch with some of the presidential contenders, particularly Mr. Edwards, though aides to Mr. Edwards said he had decided on his own to make this a central part of his campaign.
Republicans said they were startled by the brazenness of the Democratic attacks, and suggested they would have little effect.
"It's a very tricky play because you're going to try to assign blame," said Russ Schriefer, a Republican consultant. "It's almost like you're trying to make political hay out of a disaster."
Even Democrats said they had to be careful not to be perceived as in effect hoping for a terrorist attack, in much the same way that the administration painted the party as rooting for an economic downturn this past fall.
Dr. Dean warned that his party had to be careful about a backlash in confronting this issue, and said that some of his fellow Democrats had already crossed a line, though he declined to name names.
"It depends on how shrill we are," Dr. Dean said. "Some of the candidates have sounded shrill."
Some Democrats said antiterrorism preparations at home had stalled because Mr. Bush had been distracted by the preparations for a war in Iraq, and took note of concerns cited by intelligence agencies that an attack against Iraq would result in terrorism reprisal attacks in the United States.
"The combined intelligence community says that there is a 75 percent or better chance that there will be terrorist attacks against United States interests, including inside the United States, when a war against Iraq is about to achieve success," said Senator Bob Graham, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, who said he was considering a presidential race. 
"When there has been such a lethargic effort made to protect the America people by dismantling those international groups, both here in the homeland and in their headquarters, I think the administration has assumed a very serious potential risk."
While, for the most part, this is a fight between President Bush and the Democrats, there are some differences among the Democratic presidential contenders as well. In offering his criticism of the administration, Mr. Lieberman noted that he had been a sponsor of the act creating the Homeland Security Department in Congress.
But Mr. Edwards belittled the new cabinet department, describing it as "more of a political achievement for the administration than a substantive achievement for America's security."

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Visions for Ground Zero, but Maybe Not New York's

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
HOWEVER inadvertently, the cover of "New York City's Vision for Lower Manhattan" tells the story. It is an aerial photo of downtown showing nothing at the World Trade Center site.
 For the moment, that is necessarily New York City's vision for Lower Manhattan: a question mark where the most influential downtown project will rise. The plain truth is that while the trade center site is subject to mayoral influence, it lies outside municipal control. 
 As a result, several official planning efforts are under way at once. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg brought forth his vision for Lower Manhattan on Dec. 12. Six days later, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey unveiled nine architectural concepts for the trade center site, which the authority controls. The authority is also developing its own land-use plan for the site, thus far unseen by the public. (And this is before the planning for a memorial begins in earnest next year.)
City planners charged with reinvigorating downtown must somehow anticipate a development at the trade center site that may create all the new office space that downtown needs for the next decade. Its stores may compete with the city's proposed Fulton Market Square. Its plazas may draw visitors away from the city's proposed Greenwich Square park. It may offer a place for cultural institutions that the city imagines along the East River. And it may cast long shadows over residential towers that the city contemplates.
Trying to reconcile the trade center site with its surroundings is not a new planning challenge.
In fact, it goes back to the origins of the center in the mid-1960's, when the City Planning Department was simultaneously preparing the first comprehensive plan for downtown. Although the trade center had not yet begun to rise, city planners accepted it as a fait accompli, even as, among themselves, they criticized its scale, barrenness and isolation.
"It was very frustrating," recalled Paul Willen, the project director for the 1966 Lower Manhattan plan, which was recently reprinted by the Princeton Architectural Press and the Skyscraper Museum. "We were basically told by City Planning that it was a done deal, that we would just discredit ourselves if we attacked it. All we could do was tie it the best we could to our plan."
This time, officials say, what emerges from the 16-acre trade center site will bear the city's mark.
"It is impossible for those plans to go forward -- simply impossible -- if the city government is not in favor of them," said Alexander Garvin, a linchpin in the process, since he is both a member of the City Planning Commission and the vice president for planning, design and development at the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.
But with so many agencies and constituents involved, it is possible to imagine visions diverging and to wonder whose will prevail.
Mr. Willen, an architect and urban planner, said the split showed itself clearly to participants in a workshop sponsored by the Regional Plan Association and the Civic Alliance to Rebuild Downtown New York. "There was a big blank, generally, in all the drawings where the World Trade center was," he said.
The five-day workshop ended Dec. 18, the same day that architectural concepts for the trade center site went on view at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center, across West Street from ground zero.
SOME concepts took into account the city's downtown planning framework. Some ignored it. (One was developed by Peterson/Littenberg Architecture and Urban Design, which was also responsible for the design concepts in Mayor Bloomberg's Dec. 12 report.) 
Mr. Garvin declined to identify which plans were congruent with the mayor's vision and which were not, out of concern that to do so might show favoritism while the plans were still being evaluated.
Almost lost in the excited discussion of the trade center site is the fact that the city's "Vision for Lower Manhattan" contains an architectural firecracker of its own: an East River development with a permanent home for Cirque du Soleil, a floating forest and lawn, a beach, a hydroponic garden, a skating rink, an aquarium, a hotel and cultural institutions or maybe residences.
This concept was devised by Diller & Scofidio and David Rockwell of Rockwell Architecture, Planning and Design at the invitation of Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, who had seen the firms' work on a waterfront development for Cirque du Soleil in Hong Kong.
"We wanted to think about what a 21st-century park might be," Mr. Rockwell said. The fanciful megastructure would be built on barges and existing pier structures, showing "how the waterfront of this great island could be used in a way that isn't more landfill," Ricardo Scofidio said.
Though it is highly unlikely that this concept will ever be built, if it engaged public interest through its sheer audacity and imagination, it could serve as a true counterpart to the planning for the trade center site, which now seems so distant across the island.

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF; 
A Time of Trial For Some Shows

BYLINE:  By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:
Ah, Christmastime: expensive presents, delicious eggnog, bloated box office receipts. You wish the season would never end.
 But next week, as New Year's Day slips by and tourists slip away, more than a few shows are going to be tested. Surviving the fallow box office months of January and February is always a challenge, but this year has its own hurdles: a bundle of late 2002 openings, a still fragile economy and a public that is increasingly savvy about buying last-minute and discount tickets. 
 Jed Bernstein, the president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, said that while Broadway had had a "disproportionally great fall," with breakout hits like "Hairspray" and "Movin' Out," there was some wariness as to how long the good ride would last.
"You have the lingering economic softness, which hasn't really affected Broadway that much, but you have to wonder whether our number is coming up," he said.
One challenge is a packed field of new shows angling for audiences, with six Broadway openings in 15 days in December, meaning that some shows probably got less press and ticket-buying attention than expected. Hogging a lot of the limelight was "La Boheme," which sold strong right after opening on Dec. 8, though not as strong as its producers had predicted.
All those late openings may make it difficult for shows to differentiate themselves, Mr. Bernstein said.
"Because so many shows opened in December," he said, "that critical four- to six-week period after opening for marketing and branding your show is going to include January, when it's difficult enough to get people in the seats."
Among the newcomers needing help are shows like "Dance of the Vampires" and "Hollywood Arms," which are banking on television advertising campaigns. "Imaginary Friends" and "Medea" also need to fill more seats. "Def Poetry Jam" has been struggling but carries a low weekly running cost. It, too, is planning an advertising campaign, having hired a new ad agency, Spot Co., last week.
Several longer-running shows look vulnerable, including the little show that could, "Metamorphoses," and "The Graduate," where sales haven't been the same since Kathleen Turner left the cast.
Then there's one imponderable element that Mr. Bernstein especially fears: war. 
"International travel used to account for 12 percent of our sales," Mr. Bernstein said, citing figures from before Sept. 11, 2001. "Now it's 4 percent." That number would probably drop again if hostilities erupted overseas.
But what of all this doom and gloom? Isn't this the time of happiness and cheer and good will toward men? 
Well, yes. There is plenty to celebrate, the league says. The estimated gross for the calender year 2002 is more than $700 million. Through its 29th week, which ended on Dec. 15, the 2002-3 season is on pace to top the total season gross of the record-setting 2000-01 season. 
Attendance is down slightly compared with that season, but tickets are more expensive now.

The Scarlet A
It looks as if the play with the unprintable title -- a new drama by Suzan-Lori Parks based on "The Scarlet Letter" -- has found its Hester, and it isn't Queen Latifah. Officials at the Public Theater, where the play begins in February, said this week that they were close to signing S. Epatha Merkerson, an accomplished stage actress who has found national fame as Lt. Anita Van Buren on the hit television show "Law & Order."
Ms. Merkerson, nominated for a Tony Award in 1990 for her work in August Wilson's "Piano Lesson," would join a cast that already includes Mos Def, Daphne Rubin-Vega and Bobby Canavale. Queen Latifah had been widely rumored to be considering a role in the play.
The play, whose title includes the letter A, is described as the story of Hester, who lives in a violent island dystopia where she is an abortionist. (It is not a comedy.) Michael Greif will direct.

A Temporary Closing
Sunday brings the final performance, for now, of "Harlem Song," the ambitious and acclaimed show about the birth of Harlem that has been playing at the Apollo Theater since August. Created by George C. Wolfe ("Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk") and hailed by many Broadway critics, the show nonetheless had trouble drawing audiences uptown. It very nearly closed in early November before being bailed out by ticketbuyers and an infusion of cash from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone.
And while the show will close this weekend, plans are still afoot to try to stage "Harlem Song" year after year, not unlike the Radio City Christmas Spectacular. 
John Schreiber, one of the Harlem show's producers, said that the plan is to return every October for three months.
"I think the first season was almost like a learning season for the audience," he said. "They (a) didn't know what it was and (b) didn't know where it was."
Producers didn't come close to recouping the production's $4 million price tag. But Mr. Schreiber said the producers were encouraged by strong word of mouth and the number of theater parties attending. 
"We found that especially among African-American audiences, 'Harlem Song' became a real family thing to do," he said. "So we believe it should become a perennial."

Along the Way
*"Zanna, Don't!," a new musical that received favorable reviews during a run on Theater Row in October, will transfer to the Houseman Theater on March 4. Described as a musical fairy tale about a beautiful, androgynous teenager, "Zanna!" has a book, music and lyrics by Tim Acito, with additional book and lyrics by Alexander Dinelaris.
*After a bushel of good reviews, "Hank Williams: Lost Highway" has been extended until Feb. 2. The show, which chronicles the rise and fall of the world's most famous cowboy warbler, is at the Manhattan Ensemble Theater, 55 Mercer Street, SoHo.

HEADLINE: FAMILY FARE 

BYLINE:  By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:
Calling All To Kwanzaa
Whether or not you subscribe to the proverb that "it takes a village to raise a child," children will have an entire village at their disposal tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History. And this one offers entertainment as well as life lessons. 
 It's the children's village at a festival for Kwanzaa, the African-American holiday (Dec. 26 to Jan. 1) that honors seven principles: unity, self-determination, collective work and responsibility, cooperative economics, purpose, creativity and faith. 
 "Drummers will travel throughout the museum toward the Kwanzaa area, calling people to the event," said Teddy Yoshikami, the museum's manager of public programs. "Then there'll be a procession." 
After an opening candlelighting ceremony, the museum will present a variety of performers, including the singer Tulani Kinard, the Total Praise Choir of Emmanuel Baptist Church in Brooklyn, the Young Jazz Masters and the Restoration Dance Theater Junior Company.
From 2 to 4 p.m. the children's village will offer African games, face painting, the performer Ha! Ha! B. Klown,as well as a stilt walker and storytelling. "They're going to read 'Jalani and the Lock,' by Lorenzo Pace," Ms. Yoshikami said. "It all fits into the seven principles of Kwanzaa."
Including African-American foods and an African marketplace, the event promises a multicultural fest of comfort and joy. "Hopefully, by the end," Ms. Yoshikami said, "everyone will be dancing, singing, holding hands and hugging each other."
Kwanzaa Festival, noon to 6 p.m., and Children's Kwanzaa Village, 2 to 4 p.m., at the American Museum of Natural History, 79th Street and Central Park West, second floor, (212) 496-3409. Free with suggested admission: $12; students and 65+, $9; children, $7.

Twinkle, Little Moon
One of the most popular films at the holidays is "It's a Wonderful Life," in which a well-meaning but inept angel earns his wings by rescuing a man from despair. Its emphasis on the joy of doing good can also be found in "The Little Moon Theater," a musical from Tada!, the theater for thespians ages 8 to 18. But here the bumbling supernatural being is Penelope, a fairy godmother who can barely fly, much less make dreams come true.
Based on the children's book of the same title by Irene Haas, "The Little Moon Theater" chronicles Penelope's quest to earn retirement by granting one last wish. But she has unintentional competition from the itinerant Little Moon Theater. Before she can fulfill a wish, its players do, by performing a piece that heals a heart or solves a problem.
With a book by Michael Slade and music and lyrics by Joel Gelpe, the show is like a gift box that, when opened, reveals still another gift inside. In addition to the main story, children are treated to the plays-within-a-play of the Little Moon Theater. When the Little Moon members, for instance, meet a boy who's ostracized because no one likes his pet snake, they put on an amusing jungle skit. This encounter also leads to one of the musical's most hilarious numbers: "A Snake Is Just a Cat Without Legs," which notes all the similarities -- shedding, slinking, a fondness for rodents -- between these seemingly disparate species.
As for Penelope, she learns that the solution to her troubles is right under her nose. Directed by Janine Nina Trevens and performed by a gifted young cast, "The Little Moon Theater" would fulfill anyone's wish for a charming show.
"The Little Moon Theater," through Jan. 20 at the CAP 21 Theater, 15 West 28th Street, second floor, Chelsea, (212) 252-1619. Fridays at 7 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays at 2 and 4 p.m., with additional shows today, Monday, Tuesday and Jan. 20 at noon and 2 p.m. Tickets: $15; 15 and under, $7. Reservations advised. 

A Natural Laboratory
Imagine you were stranded on an island and had to mix your own insect repellent. Or create a makeshift microscope to assess the water.
These made-for-television premises don't come from "Survivor" but from "Rough Science," a PBS show in which five scientists are put on an island and given three days to meet certain challenges. This weekend, the New York Hall of Science is inviting families to get in on the act by using their own ingenuity (and a little help from museum staff) to perform various tasks. To get in the mood, they can watch episodes of "Rough Science," to be screened at 2, 3 and 3:30 p.m. tomorrow and Sunday. 
"They'll get basic materials like plain water to use as a lens for a microscope," said Marcia Rudy, the museum's director of public programs. "For a wind vane, we'll provide a source of wind, and all they'll use is a drinking straw and a card." Another challenge may involve making a battery by starting with a potato or a copper penny. 
Other weekend activities will include dissecting owl pellets (regurgitated dietary leftovers) and vicarious journeys to a rain forest, in which children will make reptile puppets (materials fee, $1 to $2) and chocolate ($3), which derives from the cocoa bean. It's one way to experience the tropics when the only heat is coming from your radiators.
"Rough Science" challenges, 2:45 to 4:30 p.m., and Rain Forest Science Weekend, noon to 4:30 p.m. (chocolate making at 1:30 and 2:30), tomorrow and Sunday at the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens, (718) 699-0005. Admission: $7.50; 62+ and students over 5, $5; ages 2 through 4, $2.50.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
In Some Circles, A Man Is Judged By the Cut of His Wheel

BYLINE:  By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
"THERE'S no way in the world you could ride around on rims you don't like," said Daymond John, the chief executive of Fubu, the urban clothing company.
 Of course not. Wheels are critical, especially on a car like his Mercedes-Benz S55 AMG, a high-performance version of the flagship Mercedes sedan with a 493-horsepower engine and a $107,000 price tag. It was inching across town in on the way from Mr. John's office in the Empire State Building to a television studio on West 57th Street, with a stop on Eighth Avenue across from Madison Square Garden -- not the kind of trip for showing what wheels can do. 
 Still, Mr. John was explaining his choice for the Mercedes -- chrome-plated wheels with thick spokes that reach out to shiny rims and rivetlike bolts circling the edge. They measure 18 inches in diameter, 3 inches larger than the ones that came with the car. "This is a $10,000, a $20,000 investment here," he said. 
And that's worth some serious consideration, even for someone with as many cars as Mr. John: a 1967 Buick Skylark convertible with 20-inch rims, a 1967 Cadillac and a $300,000 Bentley Arnage. He has another on the way: he ordered a Maybach, the low-slung monster that DaimlerChrysler hopes will appeal to drivers who want something more exclusive than the Mercedes S-Class sedan, the car he uses around Manhattan.
Choosing the right rims is like choosing the right tie or the right cuff links. "Everybody has a particular taste," Mr. John said. "My taste -- I like a real deep lip on the rim."
But not too deep. Not too wide, either -- he does not want his rims to look like mirrors.
Wheels, the things car tires are mounted on, aren't just about locomotion, anymore. When the speedometer is climbing and the wheels are spinning faster and faster, they can be a kind of kinetic artwork, with limitless variations depending on the wheels' design. Just the right wheels, in motion or at rest, are personal signatures for many automobile lovers.
A car's wheels can project the conspicuous excesses of hip-hop or the muscle-car image of a driver who is living out a childhood fantasy. Some spin like pinwheels, even after the car has stopped. Some need to be babied with powder in sensitive places.
"You've got to stand out in life, you know?" said John Kramer, a contractor from Jamesport, N.Y., who put $3,000 into extra-large cast aluminum wheels for his 1995 Chevrolet Silverado pickup truck a couple months ago.
He bought the wheels just after a paint job gave the truck fender-to-fender flames. Cruising through a Long Island outlet-mall parking lot the other day, he was photographed twice -- first by a woman with a 35-millimeter camera, then by a couple in their 30's with a video camera. "Their kids were giving me thumbs-up," he said, "and the father said, 'You got a sweet truck.' "
He added, "You see a car with decent set of wheels, you know it's not cheap.The bigger the wheel, the more money you got."
The wheels are bigger than ever -- literally. Mr. John's 18-inch wheels would look small next to a set of 20's, as in 20 inches in diameter, a size that was the largest on the market a couple of years ago.
Now there are 23-inch wheels, which are often called Jordans after the number that the basketball star Michael Jordan wears, and 24-inch wheels for sport-utility vehicles. Can 25- or 26-inch wheels be on the way? 
There are those who call wheels makeup for men -- very expensive makeup, at more than $10,000 for a set like the one on Mr. John's Mercedes.
"People want to customize their cars," the New York Knicks star Latrell Sprewell, who drives a 2003 Range Rover with 22-inch rims to Madison Square Garden, said in an interview. "You don't want to be the same as everybody else. You like to be a little different. Wheels and tires are the first and most visible thing someone can change to personalize a vehicle."
And for many car buyers, nothing right off the dealer's lot will do, no matter how expensive the car. Howard Zwang pointed to an investment banker's Mercedes-Benz SL500 that had just been brought in to his wheel shop on Long Island one morning a couple of weeks ago.
"A $125,000 car, and it's not enough," Mr. Zwang said. "He's got to drop $10,000 more" on 18-inch cast-aluminum wheels with midwidth spokes.
The investment banker could have ordered the $18,000 rims known as Sprewells, after Mr. Sprewell, who owns Sprewell Racing, based in San Gabriel, Calif.
Mr. Sprewell said he was not the inventor of Sprewells, which spin like pinwheels even when the car is stopped at a traffic light -- which can confuse drivers nearby. "A lot of people think it's me," he said.
The wheel business exploded in the 1990's. The Specialty Manufacturers Market Association, a trade group, says that sales of custom rims have climbed to $3 billion a year from $1.2 billion in 1991. Wheel sellers like Mr. Zwang say that business has not soured as the economy has sputtered.
"The demographics of wheels in the 70's and 80's was muscle-car enthusiasts," he explained. Now, he said, the carefully selected wheel is "a pure fashion statement."
Since the 1980's, Mr. Zwang has been selling wheels from Best Tire and Car Audio, an unfashionable-looking garage in Great Neck, the inspiration for the little-disquised setting of the of "The Great Gatsby." He joined a business his father started in 1963. By the 1990's, he was selling wheels as big as the ones on the roadsters that Tom Buchanan drove.
"Nineteen-inch wheels, you'd see the girlfriends shaking their heads," Mr. Zwang said. "I'd go, 'How many pairs of shoes do you have have?' "
Rap music gave the wheel business another boost. Snoop Dogg rapped about Dayton rims when the coveted car was a Detroit dreamboat from the 1960's, a Cadillac or a Chevy Impala (a hooptie, the rap term for an old American car). Twenty-inch Dayton rims -- which look like the wheels on a classic MG roadster, with 100 to 200 thin spokes -- were also what the rap artist Jay-Z was referring to in "Girls, Girls, Girls":
I come scoop you in that coupe
sittin' on deuce-zeroes
Fix your hair in the mirror, let's roll
Soon, fashion consciousness about wheels had spread from urban buyers to the suburban market, where the buyers were closer to middle age.
"Anything the urban market does, the suburban market does two years later," Mr. Zwang said.
THE width of a wheel is also important. Martin Tallon, 32, of Speonk, N.Y., chose wheels that are 15 inches wide -- as he drives they appear almost as wide as they are tall -- for his 1957 Chevrolet, another Detroit classic often seen on the stock-car circuit. He pampers them by dusting them with baby powder to reduce friction with the tires.
"I like the way the car looks when you look at it from the back and see one-third tire, one-third space between and one-third tire," he said.
He added, "I'm getting super-skinny tires for the front. Skinny little wheels in the front and fat wheels in the back. The traction is supposed to be worse, and the steering worse. It's the look."
Another issue is the profile, or thickness, of the tire -- the space between the wheel and the road. As rims become larger, tires must become thinner to keep the entire package from being too big to fit the car. 
Jim Stavrinos, who owns SpeedworldFX in Riverhead, N.Y., has admired the effect of supersize wheels on supersize S.U.V.'s like Shaquille O'Neal's Lincoln Navigator, which he has seen at car shows.But "the ride is terrible," Mr. Stavrinos said. "When you go to a low-profile tire with a big wheel, there's very little rubber," he said. "But the bigger the wheel they can get on them, the happier people are."
Mr. Stavrinos put 22-inch wheels on his pickup truck, but thought better of it and replaced them with 18-inch ones. "I couldn't take the ride," he said. "You ought to see these guys bouncing up and down. A lot of people are going to have bad backs."
Mr. John, 31, has also begun downsizing. If he did not live in a high-risk environment for wheels -- snow and slush are bad enough, he said, but salt attacks the chrome finish -- he'd stay with the big ones. But in New York, it's too much trouble.
And, he added, "I'm starting to get older now."

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Helping A Camaro Migrate For Winter

BYLINE:  By RICH BEATTIE 

 BODY:
AH, the power. Cruising down I-95 in an almost-new Camaro convertible, I found the task of aligning speedometer with speed limit the quintessential challenge. Other drivers looked on enviously as I whizzed by. With the top down, the wind drowned out my CD, even when it was blasting. I accelerated past other drivers simply because I could. 
 Even the chilly air couldn't persuade me to put the top up, and as I continued south from my starting point in New Jersey, temperatures rose with the corresponding drop in latitude. The landscape changed from industrial to rural to very rural, and after several days of visiting friends along the way and thrilling to the car's hum, I zipped across the Florida border, pleased and surprised to have collected no speeding tickets along the way. 
 Unfortunately, this powerful engine and gorgeous body did not belong to me. National Car Rental held the title, and I was just burning the rubber. Normally, borrowing this kind of speed costs $65 a day for a winter drive out of Newark Airport. But I got it for $25.99 a day with unlimited mileage. How? I was doing National a favor -- at its invitation.
It's not only the geese and the snowbirds that migrate for the winter. Rental cars have to go south, too.
In the below-freezing rental garages of the Northeast and Midwest, extra cars that helped meet last summer's demand in resort towns and big-city tourist spots have become a glut. As the tourists head to warmer spots, much of the market for rental cars goes with them.
The big national companies can always load cars six or eight at a time onto auto transport trucks. Or they can buy new cars and have the manufacturer deliver them to a car-hungry locale. But 15 years ago, they recognized an opportunity for symbiosis. For a low rate -- typically as little as $20 or $25 a day with unlimited mileage -- drivers in the know are more than happy to take cars south and get themselves there at the same time.
"The company gets its cars moved and drivers get an amazing bargain," said Travis Tanner, executive vice president of ANC, which owns both National and Alamo. 
Not all rental-car companies offer these deals, and those that do may not do it every year. Right now, only National and Alamo have the specials, and only until Jan. 31. And there is, of course, a catch. Companies call it the Florida Drive-In program (farther west it is the Arizona Drive-In) because you have to leave your wheels among the palm trees and make your way home on your own. You could return in the spring, when National, Alamo and Avis usually run the program in reverse (the Florida Drive-Out) to get their cars north. But don't count on it. Companies announce these specials only when they have to. Hertz and Dollar, for example, have run the program in past years, but this year found their fleets positioned well enough without it.
For some travelers, though, a one-way drive can be a perfect fit. You may want to see the country or visit friends as you drive south, but dread taking the same long drive in reverse a couple of weeks later. Discount airlines' one-way fares between Florida and northern cities make it economical and easy to get home by air.
Most of the cars moved in the Drive-In won't be exciting models; I was lucky to get the Camaro. But it is worth checking to see whether the car you want can be had. A family, for example, might take the opportunity to get a roomy minivan, currently $19.99 a day with unlimited mileage in National's program.
ANC, according to Ernest Johnson, its vice president for revenue management, aims to relocate a few thousand cars each fall and normally gets most of them there with the Drive-In. Dollar Rent a Car, which also looks to move about 4,000 cars to Florida for the winter, usually gets 700 to 1,000 driven down through the special. But sometimes companies are happy to redistribute even a handful of cars this way.
If it's a win-win for companies and customers, why is this a special hardly anyone has heard of? "Because the rentals are so cheap," said Gary Paxton, chief executive of Dollar, "the return on any advertising investment just isn't there." Getting the word out usually means putting a listing on the Web site and perhaps running an ad in limited publications.
The absence of penalties plus some amazing rates are what make these deals special. So now, when the spring and fall come around, think about putting the top down and hitting the road for next to nothing. It's quite a rush.

HEADLINE: Precious and Workaday, Malleable and Strong 

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
AT FIRST, the idea of following a single material through the weird, disjointed world of the Brooklyn Museum of Art for the third installment of this series didn't seem especially promising. The museum dwells in what might be called a state of glacial flux, plagued by financial problems, unending rehabilitations and space constraints that keep huge chunks of its collection in storage for years on end.
 Right now, the museum's complex floor plan is riddled by even more detours and closed galleries than usual: the reconstruction of its grand staircase on Eastern Parkway is under way (to be completed in 2004), and half of its Egyptian galleries are in the final throes of reinstallation (reopening in April). The staircase project also involves burrowing under the museum to install the apparatus that will finally enable Brooklyn to climatize its older galleries, when it has the money. 
 So I set out a bit nervously, which may be why, like a newly hatched duckling, I imprinted on the first thing I saw at the entrance to the museum's African galleries near the lobby. It was a gorgeous 19th-century fibula, or cape clasp, from Morocco made of intricately worked silver and enamel and set with carnelian: it looked as if it could hold down a tent. Metal, I thought excitedly. Why not metal? Eureka. 
Well, duh. Given that the first of these articles followed ceramics through the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the second explored textiles at the American Museum of Natural History, metallurgy was obviously next. It is one of the crucial transformations of earth-given materials that made human progress possible. Civilization's Big Bang Basics, as they could be called, developed at different times, in different orders, all over the world, with different results. The pre-Columbian peoples of South America, for example, never abandoned stone tools, reserving metalwork primarily for luxury and ceremonial items. 
Since ceramics and metallurgy involved fire and an alchemical transformation that must have struck early humans as miraculous, they figured importantly in creation narratives, with metalsmiths in particular often doubling as shamans and priests. The meshing of religion, economic might, social and political status and daily usefulness is especially potent in metals because of their inherent beauty and durability. In its rawest state metal has always had high market value and quickly became the most common form of currency. The durability that made it so eternally useful helped many metal objects survive where ceramics shattered and fabrics rotted. But value also eradicates objects and therefore history: metal things were, and still are, continuously melted down to make other metal things. 
Following metals and metalwork through the Brooklyn Museum teaches one a lot, but hardly everything about the history of the family of malleable, ductile materials, whose best-known members include iron, silver, gold and copper and whose most widely used alloys, especially in early times, are bronze (copper and tin) and brass (copper and zinc).
The Brooklyn metal route largely sidesteps Western painting and sculpture and passes through nearly every open gallery in the museum. Although the points of interest include no overwhelming caches of objects to peruse, masterpieces show up regularly. But part of the allure of the Brooklyn Museum at the moment is its combination of quality and spartanness. You may sometimes feel that you are really prospecting, or on a treasure hunt. 
Metals can play starring, supporting, purely decorative or exceedingly minor roles. Yet because of metals' supreme shape-shifting capacities, a few, diverse objects can tell a material tale that encompasses an array of colors, of shapes and textures (not to mention physical strength and weight), of purposes and meanings and of skills and aesthetic priorities.
With some huge gaps, the path here crosses nearly three dozen centuries and even more cultures, from Chinese bronzes to spun aluminum, from New Kingdom Egypt to Jazz Age New York (after all, no steel, no skyscrapers). And of course the unfolding narrative concerns the sleeping giant that is the Brooklyn Museum and its considerable wonders, both present and potential.

Africa and the Americas
I opted to begin my zigzagging metal hunt near the middle of Brooklyn's recently renovated African galleries beyond the Berber fibula, and not simply because of their proximity to the lobby. 
The objects date from the 16th century to the 20th, and while wood predominates, the metals on hand here are among the most varied anywhere in the museum. They range from the superfine elegance of a cast gold pendant of a coiled snake eating a toad to a sturdy wood Kakongo power figure whose chest bristles with rusty nails and knife blades. It makes sense that the only uses of found metal objects at Brooklyn are in works from Africa, where modern sculpture began. (Looking closely reveals that many of the carved wood figures on view are adorned with iron pendants or wire earrings that combine found and made elements.) 
There is a serene Kota figure from Gabon whose flat elliptical face is quilted with thin strips of brass and copper. The adaptation of foreign goods is visible in a thronelike akonkromfi (praying mantis) chair from Ghana densely decorated with brass upholstery tacks, and the highest level of indigenous sophistication and originality shines through in a cluster of the museum's great Benin bronzes (actually made of copper alloy). One Benin case holds the magisterial "Horn Blower," with his monumental feet, finely detailed garments and implacable stare; another displays a waist pendant showing three elegant women, with a reverse side, visible in a photograph, that bears a rare maker's mark. 
Other standouts include a blunt copper mask made by the Yoruban artist Ali Amonikoji in 1910, which shows the influence of woodcarving and a vitrine holding more than two dozen Ethiopian crosses, large and small, mostly of silver, iron and copper alloy and whose designs represent a confluence of Indian and Christian cultures.
Leaving the African galleries, you'll find yourself in the vast space given over to the art of Oceania and the Americas. It was once packed with big display cases, but its thicket of art has been trimmed back pending a thorough rethinking and eventual rehab. At the moment, the fancifully carved figures, masks and shields of Melanesia, which use no metal, make up a great majority. But a vitrine on the far wall contains a handful of highlights from the museum's Americas collection, including a Panamanian Cocle sun disc, its ferocious god depicted in hammered gold so thin and delicate it resembles folded paper. As you leave toward the right, don't miss the rare Northwest Coast Indian shieldlike plaque called a copper, which was used in Potlatch rites; its kindly bear face is painted in black on the glowing copper.

Asia and the Middle East
Through the door and toward the right, you've arrived back at the touchstone Berber fibula. Behind it is a narrow enclosed staircase that always looks slightly off limits but isn't. One flight up is, for me, the museum's sweet spot: the wonderfully hospitable galleries of Asian and Middle Eastern art, where history moves rapidly through time and space and the objects seem especially available to the eye.
First, ample evidence of one of the world's greatest ages of bronze, which was also the dawn of Chinese dynastic civilization, is provided by some of the oldest and most beautiful pieces of metalwork in the Brooklyn collection. There are more than a dozen Shang and Zhou dynasty ceremonial bronzes from the 15th through the 12th century B.C. Most were used for making symbolic offerings to ancestors. In shades of green ranging from pale celadon to rich turquoise, they start with a perky three-legged Shang dynasty jia (wine vessel), whose smooth surface imitates ceramics. The increasingly ornate surfaces of succeeding bronzes -- a three-legged caldronlike ding (food vessel), for example -- indicate a rapidly developing grasp of the possibilities of casting bronze in clay molds that were incised with intricate spirals and zoomorphic faces. (This ubiquitous animalistic face is not so far removed from the Haida bear downstairs.) The zoomorphic presence might be said to culminate in the jutting head and clenched teeth of the animal-shaped Zhou guang (wine vessel), one of the museum's finest bronzes. 
Fast-forward about 3,000 years, and the next imposing piece of metalwork is a Qing shrine, where the patterning, more naturalistic now, is rendered in blue, red and green enamel on copper with dragon-wrapped piers. The object of devotion is not ancestors but a gilt bejeweled bodhisattva. 
The Japanese gallery provides a mere glimpse of Brooklyn's riches in this area, and metal, while infrequent, takes a variety of forms. An austere second-to-third-century Yayoi bronze bell, nearly three feet tall, shows the influence of Chinese bronzes. Screens and lacquered writing boxes shimmer with sprinkled gold. The museum's great 13th-century Kamakura guardian mask, its every feature aflare, is carved in wood with glaring rock crystal eyes. It seems completed by a bronze crown whose delicate cartwheeling filigree diadem has a a flair all its own and is in fact an Edo period addition.
Around the bend, you're in the Indian and Southeast Asian galleries, where stone alternates with bronze and Buddhas alternate with Hindu gods and saints. The idealized human form reigns throughout -- seated in meditation, standing, dancing, making love. First, a chock-a-block vitrine contains small, intricate bronzes from the Himalayan cultures, including an extravagant Nepalese Shiva-Shakti bristling with so much in the way of headdresses, arms and attributes that it almost seems to be on fire. In the next gallery, a fabulous dancing Krishna represents the 10th-century Chola dynasty of southern India, a high point in the world history of bronze casting and figural sculpture. 
Step into the elevator foyer to see one of the museum's greatest and largest pieces of Asian bronze: the head and torso of a Buddha from 14th-century Thailand. With a head of curls like snail shells, a lustrous deep brown patina, handsome features and large downcast eyes, it is an image of life-affirming beneficence.
But after that, head back to the secret stairway through the Middle Eastern gallery, where ceramics reign. Toward the end, the greatness of metalwork in medieval Iran is signaled with two brass vessels whose punch work achieves an almost lacy fineness, and also with a relatively plebeian three-legged incense burner in the shape of bird that suggests a helicopter. Around the corner, there's a Han dynasty bronze wine vessel in the shape of a goose whose naturalism contrasts strikingly with the earlier Chinese bronzes.

Egyptian Art
Proceed down the stairs and across the lobby and take the elevator to the third floor of the Morris A. and Meyer Schapiro Wing, where quite a bit of the Brooklyn's important Egyptian collection, beginning with the middle of the New Kingdom, is arrayed in newly designed blond-on-blond splendor. Here, where carved stone figures and reliefs predominate, the viewing experience assumes a definite treasure-hunt aspect.
Tucked away in numerous vitrines are all kinds of small bronze figures, numerous pieces of jewelry and decorative objects, and a few relief fragments that attest to the Egyptians' mastery of hollow-casting, gilding and inlay. The gold pieces include an exceedingly small, rare gold scarab depicting a queen with microscopic crispness, and a hefty necklace strand spacer inscribed with hieroglyphs. A small black bronze inlaid with gold of King Osorkon I with an offering bowl in his upraised hand reflects how bronze-casting freed Egyptian sculptors from stone and allowed for more naturalistic gestures.
Small bronze figures become more plentiful as you move into the Third Intermediate, Late and Ptolemaic periods, when the figures were often mass produced for private shrines or to be left on tombs. None of Brooklyn's Egyptian bronzes have the masterpiece status of its stone figures, but they are immensely appealing in their liveliness and oddness.
Among the displays, keep an eye out for three bronzes in particular: a sinuous sculpture of a sharp-eyed cat, a Late Period king in front of a groundhog-like ichneumon, and an unusual casket for a mummified snake, with a human-headed serpent stretched the length of its narrow, elongated form. Giacometti would have been inspired.
One of the museum's best-known Egyptian objects is a large coffin for the royal ibis bird that combines gaudiness and streamlined restraint. Its smooth wood body is brightly gilded in gold, but its sleek neck and head and almost creepily accurate feet are solid silver, and its eternally alert eye is rock crystal edged with gold. The legs are bent, as if this creature were rising from or settling into a nest; its side-by-side feet rest before it like the hands of someone awaiting a juicy bit of gossip, or a game of cards.

Decorative Art
Partly because the third-floor corridor to the north elevator bank is closed and partly for curatorial chronology, return to the ground floor by the nearby elevator, walk to the farther, north elevators and take one to the fourth floor to reach the museum's rambling, somewhat neglected decorative arts galleries. The labels for the large stained glass windows (two by Tiffany) just off the elevator make no mention of the wrought iron that holds them together, but never mind. Silver at least will eventually get its detailed due here.
The rather abrupt transition from Egypt is softened by immediate encounters with articles whose Egyptian motifs reflect the revivalist styles of the 19th century. In the Moorish Room, assembled in 1878 by Belle D. Yarrington Worsham, the persistence of Iranian metalwork is opulently visible in sconces and vases. Metal lurks and gleams in the shadowy vitrine-lined hallway ahead: a cast-iron ornament from Louis Sullivan's Carson Pirie Scott Building in Chicago, painted to resemble weathered bronze; the 19th-century American innovation of cast-iron garden furniture; the 20th-century German innovation (Marcel Breuer's, actually) of steel tubular furniture.
But the real deal here is the long gallery at the end, on the right, where American silver, pewter, gold-plated Jewish ritual silver and red-and-gold tolework (cast tin painted to imitate Asian lacquer, with rococo flourishes) hold forth. Too often, visitors use this gallery primarily as the entryway to the museum's popular 19th-century American period rooms, but it is packed with remarkable sights and information. 
Vitrine by vitrine, the displays cover the arrival of electroplating that put silverish flatware on so many American dinner tables, and they observe the cross-fertilization between silver and ceramics. They parse the contrasting styles of Boston and New York tankards, heavy lidded status symbols used for communal ale consumption. They offer an array of the small, fretwork-handled bowls called porringers. (God is in the handles, and the delicate softened lines of the one by the maker known only as S. H.) A pock-surfaced bowl by Gerrit Onckelbag from 1720 has the rustic dignity of a Japanese tea bowl, while an impeccably plain example by Myer Myers is as taut as crystal.
There is a heady sense of competition with European silver design in vitrines that trace the medium's rapidly changing styles up to the early 20th century -- ticking off neo-Classicism, late neo-Classicism, Rococo Revival and Renaissance Revival and culminating in a stretch devoted to Japonisme and Gilded Age eclecticism. The showstoppers include the Tiffany & Company chocolate pot in brown enamel on silver, decorated with lobsters; a Meriden (Conn.) Britannica silver-plate coffeepot, on which the flora and fauna are as thick and accurate as the undergrowth in a fairy painting by Richard Dadd; and a Derby Silver Company flask with a view of the Wild West framed in not-so-bas-relief cacti.
Even the vitrine marked "Installation in Progress" engages, with a tea service whose delicate forms are pinched and dented like George Ohr pots. A quick tour of the period rooms shows silver, pewter and related metalwork in their native habitats, most charmingly in the kitchen of the Cupola House. Emerging on the other side, head for the center stairwell, past a handsomely proportioned 1638 Danish tankard and an unlabeled side chair whose decorative use of upholstery tacks may bring to mind the African chair downstairs.
Take the stairs to the fifth floor, and nip left through the museum's largest recent acquisition -- Judy Chicago's "Dinner Party," where much sparkle is provided by the names embroidered in thick gold thread. Upon emerging, left again.

'American Identities'
Now that the race is almost run, a little mop-up. The galleries of the "American Identities" installation are a lavish display, ranging through 200 years of American object-making with a contextualizing combination of painting, sculpture, folk art and all manner of decorative objects. Metal appears in many guises, but the numbers are down, especially if, like me, you're not too crazy about gilt bronze ornamentation.
The first gallery is devoted to landscape paintings, but 19th-century cast-iron chairs from the museum collection provide seating. In the next, there is an interesting metal moment in the face-off between the Herter Brothers' lavish Sloan House mantel, sconced, candelabra'ed and fire-screened to the hilt in brass and, directly opposite, a tiny slightly rough-edged silver and cloisonne box by Elizabeth Copeland; and there's another one in the third gallery, between Saint-Gaudens's bust of Lincoln and Melvin Edwards's terse implosion of abstract steel in a wall sculpture from 1989.
In the remaining "American Identities" galleries the history of metal proceeds by leaps and bounds with a series of isolated standouts. One is the Peruvian Pizarro commemorative plaque from the 19th century, with its blunt representations of Spanish conquistador and the Inca king. Other are Elie Nadelman's graphite-toned cast-bronze "Dancing Girl," her smooth curving limbs echoing the Chola Krishna in the Southeast Asian Galleries, and George Hunzinger's prophetic armchair, which used steel webbing in the seat and back for the first time. 
In the final gallery, Russel Wright's spun-aluminum beaker and John Vasso's RCA-Victor portable phonograph, its aluminum case as svelte as the Airstream trailer, hint at the new uses of metal in modern design, while David Smith's welded stool sculpture "Hero" speaks for its presence in modern art.
Trying to imagine what the sleeping giant that is the Brooklyn Museum of Art would be like if it were upright and fully alert may be one of those great New York pastimes, like wondering what it would be like if the Second Avenue subway were finished or if the Dodgers had never moved to Los Angeles. It would be great if someone (Bill Gates perhaps?) would plunk $500 million in the museum's lap so that its collections could have the galleries, endowment and (well remunerated) staff they deserve. But I wouldn't want it to get bigger and better by eradicating all of its quirks and foibles. It doesn't hurt to go into label free-fall once in a while, or to see the gleam of an object veiled with a little dust.
These qualities keep a museum as big as Brooklyn's personal and outline the very real challenges of its existence. In addition, the greatness of a city is measured partly in the vitality of its underdogs, and they include benignly neglected treasures, the haunted, imperfect places where you can see things both working and falling apart at the same time and glimpse the eternal dance of ambition and failure that fuels human enterprise.

Joining the Trail
The Brooklyn Museum of Art is at 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000. It is open Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Closed New Year's Day. Admission: $6; students and 62+, $3.

HEADLINE: A Malaysian Tycoon Loses His Flagship Concern 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Dec. 26 

 BODY:
First he lost control of Malaysia's national airline, then one of its biggest cellular operators. Now Tajudin Ramli, the tycoon whose corporate empire has been besieged by the very government that helped him build it, appears to have lost control of his flagship holding company, too.
 Malaysia's bad-debt agency, Pengurusan Danaharta, appointed special administrators earlier this week to take over day-to-day operations at Mr. Tajudin's aviation holding company, Naluri. The move came after the agency scrapped a 510.9 million ringgit ($134 million) deal to sell Mr. Tajudin's 45 percent stake in Naluri to recover some of the roughly 1 billion ringgit he owes Danaharta. 
 "We have to make sure that our rights are protected," said Izhar Hifnei Ismail, an agency spokesman. "What we really want to see is that whatever value there is preserved."
Seizing control of Naluri also gives the agency control of roughly 900 million ringgit ($236 million) left over from the government's much criticized, 1.8 billion ringgit buyout in late 2000 of Mr. Tajudin's stake in the Malaysian Airline System, the flag carrier. Naluri's new administrators will now be able to open Naluri's books, repeating a process that has already produced charges of financial misconduct against Mr. Tajudin at the two other companies he used to run.
The unraveling of Mr. Tajudin's holdings and the surrounding scandal are part of a purge by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of the entrepreneurs he once relied on as nation builders. In their place, he has promoted a group of technocrats, like those who run Danaharta, to overhaul corporate Malaysia.
While it no longer has a business of its own, Naluri owns stakes in four small airlines, including World Airways in the United States. It also owns part of a Malaysian aircraft parts company with Boeing. Executives at Naluri said they were prohibited from commenting by the special administrators. Mr. Tajudin was unavailable, they said.
A former merchant banker, Mr. Tajudin rose to prominence in the late 1980's under Daim Zainuddin, then the finance minister. Mr. Tajudin's company, Technology Resources Industries, bought Naluri, then called Malaysian Helicopter Services, from the struggling Malaysian Airline System in 1991. The same year, Technology Resources bought the country's sole cellular operator, Celcom.
Mr. Tajudin capped the rapid expansion of Malaysian Helicopter in 1994 by turning around and paying 1.79 billion ringgit in cash for the central bank's controlling stake in Malaysian Airline System, financing the purchase with a huge loan backed by his own shareholdings.
Mr. Tajudin's borrowing caught up with him, however, when the Asian financial crisis hit Malaysia in 1997. While Technology Resources and Celcom managed to win restructuring deals with creditors, Mr. Tajudin tried in vain to sell his stake in Malaysian Airline to pay off debts.
In late 2000, the government -- with Mr. Daim doing a reprise as finance minister -- finally bought out Mr. Tajudin, paying Naluri the same price per share it had paid for Malaysian Airline seven years earlier. The bailout, which paid Mr. Tajudin more than twice the prevailing market price, provoked widespread public outrage and was followed by the ouster of Mr. Daim.
Since then, the airline's new managers have asked the police to investigate allegations of irregularities involving a contract with a Naluri cargo venture in Germany.
The new owner of Technology Resources has made similar accusations. Mr. Tajudin lost control of the company last spring when he failed to make payments on roughly 1 billion ringgit in personal loans backed by his stakes in Technology Resources and Naluri. Securities regulators refused to let him use the funds raised by the sale of his Malaysian Airline stake, much of which is still at Naluri. Danaharta, which had bought the loans from local banks, in turn sold his stake in Technology Resources to Telekom Malaysia. 
This summer, Danaharta agreed to sell Mr. Tajudin's stake in Naluri to a little-known company called Valiant Entity. Local newspapers have linked Valiant to Mr. Tajudin, but Danaharta said it had no evidence of a connection. Either way, when Valiant failed to provide Danaharta with a required letter of credit for the purchase by a Dec. 17 deadline, Danaharta called off the sale and appointed special administrators for Naluri from KPMG.
Taking over the management of Naluri is an extraordinary move: the agency usually takes over only deeply indebted companies that it deems beyond restructuring. Naluri has no debts. But Mr. Tajudin remains Naluri's chairman and largest shareholder. In August, Naluri proposed buying back roughly 830 million ringgit in stock from its shareholders.
