HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE: THE YEAR IN REVIEW; 
Keeping Up With the Urgency Of Faith

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
RELIGION blew into civil society this year with the force of a shattered taboo. We now know how little we know about Islam, let alone other faiths in the modern world. Pressures for openness drove the Roman Catholic Church to a historic turning point in its relationship to the laity. And the great secular cathedral of New York City also opened itself to change.
 I visited three important ecclesiastical buildings in 2002, in each case before its completion. Seeing them as construction sites amplified their power as symbols of religion's changing value in the uncertain post-Cold War world. Richard Meier's JUBILEE CHURCH in Rome was particularly striking. The design's three free-standing walls, unencumbered by enclosure, created the effect of a regatta on land. Spinnakers billowing on the campagna. Grace. 
 The charismatic Capuchin monk Padre Pio was canonized this year, a few weeks after I visited San Giovanni Rotondo, Italy, the saint's native town on the Adriatic coast. The town's anticipation intensified the Gothic drama enacted by the construction team at Renzo Piano's CHURCH OF THANKSGIVING. With a capacity of 8,000 worshipers, the church is larger than most cathedrals. The asymmetrical design embodies the concept of pilgrimage. Even within the auditorium, which is configured in the shape of a nautilus, the visitor has a strong sense of ritual procession. The roof is supported by long-span stone arches arranged in a spiral, as if curving inward toward the enigma sometimes called the soul.
With financial pressures stemming from the litigation of sex abuse cases, the Roman Catholic diocese of Los Angeles played down the completion of Rafael Moneo's CATHEDRAL OF OUR LADY OF THE ANGELS. What a world. And it must be said that Moneo's design inadvertently reinforced the impression of an embattled church. At a time when many have been trying to turn the church inside out, Moneo reversed the process. In effect, his design turns the traditional Gothic cathedral outside in.
The enormous nave resembles a parvis, the open area outside a European cathedral's main facade. The flying buttresses have become void spaces. Slots in the stone wall enclosing the nave thrust upward on the diagonal to create openings in the ambulatory. A magnificent interior.
While it is not, strictly speaking, an ecclesiastical building, Frank Gehry's design for the CENTER FOR HUMAN DIGNITY in Jerusalem is conceived to help mediate the differences between faiths that give rise to conflict. The domed structure, 90 feet tall, can be entered at any point along the perimeter, through titanium-clad fins.
If you care to see the dome as an exhaust ventilator, be Gehry's guest. The debate could heat up in there. A project of the Simon Wiesenthal Institute, the museum includes an assembly hall, meeting rooms, a library and a Museum of Tolerance.
Richard Florida's "RISE OF THE CREATIVE CLASS" (Basic Books) is an important book for those who feel passionately about the future of the urban center. In fact, Florida virtually defines us. A native New Yorker who now teaches at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Florida is a sociologist. He offers no blueprint for architects and planners, and some of his thinking in these areas is fuzzy. Nonetheless, he has outlined the identity of the contemporary city's core population. Just by daring to use the word class, he's changed the framework for discussing social and economic inequality.
For a fuller look, pair Florida's book with Andrew Merrifield's "METROMARXISM: A MARXIST TALE OF THE CITY" (Routledge). People who equate Marxism with drabness have not been keeping up with their shopping (Prada) or their reading. Merrifield, a British writer who now lives in New York, is accessible, optimistic and even fun. The urban center, Merrifield argues, is the site of economic extremes and for that reason the most promising field for social change. A primer for the postindustrial "children of Marx and Coca-Cola."
"NEW HOTELS FOR GLOBAL NOMADS," a show at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in Manhattan, missed a golden opportunity to survey the habitats of the creative class in cities around the globe. There was a smattering of boutique hotels, but the message of mobility was hopelessly obscured by sections devoted to Las Vegas casinos, grand hotel resorts from the past and a series of pointless installations by artists.
FREDERICK SCHWARTZ wasn't the first architect to propose burying West Street, the eight-lane roadway that divides Battery Park City from the rest of lower Manhattan, and covering it with a platform promenade. He may not even have been the first to figure out that you could transfer all of the development rights from ground zero to the new acreage the platform would produce.
But he was the plan's loudest, most persistent, most obnoxious advocate. Eventually, people paid attention. Though the platform plan may not materialize (Battery Park City residents oppose it), the idea made people realize that ground zero's official planners were incapable of thinking outside the box in more ways than one.
At a TOWN HALL MEETING held at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on July 20, the public seized control of a process that had been carefully scripted to manipulate its acceptance of a banal neo-traditional plan for ground zero. Forced back to the drawing boards, officials of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation initiated a 10-week INNOVATIVE DESIGN STUDY FOR THE WORLD TRADE CENTER SITE, with projects by some of the world's leading contemporary architects.
The results of the study were presented on Dec. 18 in the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center at Battery Park City. The exhibition will remain on view until Feb. 2.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN REVIEW; 
The Idea Was Not to Have a New One

BYLINE:  By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
THE worst of times was followed by the most formulaic of times. 2002 was a year with lots of new lows and very few highs, a year of synthetic hits and ersatz stars, a year in which individual voices and independent visions were overshadowed by assembly-line products -- remakes, rereleases and regurgitations, along with lots of sequels and spinoffs.
 None of these depressing developments is new, of course, but after the terrorist attacks of 9/11, with an economy teetering on recession, and studios, networks, record companies and publishers all feeling increasingly risk-averse, the search for the Next Sure Thing dominated the cultural landscape as never before. 
 This was a year in which the most talked-about showdown on television was between a Victoria's Secret special on CBS and ABC's finale of "The Bachelor" -- between a 60-minute commercial for underwear and a two-hour catfight between two pandering women vying for the hand of a rose-bearing stud.
It was a year that witnessed the 20th installment of the James Bond franchise, the 10th "Star Trek" movie, the eighth "Halloween" sequel, the fourth Jack Ryan/Tom Clancy film, the fourth movie featuring Hannibal the Cannibal, the third Austin Powers picture, the second of a projected seven Harry Potter movies, and the 1,234,567th Cinderella story starring the starlet du jour. 
Greeting-card sentimentality and snarky, knee-jerk irony proliferated with abandon this year, and so did cheap gimmicks: "Sopranos" stars and other celebrities baring all on Broadway; an interactive $1 million treasure hunt on ABC's pretentious mystery "Push, Nevada"; and nationwide tryouts for the shame of being rejected by Simon Cowell on "American Idol."
In the past, hard times and historical uncertainties have often galvanized the artistic imagination -- think of the literature produced during the 1970's and 80's in Latin America, Eastern Europe and South Africa. In the case of millennial America, it's too soon to tell what the long-term effects will be, but thus far, the cultural fallout from Sept. 11 has ranged from the negligible to the tacky.
Certainly, the "New Normal" didn't make for kinder, gentler, higher-minded art, as so many predicted. A new fascination with mortality surfaced -- in novels like "The Lovely Bones" and movies like "Solaris" -- but it tended to manifest itself most visibly in a grisly interest in forensics and autopsies ("C.S.I.," "C.S.I. Miami" and "Crossing Jordan"). Sales of violent video games like "Grand Theft Auto" boomed, and sexual exhibitionism turned back the clock on women: prostitutes and their johns vamped before hidden video cameras on HBO's "Cathouse"; Rolling Stone made a habit of putting half-naked cheesecake shots of young singers and actresses on its covers; and even the new Barbie donned navel-baring Britneyesque togs.
If people were worried about terrorism, a possible war with Iraq and the specter of smallpox attacks, they weren't showing it. In front of television cameras, they wolfed down water-buffalo penises, underwent extreme cosmetic surgery and cried over being rejected by suitors they barely knew. Even Al Gore climbed into a hot tub on "Saturday Night Live" with an actor impersonating Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, and played at being commander in chief on the set of "The West Wing."
The harsh dose of reality Americans experienced in the last year didn't kill off phony Darwinian competitions like "Fear Factor" and "Survivor," but instead spawned another wave of reality shows, from train-wreck exercises in voyeurism like "The Anna Nicole Show" to such demeaning exercises in sexual commerce as "Looking for Love: Bachelorettes in Alaska."
Reality shows, like the fast-food franchising of movie characters and television shows, are just another symptom of Hollywood's current deficit of ideas: its ham-handed efforts to fill an ever deepening vacuum of ideas with cheap, lowest-common-denominator spectacles and low-risk, easy-to-merchandise sequels.
The creative hole in television was underscored this year by the demise of "Ally McBeal," "The X-Files," "Spin City" and "Dharma and Greg," and the utter hollowness of new ventures like David E. Kelley's "Girls Club." Many old standbys, including "E.R.," "Frasier," "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and "N.Y.P.D. Blue," jumped the shark in 2002, and even "The Sopranos" appeared to be running out of gas.
Things weren't much better in the film business. Entertainment Weekly reported in August that "the stock price of nearly every studio's parent company is approaching rock bottom." Star vehicles like Madonna's "Swept Away" and Eddie Murphy's "Adventures of Pluto Nash" crashed and burned. And many of the year's most highly anticipated auteur efforts proved disappointing as well: Steven Soderbergh's "Full Frontal" devolved into an exercise in Dogma-tic pretension; Sam Mendes's "Road to Perdition" tried to mix film noir with family soap opera and ended up feeling both portentous and sentimental; Martin Scorsese's "Gangs of New York" played like an extremely violent, extremely lugubrious segment of "Masterpiece Theater"; and Spike Jonze's wildly overpraised "Adaptation" amounted to a solipsistic reworking of Sam Shepard's play "True West."
A year ago, half of the Top 10 grossing films were sequels, and in 2002, the recycling mania accelerated. In addition to a host of franchise pictures (James Bond, Harry Potter, "Star Wars," "The Lord of Rings," and so on and so on), there was an outpouring of pictures made from old television shows ("Scooby-Doo," "Jackass," "I Spy"), Broadway shows ("Chicago"), novels ("Possession," "White Oleander") and old movies ("Rollerball," "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town") -- in many cases with little thought being given to how such properties might be adapted in a cinematically interesting way, with the notable exception of "Chicago."
Even movies that were not obvious remakes often turned out to be rip-offs of earlier hits or stylized reproductions: Jennifer Lopez's "Maid in Manhattan" is a mechanical pastiche of "Working Girl" and "Pretty Woman"; "Far From Heaven" is a studied and pointless replica of Douglas Sirk's 1950's melodramas; and the Naomi Watts thriller "The Ring" was based on a Japanese cult film.
On Broadway, where producers increasingly prize broad-based audience appeal over the idiosyncratic voices of individual writers and composers, recycling also continued, with more and more shows based on old movies and pop songs. Two of this year's most talked-about shows took slyly subversive, innovative films, sheared away the edges and produced cheesy, by-the-numbers works. The Broadway version of "The Graduate" created buzz solely on the promise of seeing Kathleen Turner shed her clothes; and the Broadway version of "Hairspray" turned John Waters's messy Dadaist comedy into a slick, candy-colored exercise in feel-good nostalgia.
With producers looking for another "Producers," more translations are in the works, including musical adaptations of "Batman," "Legally Blonde" and "Moonstruck." MGM alone is said to have some 20 projects in development for the stage.
It also became clear this year that cloning wasn't limited to shows and movies, that many of today's celebrities are in fact third-generation copies of earlier performers. Kelly Clarkson, the thoroughly generic, thoroughly manufactured star of the summer's hit reality show "American Idol," is a blurry copy of Mariah Carey, who is a blurry copy of Whitney Houston, who is a blurry copy of Aretha Franklin, who was the genuine thing. Pierce Brosnan, the current 007, is a watered down version of Roger Moore, who was a watered down, defanged version of the one and only Sean Connery. Justin Timberlake is a bad imitation of the vintage Michael Jackson, and Faith Hill and Shania Twain have both traded in their country roots to become pseudo-Celine Dions. The Strokes are Blondie and Velvet Underground wanna-bes, and with his new album, "18," the ubiquitous Moby officially became a parody of himself.
Given all these epigones, it's no surprise that many of the best received performances in 2002 came from baby-boomer artists: the Stones embarked on a triumphant tour; reconstituted versions of the Who and the Doors are back on tour, and James Taylor, Rod Stewart, Santana, Phil Collins, Elton John and Elvis all had Top 40 hits. Stephen Sondheim also enjoyed a glorious renaissance this year with a spirited revival of "Into the Woods" on Broadway, and a critically acclaimed repertory production of six of his shows at Washington's Kennedy Center.
So why do so many newer acts and projects feel so synthetic? The thinking behind movie franchises, certainly, is that it's easier to sell and merchandise a brand-name product -- familiarity, the reasoning goes, makes for bigger opening weekends, and a longer shelf life with spinoffs, video games, soundtracks and other corporate tie-ins. And in the music industry, the growing use of digital processing (using software like Pro Tools, which makes it possible to correct pitch and adjust timing) has made for more synthetic-sounding recordings, while changing the criterion by which singers are judged. As Billboard magazine noted: "Major-label executives readily admit that signing an act now is as much about star presence as it is about the artist's actual ability to consistently sing the notes."
As 2002 slouches to a close, however, all was not lost. Amid the cultural wreckage, there were potent albums from the alternative country band Wilco and the Detroit garage band the White Stripes, and novels by Ian McEwan, Jeffrey Eugenides, Richard Flanagan, Bruce Wagner and Alice Sebold that were as emotionally powerful as they were ambitious. Several new television shows like "24" and "Boomtown" tried, however unevenly, to push narrative conventions in new directions; and Larry David's HBO show "Curb Your Enthusiasm" gave us a hilarious look at the absurdities of modern life, as seen through the eyes of an endlessly put-upon curmudgeon.
Teen pop -- the apotheosis of shallow, overprocessed, image-driven music -- is clearly on the way out, giving way to more R & B, hip-hop and old-fashioned rock; Britney Spears has already been replaced as girl of the moment by the punkette Avril Lavigne. The Osbournes retained their wacky charm, in spite of an absurd amount of overexposure, and Eminem managed to go softer and more mainstream with his movie, "8 Mile," without losing his street cred.
Movies by Pedro Almodovar ("Talk to Her"), Zacharias Kunuk ("The Fast Runner") and Alfonso Cuaron ("Y Tu Mama Tambien") reminded us that original, new work is still being done -- at least by foreign directors. Performances by Tobey Maguire in "Spider-Man" and Reese Witherspoon in "Sweet Home Alabama" reminded us that talented actors can shine in fatuous projects. And after years of mannered appearances, Jack Nicholson reminded us of his skills as an actor in "About Schmidt." The phenomenal popularity of the $5 million independent movie "My Big Fat Greek Wedding" demonstrated that expensive doesn't necessarily mean big box office, just as the pallid response to much-publicized pictures like "The Four Feathers," "The Truth About Charlie" and "Death to Smoochy" sent a message to Hollywood that the Next Sure Thing doesn't necessarily reside in high concepts or big names, that audiences still appreciate the unexpected.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE: THE YEAR IN REVIEW -- THE CRITICS/10 MOMENTS; 
Richter, And Cloth, Were Abundant

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
 Here are not the 10 best, but 10 noteworthy items, in loose order:

1. 'GERHARD RICHTER: 40 YEARS OF PAINTING' -- The Gerhard Richter retrospective, an unexpected smash even for the Museum of Modern Art, proved that serious painting is alive and well and that masses of people still want to look at it. The work annoyed and baffled just enough viewers to stir debate.

2. 'TAPESTRY IN THE RENAISSANCE: ART AND MAGNIFICENCE' -- Stupefyingly beautiful, this was the year's sleeper, hands down. The Metropolitan Museum displayed a vast array of one-of-a-kind textiles by Raphael, Bronzino and other superstars: tours-de-force of color, illusion, wealth and power that rival anything in paint or marble.

3. 'DOCUMENTA 11' -- Not because the gigantic contemporary-art survey in Kassel, Germany, organized by Okwui Enwezor, was a pleasure (it wasn't). But the work -- earnest, politically inclined, morally puritanical -- epitomized the new festival mode: call it establishment-certified antiestablishment art. The catalog, full of gibberish about "transculturality" and the "supposed purity and autonomy of the art object," underscored the emphasis on social and economic evangelism, which pleased the already converted and bored many others.

4. 'EVA HESSE' -- A retrospective organized at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art of an artist whose hastened career, haunted by big ideas, reminds us that art, when produced at ecstatic pitch, can seem the most joyous and important thing in the universe.

5. 'BARNETT NEWMAN' Handsomely installed at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the show made an eloquent argument for Newman's radical and almost ludicrously ambitious achievement, dispelling knee-jerk impulses to reject it or him.

6. 'THOMAS EAKINS' This exemplary retrospective, organized by Philadelphia and then presented at the Met, reminded us that it is still impossible to see America, or at least to look back on the country in the 19th century, without some refraction through Eakins's art.

7. 'THE PAINTINGS OF JOAN MITCHELL' Lush, opulent fields of colors, seemingly all paradisiacal, containing shades of melancholy that revealed themselves to you after your eyes adjusted to their light. Abstract art does not get more ravishing than the best of the works in this exhibition, which was at the Whitney Museum.

8. 'THE QUILTS OF GEE'S BEND' An ebullient exhibition (organized by the Houston Museum of Fine Arts and now at the Whitney), in the unlikely guise of a show of hand-stitched quilts from a remote, historically black community along the Alabama River. Imagine Matisse and Klee arising not from rarefied Europe, but from the caramel soil of the rural South.

9. 'WINOGRAND 1964' The photographer Garry Winogrand crisscrossed America in an old Ford Fairlane, creating a fresh, divinely eccentric portrait of the country after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. A poor skeptic, Winogrand, whose show was at the International Center of Photography, clearly saw the fragility and the preciousness of what bound people together, and his pictures, though dark-humored, were full of heart.

10. IN MEMORIAM Larry Rivers, the irreverent, high-spirited, multifaceted, proto-Pop painter and self-mocking bad boy, died in August at 78. Roberto Matta, the last major Surrealist, who died in November in his early 90's, leaving behind automatic drawings and gelatinous landscapes filled with eerie organic shapes, influenced Pollock, Arshile Gorky and many others. J. Carter Brown died in June, at 67. A patrician populist, as director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington he did as much as anyone to reshape American art museums during the second half of the 20th century. And John Brealey, the Met Museum paintings conservator, who cleaned Velazquez's "Meninas," died in December. He did much for the museum, his profession and art.

HEADLINE: MUSIC: THE YEAR IN REVIEW; 
Changes Where It Matters Most: At the Top

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
All the studies that have examined the challenges facing performing-arts institutions in recent years confirm what intuition would suggest: artistic leadership is everything. Only a strong artistic director can hone an institutional vision, present a dynamic persona to the public and energize audiences. The challenges are especially severe as those institutions cope with the cataclysmic aftermath of Sept. 11 and the ailing economy. 
 Among classical music institutions, the major symphony orchestras have, with notable exceptions, been the biggest drags on innovation. So the most significant story of 2002 was the arrival of new music directors at several major orchestras. 
 The most contentious change took place at the New York Philharmonic with the coming of Lorin Maazel. The board surely knew what it was getting when it appointed this prickly 72-year-old maestro: a top-down, old-school conductor, undeniably accomplished, technically incomparable yet prone to willful, micromanaged performances. It's amazing that Mr. Maazel has put his stamp on the Philharmonic so quickly. The orchestra is playing with sleek technical command, burnished sound and awesome control, but at a cost to spontaneity and imagination.
So far, Mr. Maazel has proved a curt, aloof public figure. In the face of calls for innovation and freshness, he and his board act as if only they understood the weighty responsibility of carrying on the Philharmonic's heritage. That the musicians, by and large, pushed for his appointment seems inexplicable. But it's still early, and perhaps their judgment will prove right.
It's hard not to compare the changeover in New York with that at the Berlin Philharmonic, which this year welcomed Simon Rattle, 47, as its new director. Talk about a heritage: the Berlin Philharmonic's is as venerated as they come. Yet the players, especially the many younger ones recruited in recent years, seem excited and empowered by their new conductor and his vision of taking a fresh approach to the standard repertory, embracing neglected 20th-century works and making the orchestra a haven for living composers.
To assess the change James Levine will bring to the Boston Symphony, we'll have to wait a bit, for his tenure does not begin until 2004. Things had long gone stale under Seiji Ozawa, and the orchestra showed great resolve in recruiting Mr. Levine. They wanted him; he wanted them. But with no intention of leaving the Metropolitan Opera and with two years remaining on his Munich Philharmonic contract, Mr. Levine was not free. So the orchestra boldly decided to punt for two seasons, bring in strong guest conductors and appoint Mr. Levine music director designate. Even in this provisional role, he is shaking things up. Though Mr. Ozawa was a famously clueless programmer, Mr. Levine, from all reports, already has enough ideas to fill five or six seasons.
In another important change, Franz Welser-Most took over the mighty Cleveland Orchestra from the towering Christoph von Dohnanyi. Mr. Welser-Most, a 42-year-old Austrian, is a bit of an unknown. Highly skilled and deeply principled, he is an unassuming figure. Yet in his own modest way he has staked a course and reached out to the Cleveland community. Time will tell.
But with budget crises and competition for audiences, there is not much time for the new music directors to deliver. How they fare will probably be the story of 2003.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
A Rental Project Brings Elderly Strangers Together

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
THE idea of the elderly sharing an apartment with someone they have never met is not new. It is especially popular in the South and in cities, where older people with limited incomes are looking to share costs and companionship, say real estate professionals who specialize in working with the elderly. 
 But on Long Island, they say, in spite of a need for affordable housing for those 55 and over, the concept has not taken off, with the exception of some assisted-living facilities. 
 While builders remain skeptical about whether shared housing works, citing concerns about compatibility, at least one group is introducing it in central Nassau: a new 33-unit affordable rental building for people 55 and over in the town of North Hempstead, called Apex Senior Citizen Housing, will contain five units to be shared by two unrelated tenants.
"Sharing an apartment is not just for the economic aspect, but it allows seniors to be independent longer, by replacing loneliness with physical and emotional support," said Howard B. Kimmel, the founder and president of the nonprofit Anna and Philip Kimmel Foundation, which is building the $7.5 million project. 
The issue of compatibility will be handled by an on-site superintendent and regular visits by religious and social service groups, he said.
"The concept of shared living is not a new idea, but it is new for the rental community and Long Island," said Fern Karhu, manager of Prudential Long Island Realty's Syosset office. Ms. Karhu and Bart Cafarella, a senior regional manager for Prudential, are hosts of a radio program, "Seniors on the Move," which focuses on living options on Long Island for people over 55. The program is heard on Mondays at 7 p.m. on WLIE-AM (540).
"About 60 percent of the increasing number of seniors we see are alone," Ms. Karhu said. "They don't have the equity to buy affordable housing and they go to rentals. They would benefit from shared housing, but that will always be a very limited market. People want to remain independent." She noted, too, that every new development, especially rentals, provoked fears about property values. 
According to the United States census, the number of people living on Long Island rose to 2.3 million people from 1.7 million between 1990 and 2000. Of the 2000 population, 42 percent were over 55, a 25 percent increase since 1990.
There are 182 legal rental buildings in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, according to a recent study by the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group based in Hauppauge. Most of the renters spend up to 50 percent of their total income for rent, which is beyond the 35 percent recommended by the federal government, said Jim Morgo, the president. "The median rental on Long Island is now $1,200 for a one-bedroom apartment," he said. 
"The concept of shared living is a good one, and Apex is the kind of thing we need," he said, noting that while there were some small groups with home-share programs, there were not many. 
While two low-income rental projects for those 55 and over are currently being built by the Garden City-based Benjamin Development Company, there are no shared units, said Russell Mohr, director of sales and leasing. "We aren't familiar enough with the concept to consider it now," he said.
In Suffolk, Benjamin is converting the 170,000-square-foot, seven-floor administration building of the former Central Islip Psychiatric Center into 153 affordable rental units. Financing for the $26 million project, called Court Plaza, is through the state, with $15 million through the town's Industrial Development Agency and a $6 million tax credit equity.
Applicants must have an income below 60 percent of the area's median, which is $66,400 for a family of two and $83,000 for a family of four. Rents, which include heat, range from $900 for a one-bedroom apartment to $1,050 for two bedrooms. All units can be adapted for the handicapped and Benjamin expects tenants to take occupancy in April.
Farther east, Benjamin is building Medford Landing, four buildings with a total of 112 affordable rental units. Rents range from $815 for a one-bedroom unit to $1,095 for two. 
The New York City-based Sterling Glen Communities, which has built five rental apartment buildings for older people on Long Island, has not included any shared units, said Michael Daly, the president.
"We don't find a desire for shared units in independent living on Long Island except maybe with sisters or a relative," he said. "We could do it if the market tells us."
BUT, he said, Sterling Glen's parent company, Forest City Enterprises, a publicly traded real estate company based in Cleveland, has built 60 shared-living units for people 55 and over in a 320-unit complex in Florida. The shared units have two bedrooms on either side of a common living room and kitchen. "It's an economy-driven issue and there people share," Mr. Daly said. "But it comes with unusual rules to prevent conflicts, such as not permitting televisions in the common area."
"One of the challenges is to get people to know each other and to like each other," he said. "It's like going to college for the first year." 
Apex is the first building being constructed by the Kimmel Foundation, which was formed in 1995 to build housing for those with low income and special needs, according to Mr. Kimmel, who was the administrator of the State Division of Housing Community Renewal for 40 years. The foundation is named after his parents. Those eligible to live at Apex must have an income below 49 percent of the area's median. 
There are 27 600-square-foot, one-bedroom units ranging in rent from $565 to $710 a month, not including utilities. 
In addition, the four-story building has five 950-square-foot two-bedroom units that would be shared by two unrelated people paying $410 each. These units have two bedrooms, each with a bathroom and a door that locks. There is a common area, including a dining room, living room and kitchen with two refrigerators. A sixth, two-bedroom, unit will be occupied by the building superintendent. All units are adaptable for the handicapped. 
The Family and Children's Association, a social service agency, and the Rev. John Mulryan, the foundation's executive director and the rector at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Great Neck. are selecting the tenants, and screening and matching those for the shared units. They will have offices on the premises to be available to solve problems. 
Financing for the project has come from state and federal funds, including $1.1 million through the state Housing Trust Fund and $5 million in low-income housing tax credits dispensed through Key Bank and Verizon. Occupancy is expected by February. 
Apex is being built in New Cassel, a one-mile-square community of 13,000 people within the town of North Hempstead. It is in an area off Union Avenue that has been designated by the town for urban renewal.
Across Union Avenue is the incorporated village of Westbury, where "there was initial skepticism over the project," Mr. Kimmel said. After two years of meetings with the community, "it was finally accepted as a good thing," he said.
Mannie Sweat, president of the Central Westbury Civic Association, which represents 200 homeowners, said: "At first there were concerns about the need for the place, our property values, how it would be built, and the selection and safety of the tenants. Now we congratulate Mr. Kimmel and the foundation to have the foresight to see the needs of the seniors." 
The association, Mr. Kimmel said. "held us to high standards" and several architectural aspects were changed to satisfy it. These included placing a seven-foot-high wrought-iron fence around the property for security, according to the building's designer, Lloyd Goldfarb, a Great Neck architect. 
The town has given $450,000 toward the project, and will probably give $50,000 more, from its annual allotment of $1.5 million in federal money for urban renewal, said Neville Mullings, executive director of the Community Development Agency. 
"We have supported the foundation because it is a significant contribution to the renewal project and for senior housing, which is desperately needed," he said.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bridgewater, N.J.; 
Where the Downtown Is a Shopping Mall

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
IN an understated way, Mayor James T. Dowden calls the Bridgewater Commons Mall "our downtown with a roof over it." But there is little common about the upscale 900,000-square-foot mall, anchored by Bloomingdale's, Lord & Taylor and Macy's. It dominates the retail industry in Somerset County, N.J., and has given the 32.7-square-mile township an enviable tax base, traffic that snarls its roads during rush hours and major shopping days -- and an identity.
 "Back in the 1960's, before the mall was planned, we were fighting the United States Postal Service for our own ZIP code," the mayor said. "The mall has given us exposure." 
 Framed by the intersections of Interstate 287 and Routes 22, 202 and 206, the mall, completed in 1988 after 20 years of debate and legal wrangling that reached the New Jersey Supreme Court, is the centerpiece of a 140-acre tract that realtors call the Golden Triangle. It is surrounded by a 347-room Marriott Hotel and more than 300 office buildings that are occupied by many leading high technology and pharmaceutical companies. Among the companies in its Class A office space are Johnson & Johnson, AT&T and Aventis, a pharmaceutical giant that rents a dozen large buildings and has its headquarters in the township. 
"Our highways are our blessing," said Ranald C. Brown, a broker at Golden Key Realty on Washington Valley Road. 
Indeed, the development of Bridgewater from an agricultural backwater into a commercial powerhouse parallels the construction of its highway system. In 1960, its population stood at 15,789. A decade later, the population had virtually doubled to 30,325, after the construction of the 67.5-mile-long Interstate 287, a four- to eight-lane beltway that starts at the Outerbridge Crossing and loops through central, western and northern New Jersey, connecting up with the Garden State Parkway, the New Jersey Turnpike and many other large highways. It eventually links with the New York State Thruway. By 1990, after the completion of Interstate 78, which slices across the northwestern corner of Bridgewater and links Newark with Harrisburg, Pa., the population had swelled to 37,455. 
"In half an hour, I can be in Newark Airport or New York City; we are 20 minutes from New Hope, 40 minutes from the beach and less than an hour from skiing," said Onofrio R. Cirianni, a self-employed securities broker who had his four-bedroom colonial built on a half-acre lot and moved in from neighboring Raritan Borough a year ago. "Yes, the mall and the office buildings also bring us traffic. But they keep our taxes reasonable when communities without these ratables are getting crushed."
Mr. Cirianni says he tries to time his appointments to take advantage of the highways while avoiding rush-hour backups. "Traffic is a matter of timing," he said. "Besides, you can't have the convenience of the mall, the people you need in order to do business and no traffic." 
The tax rate in Bridgewater is $1.83 per $100 of assessed valuation, the fourth lowest of the 21 municipalities in Somerset County. According to the township's tax assessor, Anthony Dirado, commercial property shoulders one-fourth of the tax burden, giving relief to home owners. The largest taxpayer is the mall, valued at more that $217 million, which pays $4 million annually.
Despite the mall's high profile, retail space occupies only 2 percent of the township's 32.7 square miles, with houses taking up close to 60 percent. The single family housing stock ranges from small bungalows in the Bradley Gardens and Finderne neighborhoods in the southwest, up to sprawling new 5,000-square-foot colonials on lots of an acre or more off Chimney Rock Road on the ridge of the Watchung Mountains.
Prices for single-family homes start about $175,000 for bungalows needing work, according to Mr. Brown. Mountaintop houses with 30-mile views into Hunterdon County to the south can go for upward of $1.4 million. In mid-December, 136 housing units were on the market, ranging from $106,000 for a one-bedroom condominium in the Morgan Lane complex in the southeastern corner of the township up to $1,059,990 for an 11-room brick colonial with a three-car garage on Presidents Drive in the northwestern section. 
The lowest priced single-family home on the market was a three-bedroom 1950's ranch listed at $214,000 on Pine Street in Bradley Gardens. In the same area, developers have been buying up small, run-down houses, knocking them down and building four-bedroom colonials that sell for about $400,000.
Although the housing market has slowed since its peak in July, Mr. Brown said, houses sell in an average of 24 days, fetching more than 98 percent of their asking prices.
The most prevalent houses are 1960's colonials, splits and ranches on lots of three-quarters of an acre to one acre on streets like Papen or Buxton Roads in the Washington Valley Estates section in the northern part of the township, just east of I-287. According to Mr. Brown, three-bedroom Washington Valley homes start about $400,000 and rise with the improvements made by homeowners.
THE township also has more than a dozen condominium apartment and town house complexes, mainly in the southwestern section of town. Most were built since 1985 to comply with the New Jersey Supreme Court's Mount Laurel decision of 1975, obligating all municipalities to provide their fair share of affordable housing. For each "Mount Laurel unit" built, developers were allowed to construct four market-rate units. Since Bridgewater's allotment was set at 1,468 affordable housing units, the Mount Laurel decision led to the construction of 7,340 new homes, mainly condominium apartments and town houses and high-density single-family housing. 
Condominiums range in price from about $105,000 for some small one-bedroom apartments in the Morgan Lane complex, up to about $425,000 for some luxury three-bedroom units in the Loft Farms complex on the Watchung Mountains, off Chimney Rock Road near Route 78. 
Among the newer residents, Mr. Cirianni said that he and his wife, Rita, were drawn by the 8,550 Bridgewater-Raritan Regional School District, which the township shares with the 6,000-resident borough to its south. They both grew up in Raritan and graduated from the Bridgewater-Raritan Regional High School. "We have four children, ages 2 through 9," Mr. Cirianni said. "We had a great experience and still have friends and family in Raritan. But we wanted a larger piece of property than we could get in Raritan. So we looked in Bridgewater."
The Bridgewater-Raritan district has six K-3 primary schools, two intermediate schools for Grades 4 and 5, a middle school for Grades 6 to 8 and the 1,994-student Bridgewater-Raritan Regional High School. All are in Bridgewater itself except for a single primary school. Average class sizes throughout the district range from 19.2 to 23.2, compared with a state average of 20.8.
The high school occupies a 120-acre campus and has its own closed circuit television studio that is linked to the local cable system, allowing high school programs to be broadcast into homes.
In 1998, the high school was named a New Jersey Star School, the highest distinction awarded by the state Department of Education. Two years later, it was named a National Blue Ribbon School of Excellence by the United States Department of Education.
On the SAT reasoning test, Bridgewater-Raritan students consistently surpass the state average. On last year's tests, the students had a combined verbal and mathematics score of 1,093, more than 80 points above the state average. Last year's graduates included eight National Merit Scholarship finalists and eight semifinalists.
Of the 477-student graduating class, 69 percent went on to four-year colleges and 20 percent are attending two-year colleges. The high school offers 26 Advanced Placement courses in the sciences, computers, economics, English, history, foreign languages, politics, mathematics, music, statistics and psychology.
ACCORDING to the interim superintendent of schools, Frank J. Severage, enrollment is growing by 300 to 400 students annually, mainly because of construction of town houses and high density single-family homes. In March, the district will propose a referendum on the construction of another elementary school in Bridgewater, which would cost local taxpayers up to $24 million. 
"We are seeing many more young families," Mr. Severage said. "Our graduating classes are in the 400-student range and our lower grades have 700 students, so we have to prepare for the increase."
About one-quarter of the township, 5,200 acres, is public and open space, according to Mayor Dowden. This includes five Somerset County parks, with the 600-acre Washington Valley Park off Millers Lane the largest. The most widely used county parks are the 332-acre Duke Island, which has bike trails, two softball fields, several fishing spots and picnic grounds, and the 170-acre North Branch Park, where the County Parks Department is headquartered and where the annual county and 4-H fairs are held.
The county also operates the 18-hole 6,443-yard Green Knoll Golf Course off Garretson Road, near the mall. Greens fees for Somerset County residents are $14 on weekdays and $16 on weekends. Nonresident golfers pay twice those amounts. Besides the public course, Bridgewater has the private Raritan Valley Country Club, an 18-hole course off Route 22, near Bridgewater Commons.

The encampment, which is on the National and New Jersey Registers of Historic Places, was the spot where the Stars and Stripes first flew over United States troops in the year 1777 after being officially adopted by the Continental Congress. Washington valued the position because it controlled a strategic cut in the mountains, allowing him to obstruct the movement of British troops between New York and Philadelphia. HEADLINE: A Big Eye to the Sky, Still Blindfolded 

BYLINE:  By ALLAN RICHTER 

DATELINE: STONY BROOK 

 BODY:
SUNY STONY BROOK'S six-ton, 10-foot telescope can survey galaxies far, far away, but it has traveled more miles cross-country in search of a permanent home than it has scanned in the heavens above Long Island.
 Deane Peterson, an astronomy professor at Stony Brook, has overseen the telescope's travels and witnessed the negotiations aimed at putting the device to use. The equipment had a home in Arizona but for more than a decade has been gathering dust in a basement on the Stony Brook campus. 
 "We're sort of used up at this point," Dr. Peterson said recently. "It's hard to count the number of direct initiatives we've taken and failed. We just don't know what to do with it next. You should probably talk to somebody who's a little more enthusiastic. I pretty much used up my energy on this project." 
The university bought the telescope from an English supplier for around $100,000 shortly after building its Earth and Space Science center in 1967. The school's capital spending plan called for kicking in another $150,000 or so to build an observatory on a piece of property it owned nearby in Old Field. But the project met stiff opposition from residents of the exclusive village.
"That was a period of time when there had been drug raids on campus by the Suffolk police," said Dr. Peterson, who joined SUNY Stony Brook in 1970. "Old Field residents were very upset by the possibility of being overrun by shaggy-haired, reefer-smoking undergraduates."
After Old Field put the kibosh on the project, the university hooked up with Harvard University and the Smithsonian Institution to house the 24-inch telescope, measured by the diameter of its reflecting mirror, at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory on Mount Hopkins, south of Tucson, Ariz. SUNY Stony Brook, Harvard and the Smithsonian split the cost of erecting a building for the telescope, next to one that housed an existing 60-inch telescope. 
The Stony Brook telescope was in use at the Whipple Observatory for nearly 20 years. "It was there until about 1990," Dr. Peterson said. "Then Harvard and the Smithsonian decided they needed the site for a larger telescope, and that made sense to us, so we packed the thing up and brought it back east." 
Two university students drove the disassembled telescope to Poughkeepsie, where the university thought it had a new partner in Vassar College. But the deal fell through, and today the telescope sits in pieces on wooden pallets in a storeroom in the Earth and Space Science Building on the Stony Brook campus.
It is difficult to tell that the telescope is not a preoccupation for Dr. Peterson. A cork bulletin board with snapshots of the telescope's Arizona disassembly is tucked away behind a file cabinet near his fourth-floor office, but the professor pulls it out as if it were a daily lesson plan.
Dr. Peterson said he took the snapshots and kept notes to help in the reassembly process. "It took us about five hours to figure out how to take off one of the parts," he recounted. "As long as I'm alive it will go back together pretty simply."
A few years ago, the stars seemed to align for a reassembly when the university and the Town of Brookhaven discovered that they had a confluence of interests.
"I thought it would be nice if the town built a little observatory at one of our sites," said Chris Gamboni, an amateur astronomer and administrative assistant with the town's Office of Economic Development. "We would tell all our students and teachers that this was available. The town board fell in love with the idea."
But the town had budgeted for an observatory to house a smaller telescope. Installing the university's equipment would have meant spending about $200,000 for an observatory, more than twice the cost of the original plan. The deal unraveled last year.
Dr. Peterson had largely avoided erecting the telescope at the university. An existing observatory atop the Earth and Space Science Building holds a 14-inch telescope but is too small for the 24-incher. But with no alternatives, Dr. Peterson began warming to the idea of housing the telescope on campus.
Then this fall the university opened its new football stadium, flooding the area Dr. Peterson had in mind with evening light, the bane of people who peer at the heavens.
But the professor may not be down for the count. This month the Town of Riverhead adopted a "dark skies" resolution requiring shielded lighting on new residential and business developments. Ed Densieski, the town board member who sponsored the resolution, suggested that the Stony Brook telescope could have a home at the former Grumman property in Calverton and began playing matchmaker between Dr. Peterson and developers who are building a park on part of the site.
"I hadn't thought of that," the professor said, raising an eyebrow as if discovering some new nebula. "The old Grumman property -- well, there you go."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Deane Peterson, an astronomy professor at Stony Brook, has been trying to find a home for his telescope. (Deirdre Brennan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: State Has Become More Generous, but Still Lags the Nation 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY B. COHEN 

 BODY:
PHILIP H. LODEWICK said he is blessed in life -- his wife is his best friend, he is healthy, he has had a wealth of opportunity, and now he has the opportunity to share his wealth.
 "I don't consider any of it mine," said Mr. Lodewick, an independent businessman of 25 years, a philanthropist of roughly 12 years, chairman of the Board of Advisors for the University of Connecticut's Business School, and both a university graduate and donor. "More and more, people are understanding that bad financial planning is dying with more than $1,000." 
 When it comes to charitable giving, Connecticut has the uncomfortable task of living up to its reputation as the richest state in the nation. 
In the minds of many, bounty should equal charity, so in a state so bountiful, there should be more people like Philip Lodewick and charity should match. But it hasn't, although the state is improving.
Using the Internal Revenue Service's figures from the 2000 tax year, the most recent figures available, the Connecticut Council for Philanthropy found that the state ranked 17th in the nation in the amount of average contributions, at $3,740. And even though the state ranks first in per capita income, and has been No. 1 for years, 2000 was the first time since the council began compiling numbers in 1996 that the state managed to beat the national average for contributions, which in 2000 was $3,627.
Still, ranking 17th is a lot better than where the state was in 1995, when it ranked in the bottom third, in 36th place at $2,156. Back then, it also ranked 45th in average contributions for all taxpayers with an income greater than $200,000 who itemized their deductions, but jumped to 24th in 2000. But residents making between $100,000 to $200,000 came in at 49th in 2000, a ranking that hasn't changed since 1995.
"The first time we saw the numbers we were surprised we weren't in a better position compared to other states in the country," said Nancy P. Roberts, the council's president. "That contrast was important in getting attention to the issue" of the disparity between what residents earn and what they give. But I don't think people have been made aware that, hey, guys, we're doing better," she said. "More people are giving, and they're giving more."
Experts said they were confounded by the state's record on giving, many saying it is a question without an answer. But they pointed out that none of the New England states did well in the rankings and the explanation may be as simple as Yankee frugality. Among its New England neighbors, Connecticut shines, ranking first. Maine comes in last in New England and second to last in the nation in average contributions. New Hampshire ranks 46th, despite having the sixth highest per capita income among states.
"New England is never near the top," Ms. Roberts said.
The experts also point out that the states that rank the highest in average contribution are ones that tend to give to religions.
"If you look at the ones that are in the top five, they are states like Utah with groups that give very heavily to religious institutions in the Bible Belt and the middle of the country," Ms. Roberts said.
Wyoming, Utah, Texas, Tennessee are in the top five, but then there is the quandary of Washington. It finished second to Connecticut in the wealth ranking, having the second-highest per capita income in the nation. But unlike Connecticut, it ranks high in average contribution, also coming in second.
Elizabeth Miller, director of New Ventures at Washington Grantmakers, said that Washington also beats northern Virginia and the Maryland suburbs on average annual contributions.
"I think there's a correlation between giving and volunteering, and in this region, almost everyone volunteers," she said. "Another reason may be that here, giving is sort of the thing to do. I think people feel they need to give back in a region with so much wealth and a tremendous amount of need."
Paul G. Schervish, director of the Social Welfare Research Institute and professor in the Department of Sociology at Boston College, has been studying charitable giving trends for years and said the best explanation of Connecticut's ranking may have nothing to do with generosity.
He said linking giving to income without taking into account comparative figures such as cost of living, the cost of private education and taxes presents an incomplete and unhelpful picture geared toward shaming donors into giving.
"Hidden in a lot of this is, 'How come you're so damn rich and how come you're not giving more?' " he said. "I'm somewhat skeptical about the use of invidious comparisons to generate philanthropy."
That raises other caveats. Ms. Roberts said the numbers used in the rankings only include figures from returns where the taxpayer itemized deductions. So those who maxed-out their contributions or don't itemize are not included. Neither are numbers from family foundations.
That said, the numbers do serve the purpose of painting a relative picture over time, said George Bahamonde, president of the United Way of the Capitol Area in Hartford.
"Whether they're imperfect isn't the issue," Mr. Bahamonde said. "It's that they're consistent. It's the same measurement used five years ago, so you've got a relative measurement you can employ."
The numbers are also two years old. Figures for the 2001 tax year won't be available until next summer and for 2002 the summer after that. Charitable organizations said the weak stock market will have an affect on those figures.
"The economy has had a large impact on our fund-raising," said Brian Otis, director of development for the University of Connecticut School of Business. It's his job to focus on donors considering gifts larger than $500,000, gifts that have been harder to obtain.
"Donors who've made pledges of support with stock have had to give more shares, and that's caused individuals to re-evaluate their pledge schedules," Mr. Otis said.
Ms. Roberts is seeing the same trend. "There is a whole lot more benefit in giving when you have a highly appreciated stock, which a lot of people don't have right now," she said. "We're actually seeing people reneging on their pledges."
Joyce Perrett is the Salvation Army's community relations and development director for southern New England, and she has also found that major donors are giving less in stock gifts than they traditionally do at the end of the year. That makes life harder for the group's local volunteer units, some of which in Connecticut are getting just one-third of what they normally receive from their national organization.
The rest, Ms. Perrett said, must be made up in the holiday kettle drives.
"Places down south, for instance, don't have the same problems with kettles as we do," Ms. Perrett said, noting that it's easier to stand by a kettle in 50-degree weather than in sub-zero degree weather.
Michael R. Bangser is the executive director of the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving, a community foundation that seeks donations for its endowment and which, in turn, awards annual grants within the community. His perspective allows him to see how economic downturns trickle down to the nonprofit sector, he said.
Take, for example, a typical nonprofit with four pots of money for revenue: individuals, foundations and corporations, government grants and contracts, and user fees and earned income.
"Every one of these pots has been hit at the same time," Mr. Bangser said, adding that compounding the problem is that demand for nonprofit services rises when economic times are bad.
It is important to note that individuals give the overwhelming majority -- more than 75 percent -- of gifts in the United States, Mr. Bangser added. "So it's really about individual giving and when you have a bad stock market and a difficult economy, the individual giving also tends to suffer," he said.
Nevertheless, in the experience of Mr. Bahamonde of the United Way, "people this year have continued to give at the same level or higher than they did in the past, even though probably the majority of the firms in the area have freezes in terms of pay increases."
Fred V. Carstensen, a professor of economics at UConn and director of the Connecticut Center for Economic Analysis, said charitable organizations in the state were becoming more aggressive about raising money, which he said is one reason the state's average contribution has risen.
"If people are never asked, or are not asked in a sophisticated way, they're not terribly likely to give," he said. "And I don't think we've been asked a whole lot in Connecticut historically.
"I think the numbers reflect the evolution of our philanthropic institutions," he said. "They're beginning to catch up with the rest of the country."

HEADLINE: A Way With Words, and Numbers, Too 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
SOMEWHERE underneath the folders as thick as phone books and the bulging binders there is a desk where Marc Ryan occasionally sits to crunch numbers. But not this day. On a recent Friday morning, the governor's budget chief was given the task of convincing the unions representing state employees to accept $100 million in contract concessions, a job so finesse-filled that even the normally adroit John G. Rowland stepped away from it.
 But Mr. Ryan shies away from little. Indeed, from his earliest academic career where he was one of a few sixth graders to study Russian to his years in a conservative Washington policy group and a stint writing newspaper editorials, if it's an uphill battle, sign him on. 
 Marc Scott Ryan is 38 and the secretary of the State of Connecticut Office of Policy and Management. O.P.M. is the governor's staff agency and is responsible for all aspects of policy, planning, budgeting and management of state government. Mr. Ryan is specifically in charge of the state's $13.5 billion budget (and its $500 million deficit.) He manages 180 employees. He is probably most recognizable as the person with enough documents tucked under his arm at press conferences to fill a foot-locker. His secretary cum den mother, Linda Buccino, brings him B.L.T.'s from the deli across from his office on Capitol Avenue in Hartford. She describes him as a year-round "workaholic" who spends two weeks in February at the office, literally.
"He sleeps here," she said with a maternal mixture of pride and concern. "He's a night owl."
Forthright is a good adjective to describe Mr. Ryan. Indeed, it is a trait he takes pride in. He is a former editorial writer for the Republican-American, the Waterbury newspaper where his conservative views caught the attention of that city's favorite son, John Rowland. He is self-described "lifelong student of the press," who reads some six newspapers a day. Access to Mr. Ryan is rarely a problem; he is free with his cell-phone number and returns calls, even at 10 at night.
William J. Cibes, the chancellor of the Connecticut State University System, who served as budget chief under Governor Lowell P. Weicker, described such access as a critical part of the job of budget chief.
"Marc is a master of the big picture as well as the details," Mr. Cibes said. "For many citizens, there is not much difference between a million and a billion except the first letter of each world. Marc is able to master -- and not just from the financial side -- an explanation of the budget."
But does preparing the state's budget take a full year?
"Pretty much," Mr. Ryan said with a sigh. "The budget has become all consuming now, particularly with the kind of problems we're having."
These problems include the aforementioned deficit and the fact that the state's $600 million rainy day fund, once considered invulnerable, was drained dry as the stock market plummeted in both 2000 and 2001. In retrospect, Mr. Ryan said the state should have put more into the fund than what the General Assembly required -- 5 percent of the total budget.
Connecticut is one of 45 states in the nation facing a deficit. Its $500 million shortfall is pocket change when compared to California's projected $25 billion. 
Yet Mr. Ryan forecasts doom, saying "This is the worst state fiscal crisis since right after World War II." And to the consternation of some Democrats, he has adamantly refused to exceed the state's spending cap except for one-time payouts.
Mr. Ryan is a native of Albany where his father, a Democratic ward leader, was a county budget chief and school administrator and his mother was a teacher. Mr. Ryan, an ardent Republican, admitted having voted for a Democrat before his conversion but it was Mario Cuomo, a relic of the party, and it was by absentee ballot.
His conversion took place at Georgetown University in the foreign-service school, where he fell under the spell of an unlikely pair: the Rev. Joseph Zrinyi, a Jesuit economics professor, and Ronald Reagan.
"I sort of fell in love with Ronald Reagan and that conservative revolution," he said. Mr. Ryan worked on the Reagan campaign, took courses in Poland as communism was leaching out of Eastern Europe (he speaks Polish and Russian) and worked on the Nicaraguan election of 1990.
Mr. Ryan worked from 1986 to 1990 for a few media and foreign policy think tanks, including Media Watch, a conservative think tank run by a nephew of William F. Buckley. It was in Washington that he honed his economic philosophy and politics.
"I believe in government programs if they're a good investment," he said.
It is a philosophy that pervades his budget, several people said. Senate Majority Leader George C. Jepsen, who was involved with Mr. Ryan through state budgets, described him as "a tough and shrewd negotiator" whose philosophy of anti government spending is unwavering.
"He's very, very bright and knows the budget top to bottom," said Mr. Jepsen, who will become the state Democratic Party Chairman when he steps down from the State Legislature on Jan. 8. "He's also very right wing -- an ideological crusader."
For the past eight years, Mr. Ryan has written a 100-page introduction to the governor's budget that is published each February, when it is presented to the Legislature. For this he squirrels up in his office and spends a seven to 10 days writing. 
Mr. Ryan, who is also a member of the board overseeing Waterbury's fiscal crisis, has worked in the Rowland administration from the beginning first as deputy press director. His talent for numbers and diplomacy skills soon surfaced and he joined the Office of Policy and Management almost eight years ago, rising through the ranks to budget chief.
"He's a sponge," Gov. Rowland said recently. "He can absorb complicated information like no one I've ever seen. The guy is extraordinarily talented. No one can question his capabilities."
Mr. Ryan is equally loyal to the Governor. "This guy has done more for me than you could ever imagine," he said. "He really made my career. I would never leave him in a crunch. It's just not the right thing to do."
About a year ago, Mr. Ryan moved his family from Waterbury to Haddam. He met his wife, the former Donna Breslin, at a Halloween party in his Washington days. (She was dressed as a bumblebee and he was the only guest not in costume.) They have three elementary school-aged children and their new house, he admits with a sheepish grin, was a bit of a financial stretch.
Mr. Ryan goes to his children's swim meets and devotes his weekend to family life (when not in negotiations). He is also a committed traveler, who takes a solo trip to Poland each year to "do some democracy building and free market building," and burnish his interest in the politics of the region. He also collects wine and model elephants of all varieties, "from the dollar store to the very, very expensive," including elephants pictured on ancient Greek and Roman coins.
He has had job offers from health care, entertainment and defense industries. He has assured his staff that he had no plans to leave. Yet he admits his future might be far from Connecticut, possibly developing free markets in Eastern Europe. With the state facing layoffs and a deficit expected to triple in 2003, is he in any hurry to go?
"No," he said, "I really think you make your mark as a budget director not in good times but in bad ones."
