HEADLINE: Full Lives, Captured In Memory And Words 

BYLINE:  By Dick Ahles 

 BODY:
IN times past, tombstones often told the story of a life. 
This example comes from the book "Churchyard Literature," published in 1877:
 "Samuel Bishop, town clerk of New Haven, 54 years; its representative at 54 sessions of the general assembly, judge of the county and probate courts; died mayor of the city, and collector of the port, 7 August, 1803, aged 80." 
 And from a Litchfield cemetery come these words:
"Here lies the body of Mrs. Mary, wife of Deacon John Buel, Esq. She died Nov. 4, 1768, aged 90 -- having had 13 Children, 101 Grand-Children, 247 Great-Grand-Children, and 49 Great-Great-Grand-Children; total 410. 
Three Hundred and Thirty-six survived her."
But fashions change in death, as in life, and the inscriptions on gravestones today are much less likely to venture beyond the basics: name, date of birth, date of death. 
Yet for each life, the stories remain to be told, the memories recounted. At the end of each year, the Connecticut section tries to do just that, publishing a collection of obituaries about people who made a difference in the state. These vignettes, of those who died in the year 2002, were written by Dick Ahles.

A Familiar Voice
Bob Steele was on the radio for 66 years. He was hired by station WTIC in Hartford in 1936, shortly after coming to the city from California to announce motorcycle races at Bulkeley Stadium.
When the racing season ended, he applied for a job at the radio station, went through a rigorous audition and was hired for $35 a week.
Mr. Steele retired from daily broadcasting 55 years later, but continued to do his morning show on the first Saturday of each month in the spring, summer and fall. He broadcast his final program on Nov 2. 
Mr. Steele's morning show, which had a 48-year run on WTIC, was unlike any other. It was a leisurely paced, tightly formatted program with every segment and even the most minor features broadcast precisely at the same moment every day.
"When people listened to Bob, with the same things happening at the same time every morning, they got a sense that their morning was under control," said Arnold Dean, an associate of Mr. Steele for 37 years.
For many years, Mr. Steele had higher ratings than any other local broadcast in the United States. His plaque in the Radio Hall of Fame in Chicago says he broadcast to half a million people every day.
Mr. Steele sprinkled the show with corny jokes, the pronunciation of a word for the day, birthdays of listeners 80 and older, temperatures from other places, little stories of little significance he called "tiddlywinks" and music mostly from the 1920's to the big band era of the 1930's and 1940's. Listeners might hear Sir Harry Lauder singing "Roamin' in the Gloamin" from time to time and a march on Saturdays, but they would never hear rock 'n' roll.
On Fridays, Mr. Steele would announce his weight, in pounds and ounces and hardly a week went by without him reminding listeners of the proper way to prepare scrambled eggs. (You had to add a teaspoon of cottage cheese.)
He was known for predicting the outcome of sporting events, usually incorrectly. In the 1960's, when Mr. Steele dropped his evening sportscast, WTIC announced that he would continue to make sports predictions "as a public service."
As the host of the most listened to morning radio show in southern New England, Mr. Steele was the person families turned to during snowstorms to hear if the schools were being closed.
Mr. Steele died in his Wethersfield home on Dec. 6. He was 91. 
For several days after his death, WTIC received calls from hundreds of listeners who wanted to reminisce. One caller, after waiting on hold for an hour, said, "I was afraid I'd have to shave again."
That was Bob Steele's kind of joke.

A Major Contributor
For Samuel Birnbaum, the honorary degree he received from the University of Connecticut at age 84 was especially meaningful because his formal education had ended when he was 7 years old.
Sy Birnbaum left school in 1916 to help out in his father's little clothing store in New Britain.
He and his sister Ida took over the store when their father died in 1932 and did extremely well, so well that the Birnbaum family became major benefactors of New Britain General Hospital and the University of Connecticut's Health Center.
Mr. Birnbaum was awarded an honorary doctorate of humane letters in 1993 in appreciation for his family's million-dollar contribution to advance treatment and research in the health center's psychiatry department.
He was also generous to New Britain General Hospital, establishing several scholarships at its school of nursing. In 1987, the hospital's emergency room was dedicated to him.
Mr. Birnbaum also supported the Central Connecticut Association for Retarded Children, New Britain Memorial Hospital, Resurrection House and the Jewish Association for Community Living in Hartford.
In 1991, Town and Country magazine included Mr. Birnbaum in its annual listing of major contributors to art, science, scholarship and the humanities.
Mr. Birnbaum died March 21. He was 93.

Striving to Educate
When Alvin Wood graduated from Howard University in the 1930's, he tried to get a job as a teacher in Hartford, but Fred D. Wish, the superintendent of schools, told him Hartford was not ready for a black school teacher and he went to work as a janitor at Aetna.
Three decades later, Alvin Wood became the principal of the Fred D. Wish Elementary School. He never commented on the incongruity of that appointment until his retirement party in 1978.
Hartford was finally ready to hire Mr. Wood as a teacher in 1954 and nine years later Mr. Wood became principal of the Clark Elementary School. In 1964, he moved to the Wish School, remaining there until he retired.
His contributions to public education were not limited to Hartford. Mr. Wood was a member of the board of trustees of the State University System for many years and its vice chairman for a decade.
Mr. Wood was born in Hartford and grew up in Bloomfield. Years later he became the town's first black councilman.
Mr. Wood died Jan. 11. He was 92.

Spy, Translator, Teacher
Before she was 21, Irene Szeliga had run afoul of two totalitarian regimes.
The granddaughter of an adviser to Czar Nicholas II, she was born in Kiev, Russia, to an officer in the czar's army and a Polish mother.
The family fled from the communists soon after Irene's birth and settled in Poznan, Poland, where she was studying to become a banker when the Nazis invaded the country in 1939.
A camp for prisoners was established in Poznan, and Irene and other young Polish women secretly made visits there to gather information from British prisoners for the Polish underground and British intelligence.
At one point, according to her son, George Szeliga of New Britain, she smuggled a camera into the camp so that prisoners could photograph construction sites where they were forced to work.
Her activities were disclosed to the Nazis by an underground member who had been captured and tortured and she and a sister were sent to a concentration camp in Germany. Her sister died in the camp and a brother was captured and shot.
After the Russians pushed the Germans out of Poland, Ms. Szeliga became a translator for the Russian army, and after the war, she used her ability to speak Polish, Russian, French and English to write subtitles for foreign movies.
Among the films she worked on was Gary Cooper's classic western "High Noon," translating the lyric, "Do not forsake me, oh my darling, on this, our wedding day" into Polish. She also wrote short stories, a play and a novel, all dealing with her wartime experiences.
She married briefly and gave birth to a son before they left Poland in 1962 for Connecticut where she had relatives. 
Shetaught Russian at Wesleyan University from 1965 to 1973 and at Trinity College from 1975 to 1979. She also taught at the University of Hartford and at Indiana University.
Ms. Szeliga died March 10. She was 84.

Promoter of Medicare
You could call Stewart Hamilton Medicare's first doctor.
Dr. Hamilton was president and executive director of Hartford Hospital from 1954 to 1976 and president of the American Hospital Association in the 1960's when Medicare was being debated in Congress.
His testimony was credited with helping the legislation's passage and he was present in the Oval Office when the Medicare bill was signed into law by President Lyndon B. Johnson. It was no coincidence that the nation's first Medicare reimbursement check was issued to Hartford Hospital in 1966.
The son of a physician who headed Detroit's Harper Hospital, Dr. Hamilton was educated at Williams College and the Harvard and Wayne State University Schools of Medicine. While at Harvard, he met and married his wife of more than 65 years, Amy Washburn, the daughter of a physician.
After two years as a general practitioner on Cape Cod, Dr. Hamilton turned to hospital administration and became assistant director of Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. 
In 1942, Lt. Col. Hamilton was appointed head of the Mass General hospital unit that would be stationed first in Casablanca and then in Rome during World War II. After the war, he ran Newton Wellesley Hospital in Massachusetts before coming to Hartford. 
In 1961, a fire that started in one of Hartford Hospital's trash chutes killed 16 people. Reforms put in place by Dr. Hamilton as a result of the fire, including the elimination of trash chutes, became a model for the nation's hospitals. 
Although he retired from Hartford Hospital in 1976, Dr. Hamilton remained active in medicine for another decade, first as interim director of the John Dempsey Hospital and the University of Connecticut Health Center and later, as a member of its faculty.
Dr. Hamilton died July 29. He was 91.

A Priest, in War and Peace
Msgr. John Wodarski liked to tell about a visit that Cardinal Karol Wojtyla, the future Pope John Paul II, made to the monsignor's large Polish American congregation at Holy Cross Church in New Britain in 1969.
One of the friends that the Polish cardinal made during that visit was Monsignor Wodarski's elderly mother whom he kissed on the cheek. Years later, Monsignor Wodarski was in the Vatican with a large group of clergy and lay people for an audience with the Pope. As John Paul entered the room, he spotted the monsignor in the sea of black clad pilgrims and called out, "How's your mother?"
John Wodarski was a priest for 71 years, a monsignor for 45 and pastor of Holy Cross for more than 30 years. He trained for the priesthood at St. Thomas Seminary in Bloomfield, St. Mary College in Michigan and the University of Fribourg in Switzerland where he was ordained in 1931. 
After serving as an assistant pastor in Bristol, Willimantic and Putnam, Father Wodarski joined the army in 1944 and become a chaplain with the 20th Armored Division. He was awarded the Bronze Star after combat in and around Munich, Germany and helped to liberate the Dachau concentration camp in April 1945. Among the camp's 33,000 inmates, Father Wodarski found 700 Polish priests whom he organized to provide physical and spiritual aid to thousands of Polish slave laborers in the region. 
After the war, Father Wodarski was director of youth for the Hartford Archdiocese and for many yeras, he ran the Archdiocesan Office of Radio and Television. He became pastor of Holy Cross in 1961 and held that post until his retirement in 1989.
Monsignor Wodarski died Oct. 12, the day before Holy Cross Church would observe the 75th anniversary of its founding. He was 97.

Charitable Through Golf
When only about 50 people showed up for the Greater Hartford Jaycees' Turtle Derby in 1951, the Jaycees conceded they had to find a better way to raise money for charity.
Thinking golf might be more profitable than tortoises, one Jaycee, Ed May Jr., invited the United States Open champion Ben Hogan to play an exhibition round in Hartford.
After Mr. Hogan declined, Mr. May and two associates decided to organize a tournament. The Professional Golfers Association liked the idea, offering Labor Day weekend in 1952 if the Jaycees could come up with a good golf course and a purse of $15,000.
The Wethersfield Country Club offered its course and Mr. May was named the tournament's co-chairman and given the responsibility of raising the purse. With his co-chairman, Harry Keefe Jr., he persuaded the city's insurance companies to provide seed money. The Insurance City Open was a success from the start.
Four years later, Mr. May was elected to Congress from Connecticut's First District, thanks to President Eisenhower's second-term landslide victory. But Mr. May was defeated two years later by Mim Daddario, a fellow Wesleyan alumnus. No Republican has represented the Hartford area district since then.
Mr. May, an insurance executive, was a founder of the company of May, Potter and Murphy Inc., which later merged with the insurance brokerage company Alexander & Alexander. Mr. May was the chairman when he retired in 1984.
Ed May was in the gallery when the golf tournament was played for the 50th time in the summer of 2001. Now known as the Greater Hartford Open, the purse has grown to $4 million in 2002.
Mr. May died Feb. 20. He was 77.

Presidential Presence
At a time when it was said a woman's place was in the home, Percy Maxim Lee had a place on prestigious national boards and commissions as the appointee of three presidents of the United States. 
She was also president of the Connecticut and United States League of Women Voters and a member of several key state commissions,
Ms. Lee was the daughter and granddaughter of inventors. Her grandfather, Sir Hiram S. Maxim, was the inventor of the machine gun that bears his name and her father, Hiram Percy Maxim, invented the Maxim gun silencer and the first electric car manufactured by the Pope-Hartford Automobile Company. Her father was also a ham-radio pioneer and founder of the American Radio Relay League.
Ms. Lee joined the League of Women Voters as a young wife and mother living in Farmington. She was the wife of the late John G. Lee, who would become director of research of United Aircraft, the corporation that became United Technologies, and a founder of the University of Hartford.
During World War II, about the time Ms. Lee became involved with the League, the Lees provided a home for the children of two Oxford University professors and a family of three that had escaped from Nazi Germany.
After being elected president of the Farmington League of Women Voters, Mrs. Lee became president of the Connecticut League in 1941 and the United States League in 1950, serving four terms until 1958.
In 1954, President Eisenhower named Ms. Lee liason between the public and the government's Foreign Operations Administration. President Kennedy appointed her to the Consumer Advisory Council in 1962 and President Johnson named her chairman of the Council and also appointed her to the Public Land Law Review Commission.
Governor John Dempsey appointed Ms. Lee to the Connecticut Permanent Commission on the Status of Women and the Clean Water Task Force. Gov.Ella Grasso chose her for the Judicial Review Council and she also served as president of the Farmington River Watershed Association and was a founder of the Farmington Land Trust.
Ms. Lee was also a founder of the Junior School, now the Renbrook School in West Hartford, a trustee of the Putney School in Vermont and a longtime vice chairman of the trustees of Connecticut College in New London. 
Ms. Lee died Nov. 9. She was 96.

A Manchester Dynasty
Jacob Cheney was "the last of the dynasty that built Manchester," according to a former mayor, Nathan Agostinelli.
The dynasty was founded in the 1830's by the eight Cheney brothers, who built a silk mill hat grew into the largest silk manufacturing company in the United States.
Jacob was the last Cheney to work in the family business, which left Manchester in the 1950's, part of the southern exodus of mills from eastern Connecticut.
At its peak, the Cheney Brothers Silk Mills employed 5,000 workers, many of whom lived in Cheneyville, the company's model community in South Manchester, which had a school, churches, country club, library, community hall, theater, firehouse and Victorian homes employees could rent.
Jake Cheney remained in Manchester after the company's dissolution and became a fixture on Main Street. In 1998, Mayor Agostinelli made Mr. Cheney an honorary marshal for the town's 175th birthday parade.
"He got all dressed up and he was so proud," Mr. Agostinelli said. "I think it was the highlight of his life."
Mr. Cheney was also known for his pencil sketches of the people who worked on Main Street, merchants, waitresses and others who treasured the pictures he made and presented to them.
Mr. Cheney died April 3. He was 92.

A Man About Town
They thought so highly of Frank Smith in Winsted, that the town once held a parade in his honor.
Mr. Smith was born in Winsted and lived there all his life. During that time, he was a fire chief, a selectman, president of the Winsted Historical Society and a head coach in the Midget Football League.
He was also a member of the zoning board of appeals, the water and sewer commission and the housing authority. When he was not doing something for Winsted, he operated his own construction company.
"His whole life was the community," said John Arcelaschi, a former mayor. "He was a no-nonsense man who said what he had to say."
Last year, the town dedicated its annual firefighter's parade to Mr. Smith and the housing authority named its literacy room in the Beardsley and Memorial Library for him.
Mr. Smith died Feb. 14. He was 67. 

Early Spotlight
Diane Nappier had her picture in the paper when she was only a day old. She merited the news coverage because on June 16, 1951 she and sisters Denise and Donna became the first triplets born in Hartford's Mount Sinai Hospital.
Diane would become an amateur tennis champion and a physical education teacher and coach at Suffield High School. Denise would be elected and re-elected Connecticut state treasurer and Donna would become deputy director of the Hartford Housing Authority.
Diane Nappier was first diagnosed with symptoms of leukemia seven years ago, but the disease went into remission after she received a bone marrow transplant from Denise and she was well enough to run in her first marathon 18 months later.
"My goal was not to walk," Ms. Nappier told friends. In October 1996, she finished the Greater Hartford Marathon in 4 hours 35 minutes 19 seconds.
Ms. Nappier regained her health after the transplant but a few years ago, she was told she had acute leukemia and received a second bone marrow transplant, this time from Donna. In July, Ms. Nappier was able to join family and friends in Hartford's Elizabeth Park to hear Denise Nappier announce her candidacy for re-election as state treasurer.
Ms. Nappier died Sept. 6. She was 51.

A Planner and a Prodigy
Henry Nozko Sr. was known to most Connecticut people for the television commercials he did with his son, Henry Jr., that appeared every Sunday on "60 Minutes" on behalf of Acmat, their building construction company.
The Nozkos's corporation, based in New Britain, has constructed building interiors throughout the United States, and the father and son reminded viewers every week that their interiors provided customers "more for less and on time."
One of Acmat's best-known projects was the interior of the John Hancock Building in Boston. The company also converted West Hartford's former Hall High School into the present Town Hall.
Mr. Nozko was first known as a piano prodigy, performing with the Boston Pops at age 9. During the 1930's, as a teenager, Mr. Nozko played with some of the country's major dance bands but he stopped when he married at 18.
In 1950, he founded the Acoustical Materials Company in a garage in Hartford's North End. The company grew into Acmat, whose elegant interiors produced gross revenues of $40 million by the 1980's. In the mid-1980's, the company faced bankruptcy after the cancellation of its liability insurance for removing asbestos.
Undaunted, Mr. Nozko sued the insurer and formed his own insurance company, Coastal Insurance Company. Acmat survived and thrived.
Mr. Nozko died Jan. 13. He was 82.

From Acting to Priesthood
The Rev. Robert McQueeney was a husband and a father before he became a Roman Catholic priest 20 years ago. He was also a decorated combat veteran of World War II, a stage, movie and television actor and a golf pro.
Father McQueeney was ordained at age 63 after studying for the priesthood at Holy Apostles Seminary in Cromwell, one of only three seminaries in the United States that offers older men an opportunity to become priests.
Father McQueeney, a Bridgeport native, was a student at Columbia University when Pearl Harbor was attacked in 1941. He enlisted in the Army and served in the Pacific as an officer in an Engineer battalion.
After the war, he studied acting at the American Theater Wing and appeared on Broadway and in national tours of Helen Hayes's production of "Macbeth," in "Dial M for Murder" with Maurice Evans and in "Rain" with June Havoc.
In the early 1950's, he began a long career as a television actor, performing in such pioneering dramatic series as "Studio One" and popular programs like "Bonanza," "77 Sunset Strip," "Gunsmoke," "Perry Mason," "Wagon Train," "Marcus Welby" and many other shows. He also acted in soap operas and in several movies.
Acting was not always a lucrative profession, according to Father McQueeney's daughter, Kathleen Reynolds of Calabasas, Calif. "But he was a terrific golfer and for many years, he worked as a teaching pro between acting jobs," Ms. Reynolds said.
Father McQueeney decided to become a priest after the death of his wife, returning to Connecticut to study at Holy Apostles.
Father McQueeney died April 24. He was 83.

Tuskegee Mission
As the pilot of a P-51 Mustang fighter in World War II, Bertram Wilson shot down four Nazi fighters and received the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Medal with two oak leaf clusters and the Bronze Star.
But despite his courage and skill as a fighter pilot and the lieutenant's bars he wore, there were enlisted men who refused to salute Mr. Wilson, a black officer in a segregated Army Air Corps.
He flew with one of World War II's most illustrious fighting units, the 332nd Fighter Group, better known as the "Tuskegee Airmen" for the town in Alabama where they were trained before being sent to North Africa.
Initially, the Tuskegee airmen had to deal with commanders who doubted their ability. They were given the chance to escort bombers on raids over enemy territory only after other escort squadrons had lost several bombers. The Tuskegee group, commanded by Col. Benjamin O. Davis Jr., did not lose a single bomber to enemy fighters. 
Mr. Wilson left the Army at the end of World War II but re-enlisted in the Air Force during the Korean War and served until his retirement in 1968. During his final years in the Air Force, Mr. Wilson, by then a lieutenant colonel, flew combat missions in Phantom jets over North Vietnam.
After his military service ended, Mr. Wilson was director of personnel at the University of Connecticut until he retired in 1979. After that, he served for nearly a decade as affirmative action officer for the State Department of Education.
In an interview two years ago, Mr. Wilson recalled the racism he experienced while serving his country in World War II.
"You were very much aware of the fact that in the States, you couldn't go into a bar and have a drink," he said. "You couldn't go into the officers' club, yet you still had your bars and wings like anybody else. We were very much aware of that, but what was the alternative? Your country is still your country."
Mr. Wilson died July 9 when he drowned in his pool at his home in Ashford. He was 80.
On Aug. 6, he was buried with full military honors in Arlington National Cemetery.

Political Timing
John Gerardo liked to say that he became the Republican candidate for lieutenant governor of Connecticut in 1966 because he just happened to be in the building -- Hartford's Bushnell Memorial Hall -- when party leaders were looking for a running mate for E. Clayton Gengras.
The Gengras-Gerardo ticket lost to the incumbent governor, John Dempsey, and Mr. Gerardo returned to his home town of Torrington and the law practice he had established there after serving in the Army Air Corps in World War II.
Mr. Gerardo had first become involved in Republican party politics as a young man in Torrington and in the early 1950's, Gov. John Lodge, a Republican, made him a city court judge. 
In 1957, he was named clerk of the State House of Representatives and later became clerk of the Senate. His considerable knowledge of House and Senate rules also made Mr. Gerardo the unofficial parliamentarian of the General Assembly. He became the person both parties respected and relied upon to settle squabbles over rules and procedures.
In 1965, he was named clerk of the history-making Constitutional Convention that rewrote the state's 1818 Constitution and reapportioned the House and Senate. It was Mr. Gerardo's effective service to the Republican party and the state as the clerk of both Houses and the Constitutional Convention that led to his nomination as lieutenant governor, not his happening to be in the right hall at the right time.
Mr. Gerardo died Feb. 7. He was 80.

Big-League Credentials
Francis (Spec) Shea was just out of the Army and playing a little semipro baseball in Waterbury when the New York Yankees came to town for an exhibition game against his team in 1946.
The 25-year-old pitcher from nearby Naugatuck made a good first impression by shutting out the Yankees for eight innings. That feat earned him a Yankee contract.
After just a year in the minors, playing in the Pacific Coast League for Casey Stengel, Mr. Shea was called up to the Yankees where he more than lived up to the promise he had shown in that Waterbury exhibition game.
In his first year, Mr. Shea won 14 games and lost 5. He had a 3.07 earned run average, was the winning pitcher for the American League in the 1947 All-Star Game and helped the Yankees win the American League pennant for the first time since 1943.
During that season, Mr. Shea, known as Spec all his life because of his freckles, was given a second nickname, the Naugatuck Nugget, by the Yankees' legendary radio announcer, Mel Allen. 
The Yankees played the Brooklyn Dodgers in the 1947 World Series. The team's manager, Bucky Harris, picked Mr. Shea to start the first game at Yankee Stadium and he beat a Dodgers team that included two future Hall of Famers, Jackie Robinson and PeeWee Reese. The score was 5 to 3.
Two days after his 27th birthday, Mr. Shea faced the Dodgers again in Game 5 at Ebbets Field. He won, 2-1, and drove in a run.
Mr. Shea volunteered to start the seventh and final game after only two days' rest but he was taken out in the second inning of a game the Yankees eventually won to take the Series.
In that era, only one rookie of the year award was given for both leagues and Jackie Robinson was the winner. But if they had an award for each league, as they do now, the Naugatuck Nugget would have received the American League award. He was second only to Mr. Robinson in the voting.
Mr. Shea would play seven more seasons, three with the Yankees and four as a Washington Senator, but a chronic neck injury prevented him from pitching as well as he did in 1947. He retired in 1955 at age 34 with a 56-46 career record and a career 3.80 e.r.a. Mr. Shea returned home after his career ended and became Naugatuck's director of parks and recreation. In 1983, he coached Robert Redford in the movie, "The Natural." He retired in 1989.
Mr. Shea died July 19. He was 81.

Spreading Good Cheer
Walter Suchodolski devoted his professional life to education and the Christmas season to being Santa Claus. For more than 30 years, Mr. Suchodolski was a teacher, coach, principal and administrator in the Stratford, Rocky Hill and Hartford public schools. 
After his retirement in 1977, Mr. Suchodolski, the possessor of an impressive and authentic white beard, became a department store Santa Claus. His site was the big downtown Hartford store, G. Fox & Company. There, the educator turned Santa could not resist imparting a lesson or two.
In an interview with The Wethersfield Post in 1988, Mr. Suchodolski explained how he would discuss things like finger painting with the younger children but "with the older ones, I comment on how tall they've grown since the last time. I ask how they are doing in school and we discuss fractions, addition and subtraction."
Mr. Suchodolski was Santa until G. Fox ended its 145-year run on Main Street and closed in 1992. Thereafter, he only donned his red suit for family parties and for the annual Christmas party for Hartford children at Cigna in Bloomfield. He did, however, continue to drive a car bearing a license plate that read "SANTA."
An honor graduate of New Britain State Teachers College, now Central Connecticut State University, Mr. Suchodolski was a star athlete in football, basketball and baseball. In 1996, he was inducted into the university's Sports Hall of Fame.
Mr. Suchodolski began teaching in Stratford, then moved to Rocky Hill where he spent 25 years as a teacher, coach and principal. In 1969, he became a special education supervisor in the Hartford schools.
Mr. Suchodolski was also a high school football referee for nearly 50 years, serving as time keeper when old age prevented him from taking a more active role in officiating. 
Mr. Suchodolski died April 13. He was 85.

'Go-to Guy' for Navy
When the first Seawolf submarines were being built at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, cracks developed in the welding of the special high-strength steel so the company and the Navy turned to Warren Mayott and, as expected, Mr. Mayott quickly solved the problem.
Mr. Mayott, Electric Boat's director of technical services, was considered one of the premier welding engineers and metallurgists in the country.
The company president, Michael W. Toner, said that during Mr. Mayott's more than 40 years at the shipyard, "the Navy wanted to hear what Warren had to say before they went forward with any recommendation. He became, over the years, the real 'go-to guy' for materials and metals joining."
Mr. Mayott was credited with developing the ultra-sonic testing of welds, which could be done while a ship was under construction. This procedure replaced the use of X-rays, a major improvement since construction to be halted because of Xrays radiation.
When the Trident and Los Angeles classes of submarines were being built, Mr. Mayott came up with a new, controlled welding program that reduced rejection rates for welded materials from 17 to 1 percent. 
"When Warren said, 'This is the answer,' " said John F. Shipway, the Electric Boat's vice president for full submarine support, "without exception, that was the path we always took. The fact that we have used the strongest steel in the world in our submarines in a cost-effective fashion is because of what Warren did for our Navy and our nation." 
Mr. Mayott, who had cancer, died Jan. 5. He was 62. 

Following a Cause
Carol Kimball was an environmentalist and naturalist, a writer and a fund-raiser for a variety of causes.
As a fund-raiser, Ms. Kimball held development positions at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Columbia University, the Metropolitan Opera, the Environmental Defense Fund and the Connecticut Chapter of the Nature Conservancy.
As an environmentalist, she was a contributing author to the recently published "Tidelands of the Connecticut River: A Guide to Its Hidden Coves and Tributaries" and a frequent contributor on environmental issues to local newspapers.
She served as a docent at Connecticut College and was a director of the Lyme Land Conservation Trust.
Ms. Kimball also had a major role in merging her alma mater, Abbot Academy, with Phillips Academy Andover, a boys' prep school, in the 1970's. In 1974, she became the first woman on the Andover board of trustees.
Ms. Kimball died June 2. She was 67.

Perpetual Candidate
Louis Marietta ran for a lot of political offices but never won an election. That never mattered to him; it was the opportunity to campaign that he valued.
As a native and lifetime resident of New Britain, Mr. Marietta occasionally ran for mayor of the city, but he also once ran for mayor of Bristol as well.
As a candidate, Mr. Marietta was known for his use of a bullhorn to proclaim his often colorful and sometimes extraordinary positions. He once advocated televised executions and the use of an "electric sofa" to execute more than one criminal at a time.
Sometimes given less attention by the news media than he considered his due, Mr. Marietta engaged in a long feud with local television stations that declined to invite him to take part in debates when he ran for Congress on several occasions.
In his 1988 race against Congresswoman Nancy Johnson, Mr. Marietta threatened in a radio interview to hold the Congresswoman's staff hostage until he was included in a television debate between the major party candidates.
He later apologized and, as a way of making amends, said if Ms. Johnson ever needed blood, "I'd be the first to give it to her."
Mr. Marietta's last race was in 2000 against State Senator Thomas Bozek of New Britain, who has defeated Mr. Marietta in more elections than either of them could remember. Mr. Marietta rarely attracted more than a few hundred voters, getting, for example, 239 votes to Mr. Bozek's 12,143 in one contest in the 1990's.
Mr. Bozek had no hard feelings.
"He always had the best interests of the city at heart and was one of New Britain's institutions and an interesting character," Mr. Bozek said. "Maybe he didn't always make people happy, but he knew the issues and always had an opinion."
When not running for office, Mr. Marietta worked for many years as a laborer in the New Britain Water Department. A lifelong bachelor, his great love was politics, said Rose Kozuch of Kensington, a half-sister.
Mr. Marietta died May 18 of injuries he sustained in an auto accident in February. He was 81.

A Presence on the Court
Beatrice Healey Whaples was the captain of the University of Connecticut's women's basketball team in 1928, the year she received her degree in home economics and many decades before UConn women's basketball became a state passion.
Ms. Whaples lived much of her life near the UConn campus in Storrs, but she was also something of a world traveler, accompanying her husband, Randolph, to Sri Lanka, Cyprus and Uganda where he served with the United States Agency for International Development. 
Ms. Whaples died April 3. She was 96.

Filling the Air Waves
Tom Eaton began his career in news as a newspaper typesetter while in college. After college, Mr. Eaton joined Transradio Press, an early radio news service, and became news director of WTIC, Connecticut's only 50,000-watt radio station, in 1941 at age 24.
When WTIC was granted a television license for Channel 3 in 1957, Mr. Eaton was appointed news director of WTIC-TV as well. He ran both the radio and television news departments until the early 1970's.
Mr. Eaton was both a news manager and broadcaster, serving as the stations' principal political reporter and moderator of many radio and television interview programs.
He anchored live radio and television coverage of state political conventions, elections and state of the state addresses by every governor from Raymond Baldwin in the 1940's to Ella Grasso in the 1970's.
After his retirement, he was a broadcast consultant and put new television stations on the air in Virginia and Florida.
Mr. Eaton played a prominent role in broadcast journalism nationally, and in 1946 he was one of the founders of the industry's professional society, the Radio News Directors Association, now the Radio and Television News Directors Association.
Mr. Eaton died Oct. 16. He was 86.

Assisting the War Effort
Early in World War II, there was concern that some German fighter planes were faster than their American counterparts. That changed when Robert Murphy of the Wiremold Company in West Hartford came up with a carburetor adjustment that gave most American fighters an edge in speed, according to information in Wiremold's corporate archives.
Wiremold was founded by Mr. Murphy's father, D. Hayes Murphy, in 1900 and sold by the Murphy family a century later. Mr. Murphy and his brother John worked together at Wiremold for more than 60 years.
According to the Murphy family, Robert was the inside man and problem solver who ran the factory, while John was the outside man, handling sales and the office staff. 
Robert Murphy held 11 patents. He saw to it that Wiremold was among the first companies to adapt computers to business use, starting with the huge I.B.M. computers of the 1950's. He was also especially concerned about worker safety and developed procedures to cut accidents in metal stamping and other dangerous activities.
Under the Murphy brothers, Wiremold became one of the first businesses to adopt a profit-sharing plan and Mr. Murphy was said to have been proud of the company's productive relationship with the union that represented its factory workers.
Mr. Murphy died July 26. He was 87.

A Show of College Spirit
Hugh Campbell was the kind of alumnus that colleges cherish.
Mr. Campbell, a Hartford native, received all of his education in the city, graduating from Hartford Public High School, Trinity College and the Hartford College of Law.
He went to work for Phoenix Mutual in Hartford after law school and spent 40 years there, rising to vice president and head of the legal department before retiring in 1973.
After that, Mr. Campbell joined the Hartford law firm of Murtha, Cullina, Richter and Pinney. He was a leader in the insurance industry's bar, serving as chairman of the legal section of the American Life Convention and president of the Association of Life Insurance Counsel.
Mr. Campbell also found time for his alma mater, Trinity, where he was a member of Alpha Chi Rho and president for many years of the academic fraternity Phi Beta Kappa. He was a Trinity trustee for two terms and the national president of the Trinity College Alumni Association.
In 1957, the college awarded him its alumni medal and in 1976, he received its highest alumni honor, the Eigenbrodt Trophy.
Mr. Campbell also contributed to the greater Hartford community. He was a trustee of the Wadsworth Atheneum and a two-term president of its board. During his years as a trustee and president, the museum added 15 galleries, a conservator's studio, a library and offices for a curator and other administrators.
At the Hartford Public Library, he helped to build the Hartford Collection, which included books, monographs, old city records, pictures and other materials about the city. As a member of the Wethersfield board of finance in the 1950's, he was part of a group of community leaders who replaced Wethersfield's selectmen-town meeting form of government with a town manager.
Mr. Campbell died April 2. He was 91.

World of Fashion and Art
Lynne Lofting Mutrux first worked as a fashion magazine photographer and then as a designer of women's clothing for one of the nation's leading design houses. She later became an art educator and the author of children's books.
Ms. Mutrux was the daughter of Hugh Lofting, who wrote children's books about the Dr. Dolittle who could talk to the animals.
After studying art in Vienna, Ms. Mutrux worked as a photographer for Glamour magazine before joining the famous dress designer Lilly Dache. During her association with Ms. Dache, Ms. Mutrux designed dresses for the actresses Helen Hayes and Rosalind Russell.
In 1959, Ms. Mutrux began a third career as a teacher of art history at the Miss Thomas School for Girls in Rowayton and also served as the school's assistant headmistress. She taught art history at Fairfield University in the 1970's and contributed her extensive collection of art and architecture slides, known as the Mutrux Visual Resource Collection, to Fairfield. While teaching, she also wrote short stories and books for children. 
Ms. Mutrux died Aug. 4. She was 88.

Creating a Living Center
Frank Vilardi Jr. was a computer programmer who became a social worker after contracting AIDS.
Mr. Vilardi, who learned that he had AIDS 14 years ago, was the co-founder of the Living Center for those with AIDS in the Hartford area.
At the Living Center, AIDS patients could receive everything from food to the latest information on advances in the treatment of the disease.
"He wanted to help people," said Virginia Kriedel, a friend. "Even when he had AIDS and was fighting the battle, he still wanted to help people."
Paul Botticello, executive director of AIDS Project Hartford, called Mr. Vilardi "the heart and soul for the HIV-AIDS work done since the 1980's."
Mr. Vilardi died Jan. 25. He was 58.

A Way With News
When 20-year-old Melva Swartz was hired by The Hartford Courant after graduating from Colby Junior College in 1931, the few women employed there as reporters were assigned to the society section.
But the managing editor, John Reitmeyer, thought Ms. Swartz could do more so he assigned her to write obituaries, a job previously assigned to men.
She quickly moved on to other city desk duties and covered some of Hartford's big trials in the 1930's.
During the 1938 flood that left most of Hartford without electric power for days, she and her colleagues worked in the city room by candlelight so that The Courant could maintain its more than a century-old record of never having missed a day of publication.
In 1941, Miss Swartz married a Courant sportswriter, Bill Lee, and left journalism to devote her time to being Mrs. Lee and the mother of their four children.
She died Feb. 26. She was 90.

'Mr. Foundation'
Last August, an S.U.V. crashed head-on into the oldest home in Hartford, the 220-year-old Butler-McCook House. The vehicle came to a stop in the south parlor, causing severe damage to the recently restored building and its furnishings.
A few weeks later, Bill Hosley, the executive director of the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society, which owns the house, received a call from John M. K. Davis.
"I can see you need help," Mr. Davis told Mr. Hosley, who added that he pledged one-quarter of the funds raised to date for the McCook House restoration.
There were many similar stories about Mr. Davis, whose long association with one of the city's leading philanthropies, the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving, caused him to be known as "Mr. Foundation."
Mr. Davis was a member of one of Hartford's founding families. He was descended from Thomas Lord, who came to Hartford in 1636 with the settlement's founder, Thomas Hooker. He was also descended from the Rev. Peter Bulkeley, the founder of Concord, Ma.; Theophilus Eaton, the first governor of the New Haven Colony; and Morgan Bulkeley, a governor and United States Senator.
Mr. Davis, a graduate of the Kent School and Yale, was associated with Case, Lockwood & Brainard Company, which later became Connecticut Printers Inc. for 43 years. He served as its president from 1952 to 1973, but was best known in the community for his civic and charitable activities.
He was a Hartford alderman in the 1930's, president of the Connecticut Historical Society and Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce and a director of the Wadsworth Atheneum, the Connecticut Historical Society and the Old State House Association.
James English, a former president of Trinity College and a longtime associate of Mr. Davis at the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving, said Mr. Davis was "a very courteous, old-school kind of man, but on the other hand, he had a lively social conscience."
Mr. Davis died Nov. 28. He was 94.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Keeping an Eye on the River View

BYLINE:  By NED SULLIVAN; Ned Sullivan is president of Scenic Hudson, a nonprofit land preservation and environmental advocacy group.

 BODY:
GREAT things are happening along Westchester County's waterfront. Projects in communities from Yonkers to Sleepy Hollow and Peekskill are connecting people to the river and with recreational, residential and commercial projects that will invigorate local economies while improving the quality of life of residents.
 Westchester County has been a seedbed of environmental activism for almost 40 years -- since the day when a group of citizens gathered in a home in Irvington and vowed to fight a proposal to build a power plant on Storm King Mountain in the Hudson Highlands. A court eventually ruled that the citizens had legal standing to oppose the project in the famed "Scenic Hudson Decision," considered a defining moment in the modern environmental movement. 
 That concept of citizens' involvement in the decisions that affect their communities is alive and well throughout the Hudson Valley. In Yonkers citizens rose up in the 1980's to stop construction of six 38-story luxury condominium towers that would have blocked public access to the river and views of the Palisades for city residents. Now a new mixed-use project is under construction. Soon children and families will be able to stroll along a public esplanade, dine in restaurants and learn about the Hudson River at the Beczak Environmental Education Center, while low- and mid-rise town houses will be available for sale and rental.
In Irvington a contaminated industrial lumberyard has been converted to a public park and senior center adjacent to a commercial complex. This brownfield reclamation resulted from a joint effort of the village, county, state and the Scenic Hudson environmental group.
In Sleepy Hollow, General Motors and its development partner, Roseland Properties, have collaborated with the mayor and regional environmental and cultural organizations to design a progressive residential and commercial development. The project will protect river views and access while revitalizing this crucial 100-acre waterfront parcel. More than 40 public meetings have occurred in the last few years to gather public input on a development plan expected to set aside 25 to 33 acres of green space.
As the public awaits crucial details on the density of development and projected traffic impacts on Route 9, Roseland and GM have indicated they will remain open to citizen input throughout the permitting process.
An exception to this string of successful public-private collaborations is a project proposed for Ossining by Capelli Enterprises Inc. This massive nine-story monolithic structure would stretch 150 yards along the waterfront. Citizens decisively expressed their view of the initiative, voting out the entire slate of town board members who had pushed the project through the local approval process.
The New York State Department of State has the opportunity to stand up for local control and sound waterfront planning by rejecting modifications of the village's local waterfront redevelopment plan that are needed for the project to go forward. Gov. George E. Pataki and the Hudson Valley Greenway Council have been champions of thoughtful waterfront revitalization along our American Heritage River. The state should send the entire project back to the drawing board.

HEADLINE: Beyond Boughs of Holly: Some Approaches to Decorating Large Foyers 

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
AT this time of year, there is one particularly obvious answer to the question of how to decorate a two-story entry foyer: boughs of holly. But experienced hands at decorating such spaces say it is worth thinking twice.
 "Go with faux," advised Nancy Gallagher-Mancini, owner of Precious Petals Too, a florist shop in Fairfield, N.J. "That way you avoid one very large, very prickly cleanup job." 
 She recommends decorating a towering foyer with "something large and showy, yet simple." In large hotel foyers, or very tall entry foyers in clients' homes, she said, she usually tries to make the staircase the focal point, using artificial holly, pine or cedar garlands to add panache, or fake magnolia, "if the client can afford it.'
"Today, we are concentrating on the natural look, and working fresh fruit, such as apples or pears, into the garlands -- or else, artificial or beaded fruit," said Ms. Gallagher-Mancini. "A fresh garland smells nice, but, oh, the mess!"
She added another factor in favor of fake: "With the economy the way it is," she said, "this may be a good time to invest in something that looks natural, but you can use it year after year.'
Trish DiMugno of Kensington, Conn., who sells furniture for a living but is a decorator by avocation, keeps wrought-iron giraffes in her 24-foot-tall entry foyer, whatever the season.
"I absolutely love animals," Mrs. DiMugno said. "I got them at Pier 1, and they are my statement when someone walks in the door.'
Mrs. DiMugno created a "contemporary primitive" look for the foyer of the three-year-old home she and her husband, Jeffrey, designed together, and she decorated with earth tones.
"Holiday red and green are not my favorites," she said, "and none of our grandchildren are coming, so we didn't get out all the usual stuff. We hung a wreath, which looks wonderful with my furniture."
The Tarallos of Paramus, N.J., on the other hand, are deeply committed to ornamenting their foyer for holidays. "It's the whole motive of the house," Jeanette Tarallo said. 
"When they were building this development five years ago, we had to speak to the owner of the land, because he was particular about the design. We told him we needed a three-foot-deep ledge, with hardwood flooring on top, and electrical outlets, across the front wall of the foyer. "He asked us, 'What do you want that for?' "
"The holidays," Mrs. Tarallo said she replied.
Ample electrical outlets are critical to high-power decorating, the Tarallos said, and Ms. Gallagher-Mancini, the florist, agrees. "It's not safe to connect more than three strings of lights," she said she instructs foyer owners. "And you don't want to be stringing extension cords in your grand foyer.'
There is also the matter of achieving the required height. 
William Tarallo has ladders of various heights to permit him to perform various feats in the foyer. The 15-footer is for chandelier cleaning. The 8-foot ladder is for getting Mr. Tarallo on the ledge, where he can walk around and arrange Christmas decorations -- or Easter, or Halloween.
Between seasons, of course, ample storage space is critical.
"I'm a closet freak," Mrs. Tarallo said, "We had extra-large closets built in, and we have a basement bigger than Santa's workshop."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Holiday decorating is "the whole motive" for the Tarallos' house. (Richard Perry/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Verizon Layoffs Leave 246 Worried 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
THEY are mostly men, mostly in their late 20's and early 30's. Some are new husbands, some are new fathers and others just got engaged. Their Christmas gift from their employer, Verizon: a pink slip.
 Verizon is firing 3,500 employees in New England, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania this month, said John Bonomo, a Verizon spokesman, because of softening business and increasing competition. In New York State, more than 2,300 were laid off before Christmas, and in Westchester and Putnam Counties, 246 -- mainly technicians with the least seniority -- were asked to leave on Dec. 19. They reported to work in the morning, and instead of being dispatched to the field, were fired. 
 "It was surreal, like a dream," said Brian Beigert, a cable splicer who was laid off. "It's the American nightmare."
Mr. Beigert worked for Verizon for six years in the northwestern corner of Westchester. A father of two, Elizabeth, 23 months, and Jacob, 5 months, he had bought a Cape in Dutchess County and asked his wife, Heather, to stay home with the children. That plan is now in question. 
Mr. Beigert is most worried about the numbers: $1,200 a month for the mortgage, $356 for the car, $150 for car insurance, $200 for heating oil, $75 for electricity. And food, gasoline, water, garbage pickup. 
"It was the most unnerving thing that has happened to me," said Mr. Beigert, who made $63,000 a year in salary and $20,000 in overtime. He called his wife from the parking lot when he learned the news, and she wept on the phone, he said.
Mr. Beigert has put aside about $8,000 in savings. He figures he will be able to get $400 a week in unemployment benefits for the next six months. But what if he doesn't find a new job by then?
"And, Lord, a week before Chrismas?" Mrs. Beigert said. 
Mr. Bonomo said that the company has wanted to shed workers since September, but procrastination by the union representing New York's Verizon workers, the Communication Workers of America, delayed the layoff until December.
"A lot of the overtures we made to the union were not met with a fair response," Mr. Bonomo said.
The company has fired employees with the least seniority, complying with union rules. 
Verizon made a profit of $2.1 billion in the third quarter, excluding proceeds from the sales of some of its properties, the same as the third quarter last year. Fueling the anger of the laid-off and their families is the recent revelation of Verizon executives' compensation packages. A radio campaign by the union this month said that the company's chief executive, Ivan G. Seidenberg, made $56 million over four years from salary and cashed-in stock options.
Verizon would not confirm the figure, but the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission show it to be correct.
Although talks of layoffs have been in the air for months, the actual pink slips still shocked many.
Robert G. Brubacher, a repairs technician, had planned to propose to his girlfriend of three years on Christmas, but that was scratched because he can no longer afford a diamond ring. Ron A. Fernandes, a newlywed, just bought a $250,000 house with a $1,600 monthly mortgage payment. Now he wonders if he will have to move.
"I don't understand," said Mr. Fernandes, a cable specialty technician who worked in Ossining and Peekskill for five years. "There was so much work out there. They forced us to work overtime. I wouldn't have thought they'd be laying off people."
For Dan Woodason Sr., a third-generation worker for Verizon and its predecessors, Bell Atlantic and Nynex, who was not laid off, the ultimate insult came soon after his son was fired. Mr. Woodason's son, Dan Jr., a former repairs technician for Verizon, was let go on a Thursday. The father was assigned repair work that Saturday.
"They are forcing me, forcing me, to work," said Mr. Woodason, a special circuits technician, "to do a job that my son used to do and would be very happy doing. If I don't want to work on a Saturday, I am fired."
Mr. Bonomo said the layoffs were necessary to keep the company strong, but the process has also shaken many low-level managers, who dispatched the technicians every day and had to deliver the grim news those who were fired.
"I see these men every day for 12 hours a day, sometimes six or even seven days a week," said a Westchester dispatcher who spoke on condition of anonymity. "I see them more than I see my own family. You go to their weddings. They come to your wedding. I really felt sick in my stomach for having to do it. I hope I don't ever have to do it again."
Meanwhile, Mr. Beigert is trying to get back on his feet. Soon, the bills for the Christmas gifts will arrive, for Barbie dolls, toy cars and clothes. He chafes at idling at home and said he would take any job, even custodial work, to keep the house going. 
But he knows it will be hard to find a job that can match the one with Verizon. Already, he said, he missed the pay, the camaraderie and the satisfaction of working with his hands. Since Verizon controls telephone cables in the Northeast, he may have to move to find a comparable job.
"But I have my roots here," said Mr. Beigert, who grew up in Peekskill. "This is where I come from. I am a New Yorker, and I will do whatever I can to stay."

HEADLINE: REDEVELOPMENT; 
Renewal Comes, Renters Go

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH 

 BODY:
FRANCESCA MARONE had just returned home from Christmas shopping a few weeks ago when she opened a letter from her landlord and learned that she was being evicted. Ms. Marone, who has lived in an oceanfront apartment building on the Long Branch boardwalk for more than 10 years, put her purchases right back into their shopping bags.
 "All the Christmas stuff I bought I had to return," she said. "I have to watch my money now." 
 Ms. Marone and about 100 other tenants at the Seaview Towers have 18 months to find new places to live. The two six-story buildings on Ocean Avenue are slated for demolition, and the tenants attribute their displacement to a wave of development that has swept the shore town the last few years. 
"I can see improving the town," Ms. Marone said. "But to the point where you are driving people out, I just can't understand it."
Tenants at Seaview are among the latest middle- and low-income renters who are being pushed out of once-sagging Jersey Shore towns by new development and soaring property values.
"What is happening in Long Branch is happening in other towns as well," said Arnold Cohen, policy coordinator for the Housing and Community Development Network of New Jersey, a group that advocates affordable housing.
"We want to have plans for redevelopment," he said, "but we do not want to forget about the people who have been living in these towns, or the people who need to have a place to live in the future."
Like other chronically depressed towns along the shore, Long Branch had its heyday decades ago.
Before the turn of the 20th century, it was considered a top beach resort, rivaling Newport for the affections of the vacationing rich. But as highways and airways connected cities with more favorable destinations, many of the crowded shore towns began to empty. In Long Branch, summer beach cottages sagged into year-round apartments. After a fire in 1987, the once-celebrated city pier stood as a burned-out hulk for nearly a decade. 
A few years ago, an aggressive state redevelopment push, a hot economy and an activist city government began to turn things around. The city established five redevelopment zones in the crumbling downtown area and negotiated for streamlined approval with state regulators. The boardwalk was cleaned up and refurbished, new businesses began to sprout along Broadway and the promenade, and three major housing and retail developments were lured into the oceanfront neighborhood.
Most of the big developments are still in the early stages, but city officials say they expect to see new buildings rising next spring, providing 700 condominiums and rentals.
"This is a massive renewal," said Robert W. Burchell, co-director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University. "They have done an amazing job. They have totally transformed the area."
Seaview Towers, two brick buildings constructed in 1955, stand just south of the oceanfront redevelopment zone. The buildings, well-maintained and popular with retired and working-class tenants, directly overlook the ocean and are just minutes from the Long Branch train station.
Kristen Moylen of Cronheim Management Services, which manages the towers, said the area's economic rebound was not the only factor behind the decision by the owner, Seaview Towers L.L.C., to demolish the apartment houses.
Although the towers are in good condition, she said, they would need expensive refitting to meet the demands of the current rental market. Neither building has air-conditioning, she said, and each is served by only one elevator.
Ms. Moylen said the owner had not announced plans for the site.
Mayor Adam Schneider, who has led the redevelopment in his 12 years in office, said he had heard about the planned demolition from a city employee who lived in the Seaview Towers. He said it was the type of economic activity that the city expected to ripple out from the redevelopment zones.
"I would be surprised if they do not come in with something much more upscale than what is there right now," he said.
Mr. Schneider said that some dislocation was inevitable in any redevelopment and that the city had tried to find new housing for people who have had to move. So far, he said, Long Branch has helped 300 people from the redevelopment zone find other places in town to live. 
"As Long Branch becomes a more desirable place to live and property values go up, rents are going up," he said. "We are going to have to figure out what we can do to help people who want to stay in Long Branch stay here."
The mayor said the redevelopment would not succeed if longtime residents thought there was no place for them in Long Branch. He said that helping the Seaview tenants find new housing could be difficult, but said it would be a priority for the city.
State planners have encouraged the development of urban areas, like Long Branch or New Brunswick, as ways to stop suburban sprawl. They say they are trying to do so without displacing people. 
"It is the classic dilemma of urban revitalization," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "Areas that have fallen on hard times become the source of affordable housing."
Mr. Hughes said that as renewal projects succeed, they inevitably encourage private investment and higher prices. Blaming landlords for renovating their buildings in order to raise rents would be counterproductive, he added.
"What has to happen is a realization that there are going to be people who are hurt in a revitalization and provide means of mitigating the problems that could arise," he said.
"One possible solution is generating affordable housing or having some portion of the new development set aside for affordable housing."
State planners say that is already in the works for the shore towns.
From 1998 to 2001, the state financed 16,500 units of affordable housing around the state. Governor McGreevey said last fall that he would finance 20,000 more units of low- and middle-income housing over the next four years, at a cost of $2.5 billion.
E.J. Miranda, a spokesman for the Department of Community Affairs, said the state wanted to encourage development of areas like Long Branch without driving out the people who now live there.
"With redevelopment we can also provide affordable housing," he said.
Mr. Cohen, of the Housing and Community Development Network, noted the state's increase in spending on affordable housing but said it would still not meet the demand. 
"It is not one landlord's responsibility to do this," he said. "We live in a capitalist society. But that is why we have government, to provide for the common good. And not to have Long Branch become another town that everyone is priced out of."
That is the worry of many of the Seaview tenants.
Roberta Jacoubs, a retired office manager, doubts that she will find another apartment in town. The rent on the two-bedroom apartment that she has occupied for 12 years is less than $1,000 a month, and she said nearby apartment complexes charged well over $2,000.
"I would like to stay in Long Branch, but what option do we have?" she said. "We have to move, we have to look for a new place."

HEADLINE: McGreevey Seeks to Revamp Support for Poorest Schools 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
AFTER a year of conjecture about how Governor McGreevey might try to change the way the state's poorest school districts operate, the word is out. The shoe has dropped. Next month, lawyers representing the governor plan to ask the state Supreme Court to approve a shift in support for needy schools, not in the amount of support -- more than $3.5 billion last year -- but in how those schools allocate and spend it.
 The change would allow the schools to drop some programs and add others. The state says its goal is to have the schools place more emphasis on literacy in the early grades and on basic subjects like math, science and social studies. 
 "There is a necessity to focus on what works," Governor McGreevey said in an interview. "We need to understand that in an increasingly competitive economic climate, the education of our children in every community will be the single greatest determinant of our success." 
This is no small request. The governor is seeking to alter a series of decisions of the court itself dating to the early 1980's that fall under the general title of Abbott v. Burke.
The ground-breaking Abbott decision, widely considered of national importance, was one in which the court ruled, in 1997, that New Jersey had a constitutional responsibility to fill the gap in spending between the state's richest and poorest districts. Because the main source of local revenue for education, the property tax, made some districts rich and many others poor, the state had to give to the poor districts -- like Newark, Trenton and Camden -- and make them equal with the rich.
Although courts in many states have required increased aid for poor schools, none have reached as far as New Jersey's court in ordering direct parity.
"New Jersey was really the first state to successfully address this issue of school finance equalization," said Henry M. Levin, a professor of economics at Teachers College at Columbia University. 
The governor's request comes at an important time for school financing around the country. President Bush has asked the states to follow new guidelines stressing early childhood education and literacy in order to qualify for federal aid, at a time when the states are trying to redefine their own educational standards.
In New Jersey, tight state finances have led to fights over local school spending. And in the realm of state aid, some legislators are questioning one result of the Abbott decision -- that the 30 poorest districts now draw roughly half of all state aid provided for education. The other half is divided among 586 school districts.
The McGreevey request would alter some restrictions placed on districts that receive aid under the Abbott decision. The court ordered that the districts had to agree to adopt systems outlining day-to-day operations of their elementary schools, dealing with everything from technology in classrooms to social services. 
The problem, according to the McGreevey administration, is that the models, often adapted from plans for failing urban schools around the country, can be too restrictive, providing detailed staffing requirements and sometimes scripted lesson plans for teachers. And in many cases, the officials argue, the models have not worked. 
"Every school district has different needs," said James M. Davy, the governor's chief of operations. "You can't use a cookie-cutter approach to education. You have to look at each of the districts' needs and tailor the programs to meet those needs."
A N order that models be developed for middle schools and high schools was repealed last summer for one year. Now, if the court agrees to the McGreevey request, all schools would be allowed to opt out of the model programs and decide for themselves how to spend the aid they receive, based on need and results. The state would develop a way to monitor student performance in the poor districts as well as a way to monitor the entire Abbott funds program, trying to erase what critics say is a failure in knowing where the money goes.
Mr. Davy said the state had collected data indicating that the court-imposed plans have not produced the results that were expected. In some schools, he said, the plans have increased inefficiencies rather than making the schools more effective.
Officials plan to argue that the numbers show that some of the expense related to the court-mandated spending does not directly affect students. They say that several of the top performing Abbott school districts are in the bottom third in spending per pupil.
Moreover, the officials contend that the plans often require districts to hire support personnel who are not always needed to run the schools. In some cases, they said, districts have to pay for technology administrators for every elementary school and dropout prevention specialists. Others have been required to hire full-time people to make sure the schools are following the letter of the court-imposed plans.
Mr. Davy said some districts would prefer to share these administrators among a number of schools or to shift their responsibility to other workers. But they cannot do so under current rules. 
"Forget the fancy stuff," Mr. Davy said. "They may want to focus on ensuring that every third grader can read at grade level."
Defenders of the court-ordered programs argue that the state's claims are unfair and, in some cases, inaccurate.
Robert E. Slavin, a researcher at Johns Hopkins University who designed one of the model plans, called Success for All, said it had produced demonstrable success in New Jersey schools.
"The schools that are using Success for All are making pretty substantial gains, and they are making better gains than the state as a whole," he said.
Dr. Slavin agreed with the state's desire to allow more flexibility for school districts. But he said New Jersey needed to ensure that schools that chose to move away from the models picked a new system "that has better evidence of effectiveness."
"The whole theory behind Abbott was simply that providing money to high-poverty schools was not sufficient," he said. "The money should be used for research-based programs that had a high likelihood of success."
Most of the Abbott schools that use Success for All seem happy with the program, Dr. Slavin said. He expects that few would choose to shift, because the programs are bringing good results and because the focus on early literacy is in line with the new guidelines from the state and federal governments.
The Abbott money "is there for a purpose," he said, "and it needs to be spent on something that makes sense for the kids."
Gordon MacInnes, the assistant education commissioner in charge of the Abbott school program, who was a state senator when the Abbott decision was issued, acknowledged that the court imposed the models at the request of the education commissioner at the time. But he said the department now believes the decision was wrong.
"The remedies they laid down reflected what was currently faddish in education," he said. "They came up with this idea that you could develop an off-the-shelf approach that a school could adopt and if they implemented it faithfully they could improve."
Mr. MacInnes also acknowledged that some schools have had success with the court-imposed models, and he said the administration did not want to force schools to drop the plans if they are working.
"We expect this to be a thoughtful process," he said. "There will only be a change if the school itself determines there should be a change."
David G. Sciarra, the executive director of the Education Law Center, which represents students in the Abbott districts, said the group did not plan to oppose the McGreevey proposal so long as the state requires the schools to adopt a practical alternative to models and gives them specific direction in spending. In fact, Mr. Sciarra said, his group opposed the imposition of the model school programs when the court ruled five years ago. 
"We opposed it at the time for the same reason the department is now moving away from it -- you can't mandate a one-size-fits-all approach," he said. "What happens is a bottom-up assessment -- how are kids doing in each school? -- and then design and improvement program that addresses the gaps."
In Jersey City, an Abbott district, Suzanne T. Mack, who has served on the school board for 12 years, said the models were imposed on the districts by the state. 
"The locals never got a chance to comment on the state's plan to begin with," she said. "This was something from the commissioner's office."
Ms. Mack said, however, that some grammar schools seemed to be doing well by using the models, at least so far.
"Whether we agree with it or not, there has not been enough time to tell," she said.
Supporters of the models argue that they have been successful in a number of schools. They also say that the models, some developed by leading universities, are backed by independent research.
W. Steven Barnett, director of the National Institute for Early Education Research at Rutgers University, said models had been popular in some areas. But he said the key to any method was obtaining the cooperation of the local staff, rather than forcing a system on them.
"You can't force them to do anything because you cannot manage the logistics if they do not want to cooperate," he said.
Dr. Barnett said it could take several years to measure a program's effect.
In fact, some critics say the state Department of Education has very little idea of how effective spending has been in any Abbott school district. Mr. Sciarra said the state had only a rough idea of how financial aid translates into classroom programs and almost no idea of how effective the programs have been. 
"We don't have a database of how well students do in relation to what we do," Mr. MacInnes acknowledged. "We are trying to build a capacity to do that."
Mr. MacInnes said the state had taken steps to begin assessing all 30 Abbott districts. In October, the state notified the districts that they would be required to complete a detailed evaluation form describing their programs and their curriculum. The state expects to have evaluated by the reports by next summer. 
The state also plans to start using a database that will track the performance of all students in Abbott schools, starting with pre-schoolers. Education officials say that will allow them to focus on which programs are succeeding and failing in Abbott districts around the state.
"We want to be able to say here is what the objectives are," Mr. MacInnes said.
In line with new federal policy -- called No Child Left Behind -- the state objectives focus heavily on literacy and early education programs. The Department of Education wants elementary schools in the Abbott districts to provide programs that will increase reading scores in third-grade tests and to increase test scores in core curriculum areas like math and science.
"We want every student in the third grade to be reading at grade level," Mr. MacInnes said. "And we want students at every level to master these core standards."
Both the state's largest teachers union, the New Jersey Education Association, and the school superintendents association say they support the idea of offering more flexibility to the Abbott school districts.
"They want to keep the standards high but give the districts enough flexibility to implement their programs and probably save some money," said James H. Murphy, executive director of the New Jersey Association of School Administrators. "I am optimistic that will work out."
JAMES H. LYTLE, the superintendent in Trenton, said some schools in his district were showing good results using the model system, while others would be more likely to stop using models. Mr. Lytle was part of a working group that helped the McGreevey administration come up with its new proposal, and he said he supported greater flexibility, provided that the state continue to finance the schools at the current level.
"I am aware of the new guideline and supportive of it, with the idea that it not be used to decrease funding," he said. "That was a concern during the planning group meetings," he said, "and it was made clear that was not the intent."
Last year, the Abbott districts were expecting a $400 million increase, but the governor struck a deal with advocates for the Abbott schools and the Supreme Court to forgo that. But the state agreed to an additional $89 million that had already been committed to the districts and $140 million for pre-kindergarten programs.
Mr. Sciarra, who took a good deal of criticism from his own side for backing the deal, said he could not agree to another year of reduced financing for the Abbott districts.
"The Education Law Center has made it clear, on behalf of the students, we could not support that," he said.
It may be difficult to find enough money to go around. The governor is facing demands not only from the Abbott districts but also from school districts around the state. Last spring, because of a $6 billion deficit in the state's general budget, only the Abbott districts received any additional money over the previous year. As a result, many districts had to cut spending and ask for increases in local property taxes, which pay for most school expenses.
In one such district, the Matawan-Aberdeen regional school district, Bruce M. Quinn, the superintendent, points out that employee salaries and benefits rise every year, so programs must be cut when state aid does not increase. This year, he said, his district had to forgo several new hires and lease textbooks rather than buy them.
"We cut back on after-school activities, we eliminated some supplies," he said. "We used to have an aide in each kindergarten class, we are not going to have that anymore."
Legislators say middle-income districts like Mr. Quinn's are feeling the squeeze in educational funds. These districts are too wealthy to qualify for Abbott financing but not wealthy enough to absorb regular property tax increases.
"The governor and the legislature have not addressed this in a fundamental way for at least two and a half decades," said Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican from Flemington. 
Unless the state can find another way to pay for schools, or change the current formula, legislators like Mr. Lance say the cost will continue to be born by the property tax.
Senator John H. Adler, a Democrat from Cherry Hill, said he plans to introduce bills that will help school districts save money, but he said the state still needs to change the "structural catastrophe" of school financing.
"Abbott has absolutely the right philosophy of trying to equalize opportunity" for the relative few districts that qualify, Mr. Adler said. But, he added, "How do you accommodate the remaining 580 districts?"
Governor McGreevey said he does not plan to cut school aid in the forthcoming budget. The state is trying to find "other revenue sources" to increase the aid, he said, but declined to identify any of the potential sources.
Mr. Sciara and other Abbott supporters said the state might have to consider increasing the income tax to find money to pay for education. 
"The pot of state aid was substantially cut during the 90's through tax cuts that legislators of both parties supported," he said. "No politician wants to stand up and face it -- we do not have the revenues to do what needs to be done."
