HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
Ripken's Off the Roster, but Still in Baseball

BYLINE:  By GREGORY JORDAN 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE 

 BODY:
FOR Cal Ripken Jr. this off-season, curveballs are complex finance deals. Tricky grounders are design decisions he makes on his construction sites. The fastball at his eyes is the task of reviving baseball for a generation of children hooked on computer games and skateboards. And his big hit has been the purchase of a franchise that he has built into the Aberdeen Ironbirds, which had a sellout first season in his hometown, Aberdeen, Md.
 In his entrepreneurial first year of retirement, Mr. Ripken, 42, the former Baltimore Oriole with the record streak of 2,632 consecutive games, has shaped his name into a family-run corporation that one day could own a major league team. He manages Ripken Baseball with his brother Bill, the co-founder; his sister, Elly, the accountant for the Ironbirds; and a staff of 27. 
 The company, privately held, has not disclosed revenue or earnings, but it projects that its businesses -- stadium design, management consulting, youth baseball academies, minor league baseball ownership, apparel and merchandise, endorsements, books, videos and public speaking -- will all be profitable in the next year. 
While donating millions of dollars to youth baseball programs, Mr. Ripken has capitalized on his wealth, achievements and charisma to the point where he sees himself as a turnaround specialist for baseball, which has been struggling with faulty economics and declining popularity for many years. He will even promote baseball on Friday as grand marshal of the parade at the Fiesta Bowl in Tempe, Ariz., where Miami and Ohio State will battle for No. 1 -- in college football.
Some baseball insiders note that Mr. Ripken is building the company around his name -- a potentially hazardous practice in any business. Further, his growing role in youth baseball has created tensions with Little League Baseball, the 64-year-old federation of youth leagues, which historically has refused to align itself with any one star player.
Others say Mr. Ripken's goal of a baseball renaissance is noble but risky, considering that Major League Baseball attendance declined by 4.3 million last season from the previous year and that youth league enrollment declined by more than 100,000 in the last five years. 
"The game is struggling at all levels," said Fay Vincent, a former commissioner of Major League Baseball. "But Cal's enormously able and energetic. What he does can't be completely separated from what's going on in baseball generally, but with him there's hope. It's important for him to do well in order for baseball to come back."
MR. RIPKEN said he knew quite a bit about running a company just growing up in a baseball family, so the challenges faced by Ripken Baseball do not seem so daunting.
"We learned the game in a professional setting that included certain business insights," he said in a recent interview in a stone building that his company owns on the edge of horse country outside Baltimore. He referred often to the influence of his father, Cal Sr., a player, coach and teacher for 37 years who became the Orioles manager. He died in 1999.
"In the morning, Dad would always be pecking at the typewriter," Mr. Ripken said. "We knew that the business side was going on."
Mr. Ripken foreshadowed his career as a baseball businessman in 1994, when a 232-day players' strike crippled the game. He undertook a lead marketing role for the game, earning the unofficial title of baseball's ambassador because he would spend hours at stadiums around the country signing autographs. "I don't think anybody played a bigger role in the baseball recovery from that 1994 fiasco," Mr. Vincent said. "He almost did it by himself."
His breaking the mark for consecutive games is also credited with helping to bring baseball out of its poststrike malaise. Mr. Ripken broke Lou Gehrig's record of 2,130 games on Sept. 6, 1995; the streak began on May 30, 1982, and ended at 2,632 games, on Sept. 20, 1998.
Mr. Ripken's agent, Ron Shapiro, a Baltimore lawyer who represents many athletes, said he recognized early in Mr. Ripken's career that he might seek business challenges after his playing days. "I came to realize that we had to do something different for Cal than for other clients -- create a business base from which he might operate," Mr. Shapiro said.
Their original plan was to focus on for-profit baseball youth academies and the nonprofit programs that encourage young players. But Mr. Ripken also wanted to own a minor league club based in Aberdeen, on the Chesapeake Bay and perhaps best known for the Aberdeen Proving Grounds, an Army testing center.
He invested $6 million of his money in the first phase of a 110-acre baseball complex that is home to the 6,100-seat Ironbirds stadium and his first baseball academy. Maryland and local governments provided an additional $12 million in financing. 
The project's $1 million second phase -- three youth baseball fields and a soccer field, all financed by Mr. Ripken -- will be completed this spring. Plans call for more youth fields, a hotel and conference center and the Cal Ripken Sr. Foundation ballpark for children from disadvantaged backgrounds. There will also be stores and restaurants. 
Mr. Ripken said his main achievement last year was to make a success of the Ironbirds. He started by buying the Utica Blue Sox in New York for $3 million last January, moving the club to Aberdeen and renaming it. "Ironbirds" is a play on Mr. Ripken's nickname with the Orioles, Iron Man.
John Moag, chief executive of Moag & Company, a sports investment bank in Baltimore, said the Ironbirds probably earned at least $1.25 million the last year before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Mr. Moag called that a strong performance -- and better, obviously, than the bottom lines at many floundering major league teams. Ripken Baseball, he said, is "a diverse company that has enormous potential."
Most recently, Ripken Baseball introduced a consulting subsidiary, Ripken Management and Design, for municipalities and former big-league players who want to buy minor league clubs. The firm advises clients about how to create sports sites and organizations like the one in Aberdeen, and is negotiating to be the consultant for several municipalities, including Daytona Beach, Fla., and Evansville, Ind.
Christopher Flannery, a product development and marketing specialist from England whom Ripken Baseball hired as chief operating officer, said it had no investment partners but might as it expanded.
Mr. Ripken has financed the company partly from his income from endorsements for companies including Chevrolet, MBNA and Coca-Cola, and from fees for public speaking -- he earns $75,000 to $125,000 an engagement. Mr. Flannery would not quantify the endorsement value, saying a substantial part of it was in business-to-business barter.
With Bill Ripken, who was also a player for Baltimore and other teams, Cal Ripken plans to expand the Ripken youth academies. Last year, the first academy, which charges $400 to $575 for five days, drew 850 coaches and campers in four weeks of operation. Ripken Baseball plans to open 10-week camps at Aberdeen and other places around the country and intends to triple attendance in 2003.
The rapid expansion has demanded what Mr. Ripken calls an "absolute line" between Ripken Baseball and the youth and nonprofit commitments that he views as an obligation to his father and to baseball. The returns to Ripken Baseball created by Mr. Ripken's nonprofit activities are inevitable and could create some conflicts of interest.
"He'll have to be very careful with that tricky line," Mr. Vincent said. "But the word is noble. I think baseball needs more of him."
His focus on encouraging young people has, of course, been welcomed by many influential people in the sport besides Mr. Vincent. But Mr. Ripken's moves in the youth baseball world have not gone over universally well with Little League Baseball. 
The tension began in 1999, when the nonprofit Babe Ruth League renamed its age 5 to 12 division the Cal Ripken Division of Babe Ruth League Baseball, and Mr. Ripken reciprocated by helping to negotiate a television contract with Fox Sports to broadcast its championship games, setting up a competition for viewers. (Little League Baseball, which runs the Little League World Series, is broadcast on ABC.) Babe Ruth baseball will hold the Cal Ripken World Series next August in Aberdeen at the same time the Little League Baseball games are held in Williamsport, Pa.
Mr. Ripken and officials of Little League Baseball denied that there was competition. But Mr. Ripken said he thought that his strategy of branding and "rejuvenating fun" were the prescription for addressing the game's decline in popularity.
"We believe we can reverse this trend," he said. "It's clear that there are a lot more choices for kids. The game has gotten too serious all the way down. But we really believe the game is still the best asset."
MR. RIPKEN'S recent withdrawal from consideration to become general manager of the Orioles suggested that he is content, for now, to be a solitary entrepreneur.
But the advisory board of Ripken Baseball is an indicator that major league ownership is on the agenda. The board includes Mr. Shapiro and Stephen Bisciotti, a Baltimore businessman who is an owner of the Baltimore Ravens football team. Mr. Bisciotti and Mr. Ripken consult often, a relationship not dissimilar to that of Ted Leonsis, an owner of the Washington Wizards and Capitals, and another big investor in sports franchises, Michael Jordan.
Mr. Shapiro said that for now, Mr. Ripken's "focus is on baseball, and he certainly has dreams of ownership at the highest level, and I believe he will fulfill that."
Because of the success of the Ironbirds, Mr. Ripken said, he would at least consider ownership of another minor league club. "We're taking risks based on our abilities, and right now there's certain limitations in our manpower," he said. "Major league ownership is hard to factor from a business standpoint, but it's one of the dreams."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Shuffleboard, Starboard. Finance, Port.

BYLINE:  By HOLLY HUBBARD PRESTON 

 BODY:
OTTIS BALLENGER, a retired neurosurgeon from Greenville, S.C., and his wife, Ann, recently returned from a 10-day cruise to five islands in the Caribbean. They got a chance to soak up the tropical climate, enjoy gourmet food and mingle with other retired couples. But the biggest draw, they said, was the professional investment advice they received on board.
 "The tourism part is really secondary now since many of the ports we are visiting we've seen before," said Dr. Ballenger, who has been on six ocean cruises with investment themes in as many years. 
 The Ballengers are part of a growing class of travelers known as "investment cruisers," often wealthy retirees who spend their days at sea mostly below deck discussing serious subjects like mutual funds, bonds and commodities with financial experts. In their case, the expert was Louis Rukeyser, the host of "Louis Rukeyser's Wall Street" on CNBC. 
Mr. Rukeyser is considered a pioneer in seminars at sea, having been a host for them since 1998. Similar cruises, to name just a few, are offered by MorningstarAdvisor.com, Jim Lowell's Fidelity New Economy Investor, Forbes, and BusinessWeek, in a partnership with Standard & Poor's.
Eric Graves, the vice president of group sales for Crystal Cruises of Los Angeles, on whose ships many of these cruises take place, said the investment seminars attracted from 300 to 800 people a cruise, filling a significant portion of many ships, and represented "the fastest-growing segment of our group business."
"I can tell you that 10 years ago this investment cruise phenomenon didn't exist," Mr. Graves said.
Of course, part of the attraction is the chance to meet people like Mr. Rukeyser; Steve Forbes, the editor in chief of Forbes magazine; or Marshall Loeb, a CBS MarketWatch columnist. (Dr. Ballenger said he had sat next to Mr. Rukeyser at the blackjack table.) But cruise passengers say most of the investment lessons or stock tips come from the accompanying panel of experts, including independent professionals and senior-level business journalists.
"There is no one line of investment thought; I have seen so many of these financial people disagree with one another," said Marjorie North, a society columnist for The Sarasota Herald-Tribune in Florida and a repeat customer of the Forbes Cruise for Investors. She said she and her husband, Bill Hirons, a former executive at DuPont, planned to take Ms. North's grown daughter, Christina, 30, a lawyer, on a Forbes investment cruise to Alaska in June.
"We think it is time she learned to invest," she said, "and these seminars are better than a book."
Ms. North says the investment cruises have helped make her more comfortable about investing in these rough economic times. The Ballengers, too, say they feel better equipped to handle market fluctuations, even though their portfolio, like those of many other investors, has suffered losses in recent years.
Investment cruises can provide benefits beyond stock tips and investing lessons. Passengers may qualify for group discounts of 25 percent or more off regular cabin rates, with prices starting at less than $5,000 a couple. The Ballengers said they paid about $13,000 for their Caribbean cruise and got a deluxe stateroom with a veranda that might otherwise have gone for more than $17,000. The trip left Fort Lauderdale the day after Thanksgiving.
To attend the seminar part of the cruise, they paid an additional $895. (At least one cruise organizer has waived such fees lately; cruise bookings in general have been down because of the weak economy and lingering fears of terrorism.)
A few investment cruisers may even be able to write off part of their trips on federal income tax returns, as they do for conventions and seminars held on land. But be forewarned: there are many restrictions. According to the Internal Revenue Service, each taxpayer can deduct up to $2,000 of investment cruise expenses in a calendar year, but only if the cruise seminar relates directly to his trade or business. The law also mandates that cruise ships visit only United States ports and that they sail under an American flag. (Ordinary investors like the Ballengers generally do not qualify for such deductions; those who think they may should contact a tax professional.)
Charles Githler, founder and chairman of InterShow in Sarasota, Fla., which organizes many investment cruises, said that several repeat passengers on InterShow investment cruises reported being able to deduct all or part of the cruise costs by tying them to their business. Likewise, he said, he knew of customers who managed large family investment accounts or trusts and could write off a portion of the trip.
The seminar-at-sea concept appeals not only to information-hungry investors but also to the financial advisers themselves. The T. Rowe Price Group, based in Baltimore, has been setting up investment cruises for its mutual fund clients since the late 1990's. "Since we are a no-load mutual fund company, we don't get a lot of chances to speak to people face to face," said Steve Norwitz, a company spokesman.
IN October, T. Rowe Price took a small group of investors on a fall foliage trip up the Eastern Seaboard for nine days. The cruise was organized by Continuing Education Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., which arranges accredited conferences for investors and professionals, including physicians, lawyers and architects. Passengers receive credits for courses.
Michael Murphy, editor and founder of the California Technology Stock Letter, who has been on several cruises, said he enjoyed meeting with clients as well. "I get two things out of the cruise," he said. "First, there are often some very sophisticated investors who have made a lot of money or know a lot about some sector of technology, especially niches in medicine. Second, I want to see face to face what people understand and what confuses them, what worries them."
Among the discussion topics on recent investment cruises were the weak economy and its impact on Wall Street, asset allocation in a bear market and how to spot investment charlatans.
The formats for the seminars are similar, although informal access to guest speakers outside scheduled seminar hours can vary. Prospective passengers may want to do some homework to find the program that is right for them.
Cruise organizers generally arrange their speakers and topics months in advance, so prospective passengers can nail down how much time will be spent in seminars versus time on shore. Generally, the seminar portion takes place only while the ship is at sea. Depending on the length of the cruise, three to four full days of seminar time is standard.
Featured speakers are not always on board for the duration of the trip. Mr. Murphy, the newsletter publisher, acknowledges that he did not typically stay for an entire cruise. (He said there was no "quicker way to be totally out of touch with the market than to get on a cruise ship.") Mr. Forbes also stays for only a portion of each cruise, according to conference organizers.
Prospective passengers may also want to consider the amount of scheduled time for questions and answers after the sessions -- and whether there will be soirees outside the formal seminars at which presenters and investors can mingle.
Mr. Rukeyser says the guest speakers he chooses for the cruises must be highly approachable people, like Joseph V. Battipaglia, the chief investment officer at Ryan, Beck & Company in New York. One former investment cruiser described how Mr. Battipaglia, when stopped in the hallway on one cruise, discussed her portfolio with her for a half-hour.
For his part, Mr. Battipaglia said he had come to welcome such interaction. After all, these people could be future clients.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
If a Resume Lies, Truth Can Loom Large

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH STANTON 

 BODY:
THIS year, several high-profile executives were caught stretching the truth about their credentials -- among them, Ronald L. Zarrella, the chief executive of Bausch & Lomb, the eye-care products maker. Mr. Zarrella said he received an M.B.A. from New York University, when, in fact, he left before graduating. The board withheld a $1.1 million year-end bonus he had been promised. 
 Kenneth E. Lonchar left his position as chief financial officer of Veritas Software after the company learned that he falsely claimed to have an M.B.A. from Stanford. Then there was Sandra Baldwin, who resigned as president of the United States Olympic Committee after acknowledging that she had lied about her academic background. 
 Of course, false claims on resumes are not confined to the executive suite. They have been found at all employment levels for about as long as resumes have been around. But in a tight job market, where more security-conscious companies are checking backgrounds, employment experts say they worry that more people may be tempted to embellish their credentials as a means of gaining a competitive edge. 
Padding can take many creative forms: extending the length of employment so it doesn't look as though you've been out of work too long; changing a former job title, say, to account executive from executive assistant; or claiming to hold a degree when you're a few credits shy. Some people have made up eye-catching stints at defunct, and untraceable, dot-com companies, experts say.
Most people know what happens to high-level executives who are caught, but what about the rest of the working population? How can people recover from the embarrassment, not to mention the possible professional ramifications that lying on a resume can bring? 
Lynda Ford, the president of the Ford Group, a human resource consulting firm in Rome, N.Y., says the repercussions are not drastic for most people who are caught. "In the worst-case scenario, you're facing the same challenge that someone who was fired from their job faces," she said.
Ms. Ford says you correct the errors and move on, but that the tight economy is making it harder to bounce back. "Four years ago, I'd probably say they could get another job, but it's not an employee market anymore," she said, "so we're talking about a market where they need to exercise a little more discretion."
In other words, resist the temptation to pad.
"People are thinking, 'It's a competitive world out there, and I'm just going to get lost in the shuffle if I don't put my best foot forward,' even if it isn't true," said Robert P. Lawry, director of the Center for Professional Ethics at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. "But in the end, you will get lost."
Many people appear to ignore that advice. Automatic Data Processing of Roseland, N.J., the provider of payroll and other human resources services, said 44 percent of the 2.6 million background checks it conducted last year contained discrepancies between information the applicants provided and the data reported by their former employers. Forty-one percent of the total checks showed discrepancies in educational information, it said.
Michael W. Kramer, an associate professor of communications at the University of Missouri at Columbia who has studied resume writing, said that while he does not recommend stretching the truth, "the chance of being caught is still incredibly small." For one thing, he said, most small and midsize companies are not conducting background checks.
Companies that try to check may have a hard time tracking some employment records. "Sometimes, because of job turnover, you can't track a person's boss down because they've already had two or three other jobs," said Michael G. Kessler, the chief executive of Kessler International, a corporate investigation firm based in New York.
In other cases, previous employers cannot be tracked down because they no longer exist. Steven C. Morgan, chief executive of SalesRecruits.com in Northport, N.Y., says he sometimes encounters that problem with job candidates who list dot-com companies that have gone out of business. He says he can easily spot other resume embellishments. Candidates with less than two years of experience, for example, have "sprinkled technology nomenclature throughout the rest of their resumes to make it seem as if they have been working in the tech field for 10 years," he said.
IF you've already submitted a resume with an untruth or two, experts say the most obvious solution, but certainly not the easiest, is to come clean. "I'd say admit to it and get the resume back to the truth," said Jeffrey E. Christian, the chief executive of the executive search firm Christian & Timbers in Cleveland. "But I wouldn't necessarily go up to the C.E.O. and say, 'Hey, I lied on my resume.' Talk to an unbiased coach and figure out where you are in your career and what the situation is at your current job before you just put it all on the table."
Don't expect a career coach to help you reword any embellishments. "They want me to do that, but I can't be Stephen King and make up a work of fiction for them," said Michael Worthington, director of operations at Resume Doctor in South Burlington, Vt. A good resume coach, he said, will help highlight accomplishments so that the stronger areas of your employment history outshine the weaker spots.
Someone who has trumped up a resume should not compound the lie with another lie, Ms. Ford advised. "Just explain what happened to your next potential employer," she said. While there is no guarantee you will get the job, she said, most employers appreciate such honesty. "Once you have your resume back on track," she said, "tap into your network and use friends and trusted colleagues to open doors."
"Talk to people that will stand by you and say that 'yes, you did a stupid thing but it was just a mistake,' and get them to champion your cause," she said.
It's never too late to set the record straight. 
Thomas Manga, 26, who works at a technology company in Manhattan, says he plans to amend his resume. While he says he did not fabricate any academic or work experience, he says he stretched the truth about the length of service of his last job as a computer program trainer. He was laid off in April 2001, he said, but put on his resume that his employment ended in July that year, when his severance pay ran out. 
"I figured why not; I was technically getting paid by them," he said. "Six months is a lot of time for a tech worker to be out of work; it just didn't look good."
For those with years of resume fudges, the danger lies in believing those lies, Mr. Lawry said. "You begin to tell yourself a story, because you've told that story so often to other people and it's only when you get caught that you realize what you've done," he said.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Remi J. Browne; 
Standish International Equity Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
REMI J. BROWNE, manager of the $55 million Standish International Equity fund, says the simultaneous declines in stock prices and interest rates around the world are making it much easier to find bargain stocks for his value-oriented investors.
 "The relationship between equity valuations and interest rates favors stocks to an extent not often seen in recent history," Mr. Browne said in a telephone interview from his office in downtown Boston. 
 Many stock markets around the world have tumbled in the last three years, making stocks a better value when measured against forecasts of their earnings. Even after a rally last fall, the average foreign stock is now trading at about 12 times its expected earnings for 2003, he said, compared with a multiple of nearly 15 in the United States. 
The fund lost 7.2 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, placing it among the top 8 percent of all foreign stock funds, which lost 16.9 percent a year, on average, according to Morningstar Inc. The Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe Australasia Far East index was down 17.3 percent during that time.
The fund lost 4.7 percent in the last 12 months, versus declines of 14.2 percent for its group and 14.1 percent for the index.
Mr. Browne, 49, is vice president of Standish Mellon, the fund's adviser and a unit of the Mellon Financial Corporation. He manages about $550 million more, mostly for institutions.
The fund is available from Standish Mellon for a minimum investment of $100,000 or through Fidelity and other mutual fund marketplaces for a minimum of $10,000.
The fund's allocations by country and economic sector essentially mirror those of the Morgan Stanley EAFE index, so Mr. Browne and the five analysts who work on the fund focus on picking the best stocks to match those index weightings.
To find the roughly 150 stocks in the fund, they screen about 1,500 companies in 22 developed markets, excluding the United States and Canada. They look for what Mr. Brown calls attractive valuations and improving business momentum.
THE valuation measures compare each company to its industry group, typically using four gauges: P/E multiples; the ratio of enterprise value (the combination of market value and net debt) to Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciations and amortization); and ratios of price to cash flow and of price to book value.
To measure business momentum, Mr. Browne reviews trends in earnings forecasts over the last four months, including the number of upgrades and downgrades from analysts.
The roughly 300 companies found in these screens are then evaluated to see if earnings can be sustained. For example, the analysis eliminates earnings increases created by tax reductions or one-time events, he said.
Mr. Browne began buying shares of CNOOC, the publicly traded unit of the China National Offshore Oil Company, in January at 7.98 Hong Kong dollars, worth $1.02. The shares are now trading at 10.30 Hong Kong dollars, or $1.32.
The company, which holds exploration and production rights for offshore China, maintains exclusive rights to enter into production-sharing contracts with international companies off the Chinese coast, Mr. Browne said. He added that CNOOC has no exposure to the Persian Gulf.
"If we have war with Iraq and oil deliveries are disrupted from the gulf are disrupted, these folks are not affected," he said.
He bought shares of Nissan Motor, the Japanese automaker, in May 2000 at 532 yen, or $4.91 at the time, when a dollar bought 108.3 yen. They now trade at 933 yen, or $7.77, now that the dollar has strengthened to 120 yen.
"Nissan has been a great turnaround story since Renault took a 37 percent stake in early 1999 and sent their cost-cutter extraordinaire, Carlos Ghosn, to Japan to manage the business," Mr. Browne said.
While Nissan has strong earnings momentum, he added, its shares trade at 9.8 times projected 12-month earnings, versus a multiple of 13 for Toyota.
The fund does not hedge its currency risk, Mr. Browne said. However, if the dollar rises against the yen, the benefits of increased earnings in yen often offset the lower return when the proceeds from foreign stock sales are converted back to dollars.
Royal Bank of Scotland, which became the second-largest bank in Britain after taking over National Westminster Bank in 2000, is another bargain, Mr. Browne said. It trades at about 11 times projected 12-month earnings versus a multiple of 14 times for the largest British bank, HSBC.
"Royal Bank has also been a cost story," Mr. Browne said, because its chief executive, Fred Goodwin, "has been able to wring $:2 billion per year savings from their blockbuster merger" with National Westminster "while continuing to grow revenues."
The fund started buying shares in January 1998, paying $:8.03. On Friday, they closed at $:14.39, or $23.02.

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
A Chief's Anguish: Letting Workers Go

BYLINE:  By JULIA LAWLOR 

 BODY:
LYNN WUNDERMAN laid off seven people a year ago, and the memory of that day still haunts her.
 As chief executive of I-Behavior Inc., a data base marketing firm in Harrison, N.Y., she had never thought that she would have to carry out such a painful duty. The company, which she had founded two years earlier, initially thrived, and its prospects looked bright. 
 The terrorist attacks and the anthrax scare last year, however, brought business to a halt, and when a 10 percent, across-the-board pay cut didn't do the trick, she was forced to decide which of her 22 employees would have to go. 
"It was one of the toughest times I've ever been through," said Ms. Wunderman, who described the close-knit staff as an extended family. "I couldn't sleep at night. You build a company from scratch, you live and breathe with these people. No one thinks about what it's like for the C.E.O."
It has never been easy for executives to break the news to employees that they are out of a job, but the sheer repetitiveness of the task in the current economic climate is making the task harder, experts say. Hopes for a strong economic recovery have faded, and with the unemployment rate jumping to an eight-year high of 6 percent in November from 5.7 percent in October, there are new fears of a double-dip recession.
"Ten years ago, an executive may have faced the need to downsize once every 5 to 10 years," said Bernadette Kenny, executive vice president and chief global sales and marketing officer for Lee Hecht Harrison, an outplacement firm. "Now, it might be every few months."
That makes it harder for executives to shrug off the act as an unfortunate but necessary purging of unproductive workers. They are more likely to be torn by feelings of guilt and inadequacy, management experts say.
"It's an angry, open sore that sticks around," said Dr. David Zelman, a psychologist and founder of the Transitions Institute in Dallas, who often consults with chief executives about how to handle change. "They have a lot of feelings -- 'It was my fault, we didn't do it right, it wasn't fair.' They take it personally. The highest-level executives often don't have a place to vent."
With the exception of a few chief executives, like Albert J. Dunlap, the former Sunbeam chief who viewed rampant job-cutting as a badge of honor, most will avoid layoffs as long as possible. "I don't know of any C.E.O. that likes to do it," said Phil Simshauser, vice president at the Center for Executive Options in Manhattan, a subsidiary of Drake Beam Morin, an outplacement firm. "If they did, they were in the job too long."
Mr. Simshauser and others who help companies plan and conduct layoffs say there is a path that helps minimize the damage: Always let employees know when the company is facing difficult business conditions, so they aren't surprised when cuts are announced; communicate the business reasons for the layoff, and be as generous as possible with severance packages and job search assistance.
Despite the trauma of conducting her company's first sizable layoff, Ms. Wunderman said she believes she had no choice but to let those workers go. Her only mistake, she said, was not to announce the cuts sooner, once it became clear to employees that something was about to happen.
"The air was too thick," she said. "It dragged on. It was close to a month knowing this was going to happen."
When business hadn't improved by mid-December last year, the management team at I-Behavior adopted a plan to make staff cuts across the board, including the highest levels. "To make the right statement, we couldn't just remove a middle level," said Ms. Wunderman. "It had to include the management team."
One of the founders, the vice president for business and strategic development, volunteered himself for the list. But that bit of news was kept under wraps, since no announcement of the layoffs had been made. That caused some awkward moments at the annual Christmas party that Ms. Wunderman held for department heads at her home.
"We were celebrating, talking about the future, but I knew, and he knew, that one of the management team players was not going to be there," she said.
LIKE many top executives today, Ms. Wunderman was faced with cutting a staff that was already lean. For that reason, it took weeks for Ms. Wunderman and the rest of the management team to determine who would stay and who would go. "We looked at performance, work habits, attitude, revenue relationship, versatility," she recalled. "When we looked at the account services team, it was who had stronger ties to the larger clients. There were some that, as hard as they worked and as wonderful as their attitude was, had a hard time being reliable. If you can never get to a 9:30 meeting on time, it sends a bad message."
Managers looked at each job to see whether it was essential. Names went on and off the list. One particularly difficult decision involved a senior programmer who was well respected by everyone. "I knew the talent we were letting go, and that we would likely not get it back," Ms. Wunderman said.
The layoffs were announced after the holidays, in mid-January. Some of those who were not let go questioned the choices. "I took them through the thought process," she said. And while she acknowledged that she was plagued by doubt even as she explained the rationale, she knew she had really had no choice.
A year later, the company is well on its way to being profitable, she said, and has added three people to the staff. The senior programmer whose loss was mourned so much by his co-workers now works down the hall for another technology start-up. And he sees his former I-Behavior colleagues regularly for lunch. 
"There are people I still regret losing," Ms. Wunderman said. "But we did what we had to do, for the right reasons. If we hadn't, we might not be here today."

HEADLINE: The Fiscal Crisis, This Time Around 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "New York's Cry for Help: Echoes of 1975, but a Different Tone" (Week in Review, Dec. 22), an interview with Felix G. Rohatyn, who helped design the recovery plan for the city's last fiscal crisis:
 Mr. 
Rohatyn reminds us that what is missing today is a sense of urgency about the threat of bankruptcy. Therefore, the public does not appreciate the full dimensions of the crisis. 
 City leaders have not yet grasped that there is no bailout this time and no silver bullet short of real cuts in government spending, which has risen considerably over the last decade. 
The facts this time dictate that we must all tighten our belts, cut the size of government, search for new revenue sources like tolls on bridges that are now free, and not simply tax businesses and working people out of the city.

STAN ALTMAN
New York, Dec. 24, 2002

The writer is dean of the School of Public Affairs, Baruch College.

HEADLINE: Isolation, Not Engagement 

BYLINE:  By Victor D. Cha; Victor D. Cha is a professor at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
While the United States prepares its military for a war in Iraq, North Korea has precipitated an equally serious crisis by the unceremonious restarting of its nuclear facilities at Yongbyon. These efforts have created a sense of urgency on the peninsula reminiscent of June 1994.
 To avert this crisis eight years ago, the United States and North Korea signed a nonproliferation accord known as the Agreed Framework. In doing so, they created a broad-based, moderate consensus that engagement with North Korea was effective. 
 By refusing to negotiate directly with the North after it was found to be in noncompliance with this accord, the Bush administration has rightly fractured this consensus. At the same time, it has shown a willingness, signaled in the last few days, to support measures to deal with the North through the United Nations. Thus President Bush has left open the possibility of allowing North Korea a way out of this crisis without condoning its conduct.
The engagement policy the United States followed in 1994 would be ineffective and unfeasible today. Indeed, if the North does not come clean, the true "moderate" position for both Washington and Seoul is isolation and containment.
Engagement's proponents argue that the North's tampering with the Yongbyon nuclear facilities last week -- including the unsealing of buildings, disabling of monitoring cameras and demanding the removal of international inspectors -- is a cleverly disguised attempt to create a crisis and thus coerce a reluctant Bush administration into negotiations.
Maybe so. But even if such talks could result in a more comprehensive nonproliferation agreement to replace the Agreed Framework, there is little evidence to believe that Pyongyang could be trusted to comply with it. Given the revelations in October of another secret nuclear weapons program, the credibility of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il in Washington is less than zero.
There is no denying that palpable anti-American sentiment exists in South Korea. The election of left-leaning Roh Moo Hyun over a conservative, "pro-American" candidate for president is evidence of a perverse domestic dynamic in Seoul in which bad actions by North Korea are seen to be the fault of the "hardline" policy of the United States. Yet the North's illicit nuclear activities started before the Bush administration took office (as did the waning of inter-Korean economic engagement).
Moreover, what is denigrated in Seoul as inflexibility on the part of the United States is in fact surprisingly measured. In response to North Korean provocations, the Bush administration has maintained that it will not be blackmailed into negotiations, but that it also seeks a peaceful solution to the crisis and has no plans to invade the North. In this regard, North Korea's continued bad behavior plays right into the Bush administration's plans: It reaffirms its policy of isolation and containment. Nowhere was this more evident than in last week's public statement of Mr. Roh, the South Korean president-elect, virtually pleading with Pyongyang to moderate its behavior lest it undercut any credible argument for engagement.
Some argue that greater United States engagement with the North is a useful interim measure to stem anti-Americanism in Seoul and save the alliance with South Korea. But this view is short-sighted. If North Korean nuclear brinkmanship continues unabated, South Koreans should realize that the threat of war on the peninsula emanates not from Washington's ambivalence but from Pyongyang's truculence. Crises should cause alliances to come together, not split apart. If South Koreans do not realize this, then there is no alliance left to save.
As in 1994, going to war to deal with the North Korean nuclear problem is not an option. If Mr. Kim chooses not to make unilateral efforts at resolving international concerns about his nuclear weapons programs, then the only alternative is isolation and containment of the regime.
But won't such a strategy cause Mr. Kim to lash out? Such concerns were justifiably voiced in the crisis eight years ago. But the North Korea of 2002 is very different from the North Korea of 1994. Since 1994, North Korea has won diplomatic ties with the European Union, economic ties with South Korea, a potential normalization settlement with Japan and international food aid. If faced with the choice of complying with its nonproliferation commitments or facing total isolation, the regime's decision will be complicated by one simple fact: It now has much more to lose than it did in 1994.
Different times require different thinking. In 1994, engagement was the level-headed consensus policy option, as any other alternative would have led prematurely to war. Today, engagement is not credible (nor, for that matter is preemption). If Mr. Kim chooses not to cooperate, the only true "moderate" option is isolation.

In Washington, What You See Is What They Paid for

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
Where is the highest concentration of plastic surgeons in the country? Wrong. California ranks eighth. Washington, D.C., is No. 1 with one surgeon for roughly every 25,000 residents. 
 Last year, breast implants were the most common type of elective surgery, at an average cost of $3,043, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. Liposuction was the next most common procedure, costing, on average, $2,049. 
 People who most felt the effect of gravity paid the most to reverse it. Lower body lifts, which involve the thighs and buttocks, cost an average of $5,183, followed by facelifts, at $5,007. Those looking to spend less could erase laugh lines or other wrinkles by getting a microdermabrasion procedure for $136. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Buyers Take a Holiday, and Stocks Decline

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
Stocks drifted lower in quiet trading last week as investors stepped to the sidelines to celebrate the holidays.
 There appeared to be few good reasons to buy stocks anyway, as political tensions heated up around the world and as more signs of weakness emerged in the American economy. 
Retailers, for example, reported the worst growth in holiday shopping in about 30 years. 
 In a shortened trading week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell by 207.54 points, or 2.4 percent, to 8,303.78. The Nasdaq composite lost 14.74 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,348.31. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also declined, by 20.36 points, or 2.3 percent, to 875.40.
 Market analysts took the losses in stride, noting that the thin trading volume made stocks susceptible to sharper fluctuations. Some analysts predicted a rebound in January, when investors typically stop selling stocks for tax purposes and invest their year-end bonuses.
 More money, meanwhile, shifted into the bond market. The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note, which moves inversely to the price, fell to 3.81 percent last week from 3.96 percent the previous week. VIVIAN MARINO

HEADLINE: Business; 
After the Talk, Your Turn

 BODY:
THE last 12 months have been a vintage year for business news. As usual, many of the corporate scandals, economic ups and downs, market movements, bankruptcies and other events and incidents elicited telling remarks by executives and public figures. 
 How closely were you watching the business world? Here's a test. 

Who spoke these words? What were they talking about?

1. "There are lots of other important things to do in life."

2. "In litigation, as in life, timing is everything. Now is the time to end this chapter of the case and focus on enforcement."

3. "I know how hard it is for people to see me as a victim, but in this case, it's pretty close to the truth."

4. "Enron robbed the bank. Arthur Andersen provided the getaway car, and they say you were at the wheel."

5. "I cannot think of a time when business over all has been held in less repute."

6. "It was just on autopilot, using bubble gum and Band-Aids as solutions to its problems."

7. "We're going to miss him. Ha, ha, ha."

8. "Companies come and go. It's part of the genius of capitalism."

9. "It's a faxed copy of the deal. So I can't tell if it's signed in blood."

10. "The reason I got involved is that Andersen is in big trouble and they were looking for someone to sprinkle some holy water on them."

11. "It would be unthinkable to deprive people of my expertise."

12. "Crooks are going to be crooks at any company, but we have executives of very high integrity."

13. "I'm constantly amazed that anybody cares what I do."

14. "There is no question that the recent controversy has caused many on the staff to lose confidence in my ability to steer this organization."

15. "If you don't watch the commercials, someone's going to have to pay for television and it's going to be you."

16. "If you don't like capitalism, move to Cuba or China."

17. "At the end of the day, it's good for our industry and it's good for the American people."

18. "You're perhaps the most accomplished confidence man since Charles Ponzi. I'd say you were a carnival barker, except that wouldn't be fair to carnival barkers."

19. "What's fair on the top floor should be fair on the shop floor."

20. "I want to focus on my salad."

Answers are on Page 7.

HEADLINE: States Of Alarm 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com; Maureen Dowd and Thomas L. Friedman are on vacation.

 BODY:
There is something eerie, even a little unnerving, about the budget crises that continue to spread, like a contagious, crippling disease, to states and cities across the U.S.
 In Connecticut, which is faced with a half-billion-dollar budget gap, 3,000 state workers were notified in the first week of December that they were being laid off. 
 In Kentucky, also facing a half-billion-dollar gap, Gov. Paul E. Patton has ordered the early release of more than 500 state prison inmates. The governor acknowledged that some of the prisoners would go on to commit other crimes, but said, "I have to do what I have to do to live within the revenue that we have." 
The Washington Post reported last week that some rural school districts in seven states had shifted to a four-day week in an effort to cut costs, and other districts may follow. But Julie Underwood of the National School Boards Association told me on Friday that a shorter week wouldn't do much to ease the enormous funding problems facing the nation's public schools.
"The root of the problem is that the states are in financial trouble," she said. "And, unfortunately, when states are in financial trouble, one of the very first things they look at is the public school budget. That problem is spread across the entire United States."
California's budget crisis is monumental -- a shortfall over the next 18 months of $34.8 billion. As The Times's John Broder wrote, that deficit "is bigger than the annual budgets of every other state except New York." Gov. Gray Davis is already hacking away at services, and big tax hikes are sure to come.
If you want a story with legs, this is it. President Bush will have a heck of a time getting the national economy back on track while states from coast to coast are trying to balance their budgets by raising taxes, cutting spending and laying off employees.
The National Governors Association, in a report last month, said states are facing "the most dire fiscal situation since World War II." Nearly every state "is in fiscal crisis," the governors said.
From nearly every perspective, the outlook is grim. "As states fight to balance their budgets, the solutions available to them are increasingly dire," the report said, "and some of the most difficult fiscal decisions have yet to be made."
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, in a study released two days before Christmas, said, "The budget deficits now looming over state governments will likely reach $60 billion to $85 billion in state fiscal year 2004 and constitute the largest state budget gaps in half a century."
The potential for human suffering is great. The center, in a separate report, found that cuts in health care programs that have been proposed in 11 states could result in the complete loss of health insurance coverage for a million people currently covered by Medicaid and the State Children's Health Insurance Program.
Meanwhile, the nation's cities are beset with their own (frequently related) problems. Cities in virtually every section of the country are taking a big hit on revenues from sales and income taxes, and from tourist-related levies, like restaurant and hotel taxes. At the same time, public safety costs (in this era of terror) are rising, as are health care costs.
Moreover, as the economy continues to struggle, the nation's mayors have been confronted with a sharp increase in the demand for emergency shelter, food and other assistance for the needy.
These problems cannot be solved without significant help from the federal government. The president of the U.S. Conference of Mayors, Thomas Menino of Boston, is hoping to form an alliance with the nation's governors to petition Washington for help.
He and Governor Patton of Kentucky, who is chairman of the National Governors Association, will meet Friday in Washington to see, in Governor Patton's words, "where we have a common interest."
The governor described the meeting as preliminary. "I've talked to the mayor about the general need to get some kind of relief from the federal government in a whole lot of different areas," he said.
Mayor Menino said, "In the past there has been tension between mayors and governors. But with the fiscal shape we're in, it makes a lot of sense for us to work together."

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Hungary and Suez; 
Memories of '56, When Eastern Europe Was the First Crisis of the Day

BYLINE:  By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
CAN a superpower handle more than one crisis at a time? With North Korea dismantling the international controls on its nuclear sites just as the United States contemplates a war with Iraq, the question is very much in the air.
 History never offers exact parallels, but it seems a good time to remember the fall of 1956, when the United States had to respond at the same time to the Hungarian uprising and a Middle East war. 
 The Hungarian revolution began with mass demonstrations in Budapest in October that shocked the Russians and encouraged American officials hoping for a crack in the Soviet empire. Then, to the Americans' dismay, came the Suez crisis, in which Britain, France and Israel -- without consulting the United States -- joined to try to reverse Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal. When their forces took control of the canal and the Sinai Peninsula, they diverted attention from Hungary, which the Russians seized the opportunity to retake. An infuriated American president withheld support for the Suez takeover, and the British, French and Israelis eventually had to pull back. 
Today, Hungary is in NATO and the Soviet Union is no more. But the experience faced by American officials, as they tried to balance two crises and watched events spin out of their control, is illuminated in "The 1956 Hungarian Revolution: A History in Documents," a new book of archival material published by the Central European University Press in cooperation with the National Security Archive in Washington.
The documents show how the two superpowers weighed their options with one eye on each crisis and their full attention firmly focused on each other. CELESTINE BOHLEN
On July 12, 1956, American officials discussed the pros and cons of supporting rebellion against Communist governments in Eastern Europe. In minutes of a National Security Council meeting, Vice President Richard M. Nixon's remarks were paraphrased:
After all, we are not saying that we are going to initiate uprising and violence in the satellites. We are merely saying that we will not always discourage such uprising and violence if the uprisings should occur spontaneously. . . . The vice president commented that it wouldn't be an unmixed evil, from the point of view of U.S. interest, if the Soviet iron fist were to come down again on the Soviet bloc, though on balance it would be more desirable, of course, if the present liberalizing trend in relations between the Soviet Union and its satellites continued.
On Oct. 22, a Hungarian student group demanded the withdrawal of Soviet troops, and demonstrators were on the streets of Budapest the next day. On Oct. 24, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles talked to Henry Cabot Lodge, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, by phone. A memorandum says Mr. Lodge was told:
Re Hungary -- apparently the fighting is developing in quite a big way and there is clear evidence of considerable Soviet military activity in the area to try to repress it. We are thinking of the possibility of bringing it to the United Nations Security Council. From a political standpoint the secretary is worried that it will be said that here are the great moments and when they came and these fellows were ready to stand up and die, we were caught napping and doing nothing.
At a National Security Council meeting on Oct. 26, Harold Stassen, President Dwight D. Eisenhower's adviser on disarmament, proposed that the United States assure the Soviets that the independence of satellites wouldn't be used to threaten Soviet security. Logs were kept of a presidential phone call to Mr. Dulles:
The president said he had been turning over in his mind what Stassen had said. . . . As far as the border states were concerned, they the Soviets need have no fear that we might make an effort to incorporate them into NATO or make them part of our alliances. We want to see them have a free choice.
Another telephone call, from Mr. Dulles to President Eisenhower, followed within hours:
The president said the evening paper looks as if it is spreading. The secretary said we are sending a cable to the British foreign minister Selwyn Lloyd that it should get before the Security Council in order to focus attention on it so the Russians will not commit vast reprisals, and give us a chance to talk privately with them there.
On Oct. 27, the Americans, British and French requested a Security Council meeting on Hungary, and it was set for Oct. 28. This was reflected in working notes from a meeting of the Soviet Communist Party presidium, (Sobolev is Arkadi Sobolev, chief Soviet representative at the United Nations):
Comrade Nikita S. Khrushchev: The matter is becoming more complicated. . . . We must set Sobolev right at the U.N. The workers are supporting the uprising. 
The protests embarrassed the Soviet leaders, who decided to support a declaration by Imre Nagy, Hungary's prime minister, seeking a truce and talks on the withdrawal of Soviet troops:
Comrade Khrushchev: I support the declaration. Politically this is beneficial for us. The English and French are in a real mess in Egypt. We shouldn't get caught in the same company. But we must not foster illusions. We are saving face. Fundamentally, the declaration must be adopted. But adopt it with corrections.
The uprising spread. On Oct. 30, Moscow issued a declaration that seemed to say it would accept the reform-minded leadership of Mr. Nagy. While it envisioned Soviet forces remaining at least temporarily, it also spoke of the possibility of negotiations over their departure:
The course of events has shown that the working people of Hungary . . . are rightfully raising the question of the need to eliminate serious defects in the sphere of economic construction, the question of further improving the living standards of the population. . . . However, this legitimate and progressive movement of the working people was soon joined by the forces of black reaction and counter-revolution. . . . At the same time, the Soviet government is prepared to enter into the appropriate negotiations with the government of the Hungarian People's Republic and other members of the Warsaw Treaty on the question of the presence of Soviet troops on the territory of Hungary.
On Oct. 31 -- with British and French planes bombarding Egyptian airfields two days after Israeli paratroopers landed in Egypt -- America was preoccupied by Suez. In Moscow, the presidium met and reached a final decision to intervene with force in Hungary.
Comrade Khrushchev: We should re-examine our assessment and should not withdraw our troops from Hungary and Budapest. . . . If we depart from Hungary, it will give a great boost to the Americans, English and French -- the imperialists. They will perceive it as weakness on our part and will go onto the offensive. We would then be exposing the weakness of our positions. Our party will not accept it if we do this. To Egypt, they will then add Hungary. We have no other choice.
In Washington on Nov. 1, a memorandum of a National Security Council meeting shows, the main focus had turned to the Middle East.
The president informed the members of the council that, except insofar as it was the subject of the director of central intelligence's intelligence briefing, he did not wish the council to take up the situation in the Soviet satellites. Instead he wished to concentrate on the Middle East.
Allen W. Dulles, director of central intelligence, raised Hungary anyway. The memorandum paraphrases his comments:
In a sense what had occurred there was a miracle. Events had belied all our past views that a popular revolt in the face of modern weapons was an utter impossibility. Nevertheless, the impossible had happened, and because of the power of public opinion, armed force could not effectively be used.
But Dulles was wrong. Soviet tanks were heading to Budapest to crush the revolt, and Khrushchev and presidium members would soon inform other Communist leaders. An account of their meeting with Tito of Yugoslavia from Nov. 2 to Nov. 3 is provided by Vljko Micunovic, a Yugoslav diplomat:
"What is there left for us to do," Khrushchev asked, meaning the Soviet Union. "If we let things take their course, the West would say we are either stupid or weak, and that's one and the same thing. We cannot possibly permit it." . . . 
Khrushchev said that British and French aggressive pressure on Egypt provided a favorable moment for a further intervention by Soviet troops. It would help the Russians. There would be confusion and uproar in the West and the United Nations, but it would be less at a time when Britain, France and Israel were waging a war against Egypt.
"They are bogged down there, and we are stuck in Hungary," Khrushchev said.
In the end, the Russians would stay in Hungary until their empire collapsed 32 years later. The British and French would leave Egypt in humiliation at America's lack of support. As for the Israelis, when Egypt again tried to block their shipping, in 1967, they would refight their way across Sinai -- this time after making sure America would not object.

LENGTH: 533 words

HEADLINE: McDonald's Tarnished Arches 

 BODY:
"Would you care for some fries with that?" must rank among the most common of universal expressions. McDonald's 30,000 burger joints worldwide feed the equivalent of Spain's population -- every day.
 And yet the company's torrid growth rate has stalled. McDonald's has said that it will report its first quarterly loss since going public in the mid-1960's, and that it will do what would have once been unthinkable: pull out of some countries altogether. 
 McDonald's is not the first of America's mighty global brands to have fallen on hard times. Among companies seemingly on the verge of omnipotence a decade ago, when the term "globalization" carried a less ambiguous message, Coca-Cola, Disney, the Gap and Nike have also encountered unexpected turbulence in recent years.
There is more at play here than changing habits, an economic slowdown and an anti-American backlash. It is a fundamental human ambivalence toward the ubiquitous. 
One of the paradoxes of American life is our penchant for celebrating individualism even as we enjoy the fruits of standardization. By endlessly cloning an efficient Southern California burger joint, Ray Kroc turned McDonald's into an icon of America's assembly-line answer to a basic human need. It is no accident that McDonald's, the ultimate chain, dates to the Eisenhower era, when the Interstate highway system and network television began binding the country together like never before.
American companies exported this standardization to a world of consumers grateful for the promise of certainty -- the certainty that a Coke or a Big Mac bought today will taste like one bought yesterday, not to mention one bought on another continent. But after a while, once the likes of McDonald's have elevated consumers' expectations, their omnipresence can become as unsettling as it is comforting. Fickle consumers turn away, seeking to reassert their individuality. That helps account for the ongoing fragmentation of consumer taste. 
To reignite its growth after hitting an unexpected speed bump, Coca-Cola realized that it had better start selling juices and bottled water. The Gap owns Old Navy and Banana Republic. Nike now sells some product lines without its trademark swoosh. Reacting to the fragmentation of their TV audience, the owners of the three broadcast networks acquired cable channels. 
Similarly, McDonald's may be forced to tinker with its old formula, at home and abroad, if it is to cater to a more affluent clientele with more varied tastes. Fast-food joints are losing market share to a growing niche of more expensive, and possibly healthier, "fast casual" eateries, like Panera Bread and Cosi, that offer more customized selections. McDonald's itself is expanding its successful Chipotle chain of Mexican-themed restaurants. 
Trouble is, at its core restaurants McDonald's acts as if its main problem were insufficiently low prices. So it is pushing its $1 "value menu" items with renewed vigor. Upgrading its offerings might make more sense. Otherwise, the chain's main product may soon generate nostalgia for a more innocent age when standardization was still a novelty and nobody could have foreseen a backlash against the ubiquitous.

HEADLINE: A Fear of Vampires Can Mask a Fear of Something Much Worse 

BYLINE:  By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
VAMPIRES are us, as vampire experts say. And that may explain why Malawi is now in the grip of a vampire panic. 
 Rumors that the government of that landlocked southern African country was colluding with vampires to collect human blood in exchange for food sent terrified villagers fleeing, wire services reported last week. A suspected vampire helper was stoned or beaten to death; three priests were attacked; and a foreign aid encampment identified as vampire headquarters was destroyed. 
 It didn't happen in a vacuum. Malawi faces widespread starvation and a severe AIDS epidemic, as well as an uproar over efforts by the country's first and only democratically elected president, Bakili Muluzi, to override a two-term limit and remain in office after 2004.
"Vampires say a lot about our fears and hopes," said Nina Auerbach, an English professor at the University of Pennsylvania and author of "Our Vampires, Ourselves." 
For millennia, the storied undead that emerge from the grave to suck the lifeblood of the living have embodied power "and our fears of power," Ms. Auerbach said. "They can be whatever you want." They are immortal. And unlike ghosts, they are robustly corporeal. 
Another scholar, David J. Skal, author of "The Monster Show: A Cultural History of Horror," has said that a fixation on demons often accompanies periods of national stress. "In times of social upheaval, the vampire asserts itself," he said. 
President Muluzi, in debunking the vampire rumors, may have inadvertently encouraged them when he said, "No government can go about sucking the blood of its own people."
The denial rang false, Ms. Auerbach said, because, "Governments have always sucked the blood of their people." 
It was for good reason, she said, that the vampire legend became deeply rooted in Eastern Europe, where the peasantry was cruelly persecuted for centuries.
In the United States, perhaps by the same reasoning, vampires come in friendlier form. There is Count Chocula cereal; Sesame Street's helpful arithmetic tutor, the Count; Anne Rice's novelistic dynasty of masterful and sexy vampires -- "practically spa people," Ms. Auerbach calls them; the empowered and liberated black lesbian vampires of Jewelle Gomez's "Gilda Stories;" and the wholesome cheeriness of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer." 
THE origins of the vampire legend lie buried in antiquity, dating to Greece and perhaps Egypt, scholars say, at some point taking credence from the bats that suck the blood of horses and livestock.
Drawing on ancestor worship, cannibalism, human sacrifice and the Christian doctrine of transubstantiation, and real fears of violence, tales of ghouls nourished on human blood surfaced in widely separated cultures, including China, India, the Middle East, Africa and Europe, wrote the British author Anthony Masters in his book, "The Natural History of the Vampire." 
The medieval plagues that spread unseen contagion also fed the vampire legend, as did commonplace grotesqueries like live burials (by mistake and on purpose), body-snatching and grave-robbing, along with the capture of some all-too-real fiends like Gilles de Rais of France who fought along with Joan of Arc in the 1400's before becoming an orgiastic child-slaughterer, and Countess Elizabeth of Bathory in Hungary 200 years later who bathed in the blood of murdered virgins. 
Austrian forces returning from conquests in the Ottoman east in the early 1700's brought back vampire stories, which circulated throughout Europe, later inspiring Byron, Keats and Coleridge. It was left, however, to Bram Stoker, stage manager for the revered Shakespearean actor Henry Irving in the 1870's, to turn the fragments into terrifying form in his 1897 "Dracula."
But it was not until the vogue of vampire plays and films in the 1920's that the popular Dracula cult took hold, at a time when it was still believed that evil always wore an evil face, or at least a wicked-looking widow's peak.
Soon vampirism became as rule-bound as any orthodoxy. So today one can read, on the Web and in a slew of popular books, that an animal or a nun passing over an unburied body turns into a vampire. So will a child in the womb whose mother was looked at by a vampire (particularly after her sixth month), a seventh son and a dead wizard.
Of course, today, at least in much of the West, this is merely the stuff of high camp. But the fear stalking Malawi these days is a reminder that, among desperate people, who with reason feel their life's blood, or that of their children, is being sucked away, the vampire myth still resonates uncannily with human experience.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Eugenics and Sects Go Together

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. KEVLES; Daniel J. Kevles is a professor of history at Yale University.

 BODY:
AS much of the world has heard by now, on Friday the chief scientist of a company founded by a sect that believes space travelers created the human race by genetic engineering announced that a 31-year-old American woman had given birth to a seven-pound baby cloned from her own cells. 
 Whether or not the baby, named Eve, is a genuine clone -- or even exists -- remains to be seen. The sect, called the Raelians, not only exists, but in some sense is old news. 
 The group's founder was Claude Vorilhon, a French race car journalist who said he encountered space aliens in 1973 while out walking near a volcano in France. He said the aliens traveled by flying saucer and revealed that they were the Elohim mentioned in the Bible -- not God, but beings from afar who had engineered the creation of the human race on Earth from inert DNA. They named Vorilhon "Rael" and asked him to tell mankind the true story of its creation. 
The Raelian Movement, which claims 40,000 members in France, Canada, Japan and elsewhere, believes humanity is scientifically advanced enough to comprehend its origins, to create life from inert matter, and thus to achieve, through human cloning, eternal life. 
This futuristic blend of religion and science, of millenarian purpose with reproductive practice, has numerous antecedents, dating from the 19th century and continuing up to modern groups like the Branch Davidians. 
The historian Lawrence Foster has written of "the turbulent decades of the 1830's and 1840's before the Civil War, when thousands of Americans joined new religious movements that rejected existing marriage and sex-role patterns in favor of alternative life-styles." 
These movements included John Humphrey Noyes's Oneida Community in upstate New York, created in 1848. The utopian venture was organized around communal ownership of property and the practice of "complex marriage," which declared all members of the community wedded to each other.
"To be ashamed of the sexual organs is to be ashamed of the most perfect instruments of love and unity," Noyes said.
He ran Oneida autocratically, including its sexual relationships, usually initiating young women himself. 
He intended at Oneida to establish "right relations with God"; "right relations between the sexes," the kind that would foster harmonious living; "right economic relations," in contrast to the growth of vicious capitalism; and, by achieving these goals, the creation of the true millennium on earth, with the elimination of "disease and death." 
In 1865, in further pursuit of perfection, Noyes's Oneida newspaper, "The Circular," took note of the ideas of eugenics then becoming current and proclaimed in an editorial that "human breeding should be one of the foremost questions of the age, transcending in its sublime interest all present political and scientific questions." 
A few years later, Noyes launched volunteers at Oneida on an experimental program of selective human breeding. 
Unlike Noyes, Rael is no communitarian visionary, but sensuality and sexuality have long been a feature of Raelian doctrines. In 1987, the Raelians published a small book, "Sensual Meditation," with a cover showing two nude women in erotic postures and a text that urges the reader to "uninhibit oneself. " 
RAEL has also published a message from the Elohim asking "our last Prophet, Rael, to found a religious order that will bring together young women who wish conscientiously to put at the service of their creators and of their Prophets their interior and exterior beauty when we arrive at the embassy." "While awaiting our arrival," the message continued, "they shall prepare themselves for this day of such hope in placing themselves at the service of the Last Prophet, Rael, and in seeing to his well being when necessary." 
Dr. Brigitte Boisselier, the chief scientist at Clonaid, the company the sect founded, says that she is a Raelian "bishop," but it is likely that human cloning ultimately will have nothing to do with Rael's quest for eternal life or anybody's drive for perfection. 
Noyes's ideal of sexual freedom was ultimately divorced from utopian communitarianism, becoming an end in itself, aided by the technologies of contraception. So, too, human cloning, if it proves safe and effective, will likely become just another reproductive option for people who cannot reproduce otherwise.
