HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
A Benefit Program for a Fortunate Few

BYLINE:  By Terry Pristin 

 BODY:
YESTERDAY was a significant day for thousands of New Yorkers, but it was hardly a day for celebration. It was the day that unemployment insurance benefits ended for some 62,800 state residents, even if they had yet to receive all of the 13 weekly checks to which they were entitled under a federal extension program.
 New York, unlike most other states, happens to have another program that could have helped some of the people whose benefits were abruptly terminated. It also might have been a blessing for some of the 84,200 other state residents who have exhausted their benefits and remain without work. 
 Under Section 599 of the state Unemployment Insurance Law, people who are enrolled in state-approved vocational courses can receive additional benefits for up to 26 weeks. The idea is to encourage jobless people to become more marketable by improving their skills or learning new ones. The problem is that the program is so poorly funded that few people can take advantage of it. 
And perhaps for that reason, the Department of Labor makes no effort to publicize it. The 599 program gets only $20 million a year in general revenue funds -- a sum that the labor department acknowledges is depleted two or three months into the fiscal year, which begins April 1. This year, 51,300 people applied for the benefits, but only 15,000 got them.
Joan DeLuca, of Oakdale, N.Y., on Long Island, was not one of the lucky ones. She lost her job as a software engineer in April when her division at Computer Associates was sold. Perhaps because she is 51, she said, she has been unable to find another job. But she figured that her age would not be a liability if she taught school. Teachers, she reasoned, are always in demand. 
In September, Ms. DeLuca learned about the 599 program through a chance conversation with former colleagues. By then she was enrolled in a teacher-training program at a nearby college. She applied for 599 benefits, hoping to pay some of the cost of a full-time student-teaching program, which begins next month. 
Her application was denied on the grounds that she was not taking enough credits when she applied. But Ms. DeLuca saw this reason as a pretext. At the time, she was taking the 10-credit prerequisite for student-teaching at her expense. Once she began student-teaching, she said, she would be in a classroom all day and evening.
Ms. DeLuca was unable to get the Labor Department to reverse its decision. And yesterday, her extended unemployment benefits ended, even though she qualified for three additional checks. Congress is likely to restore those lost weeks when it returns from the holiday recess, but getting the money will take time.
The experience with the program has left her bitter. "If I'm not qualified," she said, "Who is? Here I am, a viable candidate. They have a teaching shortage. I am willing to go through the training, which is intense, and they are not trying to help at all."
Labor Department officials declined to be interviewed about the 599 program and answered questions only by e-mail.
Ms. DeLuca's complaints are echoed by other disappointed applicants, most of whom said they were too embarrassed about being out of work to allow their names to be published.
Several other states link unemployment benefits to job training, but most are more generous because they are financed by a separate small payroll tax on employers, said Maurice Emsellem, the director of public policy for the National Employment Law Project. New Jersey's program, for example, has a cap of $46 million, more than twice the money available in New York. Last year, the New Jersey program spent $22.8 million on so-called additional benefits during training.
For the fortunate few, the 599 program can be very helpful, said Jonathan Bloom, executive director of the Workers Defense League, a nonprofit organization in New York. "It's not the answer to an 8 percent unemployment rate," he said, "but to give people extra benefits to encourage them to learn seems like a very progressive program."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank and Joan DeLuca, who lost her job in April. She studied to become a teacher and hoped a state program would help with costs, but she was denied aid. (Shannon Stapleton for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Staten Island Rail Line An Engine for Growth 

 BODY:
To the Editor,
 If the Port Authority is considering reopening the rail line on the North Shore of Staten Island to alleviate traffic ("As Local Traffic Worsens, Silent Trains May Toot Again," Dec. 15), they should also study the viability of using this route for freight traffic too. 
 By linking this rail route with proposed improvements at cargo handling facilities on Staten Island, and eventually other parts of the city, the Port Authority will make the North Shore Railroad not only profitable but also an engine for economic growth.

Guthrie Alberts
Brooklyn Heights

HEADLINE: In Hot Pursuit Of Those Elusive Bubbles 

BYLINE:  By Caroline F. Campion; Caroline F. Campion is an editor at GQ.

 BODY:
MOST people probably imagine New York as a heady nirvana for New Year's revels. Perhaps they conjure a holiday presided over by a singing Guy Lombardo who casts a spell of magic and romance over a swarm of sequins and tuxedos. Or they picture the scene from the movie "When Harry Met Sally," the one in which a teary-eyed Meg Ryan finally embraces her here-to-fore-unrealized soulmate (Billy Crystal) in a shower of confetti to a soundtrack by Harry Connick Jr.
What most New Yorkers can probably recall is the year they spent their rent money on an all-you-candrink (and we're not talking French Champagne) mosh pit, sponsored by a formerly exclusive nightclub. Or the evening where one true love never materialized at midnight but was later seem making out with a roommate. Or the evening capped not by a limousine ride through a snow-dappled Central park but by a greasy falafel sandwich eaten at 4 a.m. on the Bowery.
 Is there not an antidote to heart-ache and heartburn? Are there not some New Yorkers who have cast aside the liches to create something more enchanting and more true than any ideal? 
 Which brings us to a tale of two parties, held in one city, on the eve of a new year. One celebration will unfold behind the bright red door of a brick town house on Bank Street in the West Village. The other will take place in a third-floor walk-up on a shadowy stretch of Bushwick Avenue in the hipster badlands of East Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
 Despite locations as different as cobblestone and aluminum siding, both gatherings have an identical mission, to do their celebratory best at ushering in an uncertain yet hopeful future. In their separate but not so dissimilar ways, these two urban tribes will conjure the spirit of baby New Year, in his diaper and jaunty top hat, and by light of early morning, they will have sent the old man of 2002 packing.
 Behind the door on Bank Street is the home of Andy and Elyce Arons, who have played host to a New Year's Eve party here for the last three years. The guest list always includes their closest friends, someof whom they met in New York, some from the time before they were New Yorkers, most of them artists or entrepreneurs in their 30's or 40's, and all of them blessed with an attractiveness only seem in the fit and untroubled.
 The list of 16 dinner guests - more arrive later in the evening - is informal. Friends of friends are invited, as well as the wayward soul who shows up at the door. Once inside, and before throwing their coat on an upstairs bed, guests must pass a sentry of two canines, a Yorkshire terrier named Edna and a gentle Labrador named Sandy. The dogs bark and yap, attempting ferocity, them trax off politely to mingle with the dogs brought by other guests.
 An artist or writer may set off to hunt down the first of many cocktails while others circulate into the living room into the living room, which is decorated with tastefully shabby antiques and modern art hung on ice-blue walls. Mr. Arons will warily tend the Duraflame log in the fireplace (one of eight in the house), particularly cautious after a previous party during which overzealous guests from Australia produced a mild inferno that required calling the Fire Department.
 Ms. Arons, with cornflower eyes and pink-dusted cheeks, might be crouched next to the Christmas tree, which is near a window facing the street. If guests wonder why the pretty hostess is on the floor, they may notice that the tree is rustling, as if being blown by a gust of wind. In fact, the Aronses' infant daughter, Katie, is probably hiding beneath its brightly lighted boughs.
 EARLY arrivals will invariably include Kate and Andy Spade of handbag fame. They will be nattily dressed, Mr. Spade in a well-fitted sports jacket of fine wool and his wife in black cigarette pants with tiny ruby barrettes in her dark brown hair. Ms. Arons and the Spades are not only business partners, they are also best friends since college. The two women became friends as freshmen at the University of Kansas. They met Mr. Spade when they transferred to Arizona State University in their sophomore year. After graduating in 1985, they landed like two metropolitan Dorothys in the Emerald City of New York.
 Mr. Arons, who spends the early part of the evening tripping over dogs to refill Champagne flutes, is the chief executive of Gourmet Garage in Chelsea, a vocation that comes in handy when planning the menu.
 "When I came here," said Mr. Arons, who arrived from Boston in the 1980's, "I had never seen a prostitute, a roach or a rat. On my first day in the food warehouses, I saw all three."
 Also at the party will be Mr. Aron's best friend, Charlie Homet, who has the good looks of a ski instructor, and his wife, Meredith. This year they will be bringing another guest, their French bulldog, Calvin.
 The two men met while working as waiter and busboy, respectively, at a restaurant on Martha's Vineyard, and during their bachelor days, they often celebrated New Year's Eve together with other friends in their 20's who were starting out in the city. They'd rent tuxedos, sometimes stained with the remnants of the previous wearer's dinner, and assemble in someone's 500-square-foot apartment before venturing to a nightclub.
 "Andy was the only one with money to spare, because of his business," Mr. Homet recalled. "So he would always bring a huge tin of Beluga caviar - but probably on blinis instead of crackers. When the score of dinner guests have arrived and begun feeling the buzz from their first cocktails, they will head into the dining room, lighted with candles and a crystal chandelier that is original to the house, which was built in 1851. The table will be laid out for a feast and decorated by Ms. Arons - without the assistance of an uptown party planner or a maid - with woven Mexican placemats and party hats and whistles at every setting.
 One year they ate lobsters. This year the guests will dine on heirloom turkey from Mr. Aron's store. Nobody has any idea exactly what an heirloom turkey is 0 is it like the tomato? - but he will explain that it is important to eat them so more are bred before they become extinct. Everyone will tell stories, Mr. Homet about the time his friend had too many preparty drinks and on the way to a New Year's Eve ball tell head over heels down three flights of stairs, and still managed to make it out.
 They will toast one another with pink Champagne. They will reminisce about friends who have moved away and are missed. After dinner, some people will sprawl on the worn Oriental rugs and drink sweet, expensive port. They will also play games. Ms. Spade, who dislikes games, will insist on being timekeeper, even for games that have no time limit.
 One year a friend taught them a game called bite the Bag, which sounds a little X-rated but is not. Each player stands on one leg, bends over and must lift a brown paper bag using only his or her teeth. After each round, an inch is torn from the bag's edge until only the person most agile or least affected by the Champagne remains.
 Just before midnight, guests click on the television to watch the ball drop in Times Square, a few blocks and a world away. While drunken New Jersey teenagers and panicky tourists disperse into the paper-strewn streets of Midtown, the Bank Street crowd will turn up the music and fortify themselves with more champagne. They will push back the furniture and dance with awkward abandon to Motown records; Ms. Homet, despite the regal carriage of a Nordic ballerina, will perform in a manner her husband lovingly calls the "geek swirl."
 Some people will deift upstairs, some to seek out in empty room, some to a second-floor terrace to huddle arm in arm and smoke cigarettes in the cold night air. Anyone who wishes to rest by the fire will have to shove aside a napping dog to make room on the faded blue couches. Although most guests have usually left by 4 a.m., the party has no fixed end. Everyone can meander home whenever they choose.
 ON the other side of the East River, Bruce Mason, a swarthy Noel Coward type given to such Vreelandesque proclamations as "If I could be reincarnated. I'd want to be a ring on Gloria Estefan's finger," will be preparing a blowout on Bushwick Avenue.
 The first indication that there is something strange and possibly eccentric about his household are his two cats, Kitty and Cotton, both carrying 15 more pounds than a cat should and Cotton having the distinction of seven toes on each paw. When Mr. Mason scoops one of his cats into his arms, he looks like a herder cradling a sheep.
 Both cats are brown to lash out, divalike, with little warning. The onlyperson who gets along with both of them is Mr. Mason's boyfriend, Desmond Sheehan, hairdresser who moved in last summer after meeting Mr. Mason at his 2001 party.
 The two-bedroom apartment is a sprawling Bohemian lair. Furniture that looks as if it had been inherited by a mad aunt is scattered amid a variety of plant life and mounds of books, some piled like cairns on a ruined plain. Mr. Mason, who is 29, is a publicist with Miramax Books, and he could start a successful used bookstore with the work that has followed him home. In the corner of the living room is a ficus tree, which this year will be standing in for a Christmas tree. It is hung with homemade ornaments, one make from a photo of Willie Nelson.
 A dozen of Mr. Mason's closest friends are invited for dinner, with several dozen other guests arriving later for more of an open house party. The diners, who will start tricking in around 9, are an eclectic posse of 20- and 30-somethings that includes artists and writters, an economist and a Texan, an architect, a teacher and a lounge singer. There will be Aimee Blanca, who favors vampish scarlet dresses and matching lipstick and who last year introduced a Russian custom of writing one's wish for the New York on a scrap of paper and swallowing it with a shot of vodka at the stroke of midnight. Also present will be Lizzy Lorch, a friend from Mr. Mason's hometown, Little Compton, R. I., where they both worked at a fruit stand.
 The vibe at Mr. Mason's New Year's Eve party - this is his third - always involves the unexpected, fueled by copious amounts of beer, cigaretts and a cretaive spirit of happenstance. There is always the promise, or at least the pretense, of dinner. The meal is served in the dining room, whose walls are painted the color of a ripe strawberry and give the impression that one is feasting in a bordello. The walls are hung with framed photographs, some taken by Sunny Payson, a friend and professional photographer, who set up a studio at last year's party to take pictures of the guests.
 One of the most arresting images is of Wes Lang, an artist, posing shirtless to display the collection of tattoos on his arms and torso, including alush rendering of a film noir pinup girl on his forearm. Subject and artist became a couple after meeting that evening.
 Dinner is always eagerly awaited, and rarely served until after midnight. One year, Mr. Mason served on elaborate Asian spread, which all assembled were told had taken the entire day to prepare.
 "But later that night," explained Emily Mead, a writer who wears her hair in a stunning cascade of nut-brown ringlets, "I went into the kitchen and found all of the takeout containers stashed inside of the garbage can." (Mr. Mason admits to a emergency contingency plan arranged with the local Cheers Thai Restaurant.)
 After dinner, all the guests must make a speech. Mr. Mason also hands out cards bearing verses from the subway system's Poetry in Motion program for everyone to recite. Some gregarious guests may horde more than their share. "Sometimes I have to be very stern," Mr. Mason said. "There are several actresses in the group. So I cut them off after they try to read a fourth or fifth poem."
 As at the Aronses', there is dancing after dinner, but the music here has been known to veer abruptly from genre to genre, starting with Mr. Mason's favorite, Nina Simone, until someone hijacks the stereo and replaces bossa nova with the Beastie Boys. As the dancing grows wilder, a vase or plant may crash to the floor, and sometimes things get out of hand. At one party, an actress known as a darling of independent films took up an unseemly amount of space on the dance floor, despite her waifish frame. She was pushed aside by a guest from Sweden, which brought on the ire of the actress's boyfriend and led to a brawl that poured into the hallway.
 As morning nears, the party will only get louder. Strangers have been known to become dance partners, and maybe more. Before dawn, the still mobile will retire to the rooftop of Mr. Mason's building to keep dancing or just to gaze at the charcoal-colored imprint of the Lower Manhattan skyline to the west.
 During all this, the host will be swirling through the throng, his dark hair pushed back over his brow, sweaty from the exertion of dancing and preparing a lavish meal. The Bon Vivant of Bushwick, as his friends call him, was born to give New Year's Eve parties.
 Mr. Mason believes it was his mother, who is Vietnamese and met his American father in Saigon before the war, who raised him to be the ultimate social butterfly. Like many parents with first-generation American children, his mother was consumed with making sure that her son fit in, that he belonged. When young Bruce brought friends home after school, his mother greeted them in the kitchen wearing a silk dress and pushing a cart laden with dim sum.
 IT is a gift to be able to throw such parties. Although they take place in very different settings, the Aronses' Gotham fairy tale and Mr. Mason's Bushwick Avenue bacchanal share a few things. This year, a tin of Beluga caviar may appear on the coffee table at Mr. Mason's party, next to the overflowing ashtray; and Ms. Homet may break a vase of white lilies while preforming the geek swirl at 2 a.m.
 Daniel Fadin, a theater director who is a regular at the Bushwick Avenue gatherings, thinks that friends who gather at these New Year's celebrations are all struggling for perfection in life and art: "They are torn between their roots in whatever far-flung suburb they hall from and their reinvented lives among their city family," he said.
 Or, as Tobin Levy, another Bushwick Avenue friend, suggests, the motivation may be less profound. "What this is about," she said, "is friends who don't care what you do for a living or if you are great success. Everyone has to pay the rent. These parties are just about the people you want to be near on the last day of the year."

HEADLINE: Other Advice for Ford 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Ford and Goldman, So Cozy at the Top" (Dec. 8), which described the long friendship of William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Ford Motor, and John L. Thornton, a president and co-chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs: 
 The article brought to mind the firing in 1978 of Lee A. Iacocca by Henry Ford II, who gave as his reason that he just didn't like him. 
This happened as Detroit was facing a blitz of Japanese imports -- and about to even find Japanese assembly plants built in its own backyard. Mr. Ford soon turned over the reins to a nonfamily member who began the Ford recovery.
Among the importers was Nissan Motor, which successfully made the move into global markets only to be upended in the 1990's by severe recession at home. It was also bogged down by the huge debts of its affiliated suppliers.
Nissan, to save itself, sought a president from well beyond Japan's borders, from the French automaker Renault. The newcomer, not beholden to any parochial interests, administered the necessary moves. 
Now that Ford is again encountering perilous times, it might similarly consider injecting new blood into its executive suite that might transform the company into a global competitor.

LESLIE S. HIRAOKA
Union, N.J., Dec. 9

The writer is the author of "Global Alliances in the Motor Vehicle Industry" (Quorum Books).

HEADLINE: A Tunnel Too Far: L.I.R.R. Plan Panned 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
WHEN the New York City mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, announced late last month that he supported a proposal to extend the Long Island Rail Road tracks from Brooklyn into Lower Manhattan, he might have expected many L.I.R.R. commuters to rejoice at the prospect of easier access to the financial district. But the details of the plan leave it unclear that it would provide substantially easier or quicker access to downtown, and the Island's business and political leaders, worried that such a project would imperil other transportation initiatives that they hold dear, have given the mayor's plan chilly reviews.
 The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, said his priority big-money projects are the development of the Coliseum area, the so-called Nassau County hub; a third track on the L.I.R.R.'s main line; and the development of the East Side Access project that would take L.I.R.R. commuters to Grand Central Terminal in addition to Penn Station. 
 "Government is all about making priorities, and with limited resources, that is not my priority," Mr. Suozzi said of the Lower Manhattan project. "The first three are long-term projects. That one is long-term plus." 
Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County executive, said simply, "Given today's economic climate, there are other projects that should move forward before something of this magnitude takes place." 
Mr. Bloomberg said his plan to reinvigorate Lower Manhattan would cost $3.7 billion and take nine years to build. Included in the plan is a new tunnel under the East River to create a nonstop ride to Kennedy International Airport from Lower Manhattan. From Kennedy, Long Island commuters would use the AirTrain to get to the L.I.R.R.'s Jamaica station, then take trains east.
The proposal would mean changing trains at least twice to get from downtown to Long Island, not much of a selling point for the many Long Islanders who now have to change only once, at Penn Station, to get downtown. But advocates of the mayor's plan say Long Islanders will save time by skipping a handful of subway stops.
Another plan to accomplish the same goal but use existing tracks was introduced last summer by Brookfield Properties, a major landlord in Lower Manhattan. It envisions an express subway from Jamaica to Lower Manhattan, with only one stop at the Metrotech complex in downtown Brooklyn. A spokesman for Brookfield, Lloyd A. Kaplan, put the price tag at $1.9 billion and said it could be built in four years.
Both the Brookfield proposal and Mr. Bloomberg's would pay for new rail service using the $4.55 billion the federal government has allocated for rebuilding transit lines in Lower Manhattan after 9/11.
But the Long Island Association, the region's largest business civic organization, said in a letter to federal officials on Nov. 25 that it feared the Lower Manhattan project would "siphon off very important federal and state funds" that it believes should be used for three Long Island projects it considers higher priorities.
The letter, written by Mitchell H. Pally, vice president for government affairs, said its priorities are the East Side Access project, adding a third track to the main line of the L.I.R.R. and making improvements to Route 347 from Hauppauge to Port Jefferson.
In an interview, Mr. Pally stressed that his organization is not against the express subway plan and would support it "if we had unlimited funds."
"Let's see funds allocated for our three projects and have them started before they approve" the subway project, he said. 
Lisa Tyson, director of The Long Island Progressive Coalition, a citizens' group, said that although an easier ride to Lower Manhattan from Jamaica is attractive, "there are limited transportation dollars out there."
"Right now on Long Island, public transportation doesn't work," Ms. Tyson said. "We need intra-Long Island travel, and that is where the focus should be. There is a plan to build light rail to the Nassau hub or start express bus service there because traffic is so bad it takes an hour for a 10-minute ride."
Mr. Kaplan said he understands those concerns but believes they are ill-founded because the money for his plan and the mayor's would come "from a different pot designed solely for improvements in Lower Manhattan; you can't use it for things not related to Lower Manhattan."
Mr. Suozzi said he has heard that argument but is skeptical.
"If they can establish that no money would be taken away, they would have a stronger case," he said. "But they have not convinced me yet."
Mr. Kaplan disputed assertions that the benefits of his plan were too small to be worthwhile. Mr. Pally argued, for instance, that the supershuttle would benefit only 5,000 Long Islanders while the East Side Access project would benefit 60,000. The Tri-State Transportation Campaign, an transit advocacy group, said in a statement that "the plan would likely attract too few L.I.R.R. riders to justify service disruption for over 110,000 subway riders." And Beverly Dolinsky, executive director of the Long Island Rail Road Commuters Council, said the proposal "would only take two to four minutes off the ride for those who go to Penn Station and then take the subway downtown."
But Mr. Kaplan stressed that the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan with an improved transportation system would "make sense and be helpful to the region, including Long Island."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Island's Unemployment Rose Last Month
The unemployment rate on Long Island rose slightly last month to 3.9 percent, up from 3.7 percent in October, the state Department of Labor reported on Dec. 19. Regional employers cut back some 2,600 private sector jobs, mostly in Suffolk County. 
 The report showed a net loss of 400 jobs from the previous November. 
 In New York State, the unemployment rate in November was 6.4, up from 6.3 percent in October.

Symbol Resignation
 Symbol Technologies (NYSE:SBL) of Holtsville announced the resignation on Monday of its chief financial officer, Kenneth V. Jaeggi. William Nuti, the company's president and chief operating officer, will handle Mr. Jaeggi's duties while the company interviews for his replacement.
The resignation takes effect Jan 2.
In its announcement, the company, which manufactures bar code scanning technology and wireless telecommunications products, did not mention any link between Mr. Nuti's resignation and investigations into the company's nternal accounting practices by the Securities and change Commission and by the United States Attorney General's office, as well as a class action lawsuit filed by shareholders.

Pall in Agreement
 The Pall Corporation (NYSE: PLL) of East Hills, a manufacturer of filtration and purification systems, said on Monday that it has agreed to acquire Whatman HemaSure, a manufacturer of blood filtration products, for $5.95 million, ending a patent infringement claim dating back to 1996.
The dispute involved filtration technology that Whatman HemaSure, based in Marlborough, Mass., used and that Pall claimed was covered by its patents. The purchase is not expected to affect Pall's earnings for the year.

CDKNet.com Discussions
CDKNet.com (OTCBB:CDKX) of Melville, an investment banking concern, said on Monday that it has entered discussions with the Western Power & Equipment Corporation, in Vancouver, Wash., to acquire a portion of Western's business in California and Nevada. Western sells, leases, rents and services construction and industrial equipment. Size of the prospective deal was undisclosed.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Vail Has Big Bets Riding Off the Beaten Slopes

BYLINE:  By ALEX MARKELS 

 BODY:
LIKE a farmer eager to sell a bumper crop before it withers, Adam M. Aron, the chief executive of Vail Resorts, is taking every opportunity to crow. "Ten feet of snow!" he recently barked at a CNNfn studio camera three times in a three-minute interview. "We've got 10 feet of snow."
 Never mind the fact that by that day, Dec. 11, the Vail ski resort's early snowfall had already settled down to a solid but less spectacular 25-inch base. Mr. Aron, 48, was determined to put the best spin on an unusually good start to the ski season and to play down a less-than-bountiful net loss of $24.8 million, or 71 cents a share, on $113.9 million in revenue in Vail's most recent quarter. 
 Mr. Aron, a marketing veteran who cut his teeth dreaming up promotional campaigns for Hyatt Hotels and United Airlines, seized the moment to appeal to his core customer base: affluent New York financial types for whom a Vail ski vacation is an annual bragging right. 
"One out of 10 visitors to Vail is from New York City," he said. "A lot are both skiers and investors."
Ronald Baron fits that profile perfectly. "I am absolutely in love with skiing," said Mr. Baron, who was skiing at Vail over the Christmas holiday and whose Baron Capital Group owns about a third of Vail Resorts. "Vail is probably the best ski mountain in the world." He said he is excited about Vail Resorts whether or not the slopes are buried in snow.
Unfortunately for Mr. Aron, many investors feel the opposite, leaving him to wring his hands each season as the company's stock price inevitably rolls through a mogul field of weather-induced bumps and dips.
That is why Mr. Aron has stepped up a campaign to diversify the company far beyond its roots in Colorado. While many in the travel business are rentrenching amid an industrywide slowdown, Vail Resorts has invested more than $300 million in the last year alone, buying upscale hotels, desert spas, golf real estate developments and a large ski area, Heavenly, near Lake Tahoe on the California-Nevada border. And those are only the latest in a string of about $1 billion in acquisitions and capital improvements at the company since the financier Leon D. Black and his Apollo Advisors investor group installed Mr. Aron as chief executive and took the company public nearly six years ago.
Last year, Vail Resorts bought RockResorts International, the hotel chain founded by Laurance Rockefeller in 1956. It includes properties in the Florida Keys and in the San Juan Islands of Washington State. (It does not include some of the more famous resorts in Hawaii and the Caribbean that were in the chain when Mr. Rockefeller started it.)
Since then, Vail has placed other recent purchases -- including the Lodge at Rancho Mirage, Calif.; the Lodge at Vail; and the Snake River Lodge and Spa in Teton Village, Wyo. -- under the RockResorts brand. Mr. Aron wants to turn the brand into an industry powerhouse by adding one or more hotels annually; it now has 10 properties. He also hopes to change how the company is viewed by investors, who currently value Vail Resorts at about 6.6 times its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Shares of leading luxury-hotel managers like Fairmont Hotels and Resorts sell at nearly twice that.
VAIL'S competitors have found some success by following a similar diversification strategy. "It takes the weather factor out of the equation," said Joe S. Houssian, the chief executive of the Intrawest Corporation, a resort development company in Vancouver, British Columbia, that operates both ski areas and warm-weather properties.
"Vail has a very high-end clientele, and they obviously feel they can migrate them from one leisure activity to another," Mr. Houssian said. "We feel the same; we just aren't spending as much capital to execute on that strategy."
Instead, Intrawest prefers to manage the properties it develops for outside investors.
Mr. Aron has different role models. "I watched the Pritzker family in action," he said of the seven years he worked at Hyatt Hotels, which the Pritzkers control. "I learned from them and I learned from Apollo: buy top-flight assets when you know you can change or improve them, and buy them inexpensively."
Despite the recent recession and the sharp decrease in corporate travel spending after the Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. Aron said a spurt in occupancy rates at RockResorts hotels last quarter had demonstrated the plan's early success. 
Some investment analysts endorse the RockResorts strategy, pointing to changing habits among an aging population of wealthy skiers happy to trade a day on the slopes for one at the spa or on the golf course. "Don't trust that all your customers are going to want to ski," said Bryan A. Maher, a senior lodging and leisure analyst at Credit Lyonnais, who has an "add" rating on Vail Resorts' stock. "You need the spa and all the rest of it to increase revenues and gain market share."
Mr. Maher said it would make sense to lump all of Vail's assets, and even its name, under the RockResorts banner.
Others, however, are less sure. "Anyone can go out and buy a hotel -- that's not why I invested in Vail," said Mr. Baron, who was critical of the RockResorts purchase and instead favors redevelopment at Vail's base area. "There's a huge opportunity to increase profits just by bringing more people to Vail."
Capital improvements have already helped to triple Vail's nonskiing revenues, to about $500 million annually since Mr. Aron arrived. Yet neither local redevelopment nor the recent diversification has bolstered Vail's bottom line so far. The company's annual earnings of about 21 cents a share are about what they were when the company went public in 1997, while its long-term debt has more than doubled, to more than $600 million, since 1998.
Apollo, which controls the board, recently told Mr. Aron to trim expenses, prompting cuts of $20 million and 100 jobs from Vail's annual budget. The move has fostered resentment among some ski resort employees, whose bonuses have been cut and whose stock options remain worthless as underperforming acquisitions drain cash from Vail's profitable ski operation.
Vail's stock price, which plunged to a record low of $12.23 in October, has also curtailed Mr. Aron's bonuses and prevented him from cashing in options on more than 900,000 shares of stock granted to him since he joined the company. But he has profited in other ways, including grants of thousands of restricted shares, a home valued in 2001 at $1.5 million and two empty lots and golf club memberships in the company's developments west of Vail at the Red Sky Ranch and the Bachelor Gulch neighborhood near the Beaver Creek ski area. Similar lots in Bachelor Gulch sell for more than $2 million each.
Some company insiders complain that Mr. Aron has been the sole beneficiary of his tenure, while others at the company suggest that the recent drive to cut costs demonstrates that Vail's largest investors are becoming frustrated with Mr. Aron's performance. They point to a recent announcement that Mr. Black plans to step down from Vail's board as a sign that his patience with the company's progress may be wearing thin and that he and his associates are eager to sell their interest.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Black denied those assertions. He said he had left the board, along with four other Apollo-affiliated members, merely because New York Stock Exchange rules now require a majority of independent directors. Apollo maintains the right to choose two-thirds of the board.
Adding that he is pleased with Mr. Aron, Mr. Black said he believes the diversification effort will help balance Vail's weather-related fortunes. He also acknowledged that the timing of several recent acquisitions -- after Sept. 11 -- was unfortunate.
Yet subsequent concerns about traveling abroad may have helped domestic destinations like Vail, where Mr. Black and his family were vacationing over the Christmas holiday.
In separate interviews, Robert A. Katz and Marc J. Rowan, two Apollo partners and Vail board members who helped orchestrate many of Vail's recent acquisitions, also defended Mr. Aron and his compensation.
"Adam is the best-qualified C.E.O. in the winter resort business," said Mr. Katz, who worked under Mr. Black when he ran Drexel Burnham Lambert's buyout group in the late 1980's. "You have to retain him. And like everyone, he deserves a certain level of compensation."
Mr. Katz added that Apollo might well take advantage of the current malaise in the lodging industry to pick up additional assets at attractive prices.
THE vulture strategy is not unlike Apollo's approach in acquiring Vail in the first place: Mr. Black and his associates bought billions of dollars in junk bond debt held by Executive Life Insurance, now defunct, including bonds issued by Vail's previous owner, George N. Gillett Jr., a meatpacking magnate. It converted the bonds into equity after he declared bankruptcy in 1992.
Apollo cashed in when the company went public in 1997 and has since sold a total of $165 million in shares. It still owns 21 percent of the company.
Vail has two other large investors, Baron Capital and Ralcorp Holdings. Together, the three own nearly 75 percent of the shares outstanding. Mr. Aron said he has discussed with these big investors the possibility of selling some shares to bring in a broader base of shareholders. "We would be better off if they sold some shares because it would be easier for other institutional investors to get in and out," Mr. Aron said.
Yet with Vail's shares trading near their lows, industry analysts say it is unlikely that Apollo will be able to sell out anytime soon. And with much of Vail's profits still tied to the weather, it is unclear whether new investors will be interested.
Mr. Rowan says Apollo is committed to investing in its portfolio companies. "When we arrived in Vail, the local papers ran headlines saying 'Wall Street to strip area of resources,' " he said. "But it's been exactly the opposite. We've invested $1 billion in the company. And it's been a good investment so far."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Deficit Spending Can Help Republicans

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
"A DEFICIT will hurt economic vitality."
 That statement was made three months ago at a campaign stop in Flagstaff, Ariz., by President Bush, who has also overseen the sharpest two-year deterioration in the government's bottom line since World War II. Though he may publicly bemoan the economic effects of the deficit, the long-term political effects could suit his party just fine. 
 From the beginning of 2001 through the third quarter of 2002, the federal government leapt from a surplus (including Social Security) amounting to 2.3 percent of gross domestic product to a deficit of the same size. By itself, the current deficit is not terribly threatening. Indeed, running a modest deficit during an economic downturn can be useful, as long as the policies behind the deficit -- lower taxes and higher spending -- benefit consumers and businesses. 
More worrisome is the expectation of deficits in the future. In a new report released by the Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center, William G. Gale and Peter R. Orszag assess the connection between fiscal expectations and long-term interest rates. Their figures, not to mention the vast majority of earlier studies, suggest a strong link between growing expectations for deficits and higher rates, which can stifle corporate investment and cripple the housing market.
The Bush administration has plans for much more spending and many more tax cuts in the name of economic stimulus and domestic security. If all the plans were put into effect, forecasts for deficits over the next decade could grow by hundreds of billions of dollars. Even if none were to become law, a war in Iraq could expand the deficit to more than 4 percent of gross domestic product, a level not reached since the last days of the elder President Bush's administration.
The White House says lower tax rates will lead consumers to work more and businesses to expand, resulting in higher tax revenues and eventually closing the budget gap. That notion, chided as "voodoo economics" by critics, turned out to be false when it was last in vogue, during the 1980's.
But there may be reason to believe that the president's team cares little whether the deficit disappears. In fact, abig deficit may suit its purposes perfectly.
In the late 1980's and early 1990's, several experts in political economy struggled to explain the public's acceptance of the huge deficits of the Reagan administration. Even though the federal deficit more than tripled during President Ronald Reagan's first term, and stayed high through his second term, Republicans held on to the presidency. Why didn't voters rebel against the threat of higher interest rates and taxes?
The political economists concluded that voters supported the Republicans' emphasis on tax cuts and on military spending. That part stood to reason, but the second conclusion was less straightforward: by pursuing extra spending and casting the nation into deep deficits, the Republican administrations tied the hands of their successors. If a future Democratic administration wanted to spend money on its agenda of social welfare programs, it would have to raise taxes -- a prickly political proposition.
THIS strategy, the experts conjectured, probably made the people who voted for the Republicans even happier. By constraining any Democrats who might take office in the future, Presidents Reagan and George H. W. Bush were serving their constituents.
In the early 1990's, the nation was hung over from the splurge of the 80's. President Clinton did have to raise taxes to bulk up social programs. Fortunately for him, the strongest boom in postwar history lightened the blow to consumers and business.
Now, President Bush may be playing the same game of blocking his unknown successors' ambitions. It seems unlikely that he's doing so on purpose, though. "The president and this administration do not like deficits," said Trent D. Duffy, spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget. "We want to get back to balance as soon as we possibly can."
Yet having a surplus that could be spent by future governments seemed equally unattractive. "President Bush in his campaign said that if you leave money in Washington, it will be spent," Mr. Duffy said. In the coming year, he added, "we cannot repeat the guns-and-butter mistakes of the past."
Elsewhere, voters have learned skepticism from similar policies. In Britain last year, the Labor Party crushed the Conservatives by warning of a return to the "boom-bust" policies that paired high spending with economic uncertainty in the 1980's and early 1990's.
Will Americans decide that they're facing the same choice in 2004?

HEADLINE: NOTICED; 
Another Dad Flick, and Guys Are Crying

BYLINE:  By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
AS if the economy and the plight of the Knicks and the Rangers weren't enough, men now have something new to cry about. A movie called "Antwone Fisher" opened 10 days ago, and all over the country men are honking into their handkerchiefs as the movie ends with a crawl saying, "In memory of my father . . . "
 The film is a virtual fatherfest, with Denzel Washington (who also directed) playing a psychiatrist-father figure to the title character, a mixed-up (and fatherless) Navy seaman played by Derek Luke. One surefire audience grabber occurs at a Thanksgiving dinner, when the seaman recites a poem that begins, "Who will cry for the little boy?" Later the manly psychiatrist (who has no children himself) tells Antwone, "I love you, son." And a scene at the end that includes a grandmother sitting at a groaning table and croaking, "Welcome," is bound to choke up any holdouts. 
 "That one gets everyone," said Joy Bryant, who plays Antwone's love interest. She watched the movie in a screening room with a group of men. "Men kind of have this shifting in the seats thing, a lot of umm-umm frog-in-the-throat to keep from crying," she said. "And some men really bawled. One big manly celebrity, a young cute stud, came up to me with his eyes bloodshot. He said, 'I tried to hold it in, and I couldn't take it anymore -- wah!' " 
Sure, women cry at movies, but as men are wont to say, women cry at anything. Men have traditionally cried less often and less hard, and even after decades of urging by therapists (and women) for them to express their feelings, most men still feel that crying shows a loss of manliness.
"Antwone Fisher" is the latest of a subgenre, the male weepie -- others include "Field of Dreams," "Saving Private Ryan," "Bang the Drum Slowly" and "Braveheart" -- that undam the waterworks. In time for the traditional upwelling of male sentiment on New Year's Eve, its popularity raises a question: what does it take to make strong men cry?
Randolph R. Cornelius, a professor of psychology at Vassar, has studied the matter under laboratory conditions. He showed men films like "Peege," a 1972 short about visiting a grandmother in a nursing home, and what he considers the champion male weepie, "Brian's Song," a 1971 television movie about an interracial friendship between two Chicago Bears, one of whom dies. (In his lab, women get the death scene from "Steel Magnolias.") Women cry when they are angry or frustrated, Mr. Cornelius said, or when there are conflicts in a relationship. "Men cry more in situations involving loss," he said, "or about re-establishing connections."
Terrence Real, a psychotherapist at the Family Institute of Cambridge in Watertown, Mass., echoed that conclusion. "What men think about when they cry are the losses, the missed opportunities, the missed connections with other people," he said. "They have regrets about bad behavior, like drinking, or being too angry, or not being with their kids enough. And their issues with their fathers."
Come Tuesday night, adding the fuel of alcohol to the accumulated kindling of regret over the year's losses and disappointments, men across America will be letting the tears flow on hearing, "Should auld acquaintance be forgot, and never brought to mind?"
"If you think about that song -- the Robert Burns poem -- it's about loss and connection," Mr. Cornelius said. But, he added, "You can always blame the tears on the alcohol."
Mr. Real said: "Women continue making friends all through life. As men grow older they have fewer friends. So as they go down the conveyor belt of life, they cry more."
American men, mind you, more than hold their own in the international crying Olympics. A study in 29 countries completed in 1999 found that American male college students cried 1.9 times a month on average, half as often as American female college students but tied for first place with Nepalese male college students.
Many men are more likely to grow teary watching a movie or a television drama -- even a Hallmark commercial -- than in real life, even after a wrenching event like a parent's death.
"That's the power of movies," Mr. Cornelius said. Not only do they take place in the dark, where men feel safe, he said, "but they can create this alternative life space in which we express our emotions, and they are freer and less complicated than our real lives."
The movies that bring on men's tears, Mr. Cornelius said, are in essence about male bonding -- losing or winning at sports, sacrifice on the battlefield, or losing or gaining a father. " 'Ordinary People' was a real tear-jerker for men," he said. "A boy says, 'I love you,' to his father at the very end. As the lights came on, every man in the house wiped his eyes very quickly."
They wiped their eyes because men fight not to be seen with tears. Jim Olson, 62, an architect in Seattle, calls himself a crier. But he doesn't like others to see him cry at movies. If he knows the movie is almost over and feels a sad scene coming on, he will take protective measures. "I fight it back just so it won't happen," he said. "You force yourself to think about other things. You bite your tongue. It's painful, but it works."
It's easy to say such men fear being seen as wimps. But something about men's tears is itself upsetting. Consider how CNN handled footage of Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa choking back tears for a full minute before speaking about his friend Senator Paul Wellstone, who died in a plane crash in October. Before rolling the tape, CNN issued a viewer discretion advisory. Senator Harkin "gets very emotional," cautioned the anchor, Wolf Blitzer, who added, "I just want to issue that alert to those of you who may not want to watch this."
It was as if the sight of men's tears threatened viewers' own composure, implying that the social order itself was in danger.
"It's seeing the combination of masculine strength and vulnerability that makes men cry," said Michael Mayer, the director of "Thoroughly Modern Millie" on Broadway. "That gets me every time."
After the Sept. 11 attacks, when national figures like President Bush and Dan Rather shed tears publicly, a number of commentators noted how far society had come in allowing men to express emotions publicly. They contrasted those displays with the moment in the 1972 presidential primary campaign when Senator Edmund S. Muskie was shown apparently crying over speculation about his wife's mental health. (Shortly after, Mr. Muskie withdrew from the contest.)
Many sports fans feel that there has been an upswing in the number of male athletes shedding tears. Whereas it was big news in 1989 when Mike Schmidt broke down on retiring from the Phillies, it seemed almost commonplace by 1999, when wide receiver Cris Carter and his fellow Vikings cried over losing the National Football Conference title to the Atlanta Falcons. The same year, quarterback John Elway cried several times when he announced he was retiring from the Denver Broncos. This year, John Franco, the Mets reliever, cried after suffering what could be a career-ending injury. And running back Curtis Martin cried both in relief and in gratitude on learning in August that the Jets had given him a $46 million contract extension.
Many men cry when an Olympic athlete steps onto the winners' stand to the strains of a national anthem. "In that context, a man crying has a certain kind of legitimacy, a nobility," Professor Cornelius said. "People think if a man is crying, something really deep must have happened."
Then there is Douglas McGrath, the director of the movies "Emma" and "Nicholas Nickleby," which opened Friday, who says he cries at almost anything. "I'll be in bed at night with my wife," he said, "and a rerun of 'I Love Lucy' starts, and just as the heart is closing around the title, the tears well up in my eyes." Why? He thinks it's because of the contrast between the triumph of love of the fictional Desi and Lucy, and the fact that they broke up in real life. Now that's a sensitive guy!
But for most men it is the father-centric films like "Antwone Fisher" or books and plays with father figures, like "Tuesdays With Morrie," that get to men the way "Old Yeller" breaks up young boys. As Mr. Real put it: "Want to see men cry? You put them together in a room where they feel safe, give them a facilitator and have him ask them, 'When I think of my father, I . . . ' "
This moment of free-flowing men's tears may be coming to an end. "I see it changing back," Mr. Cornelius said. "We are moving into a more of a 'you've got to tough it out' phase as our culture is preparing us for war and there will be a lot of sacrifices. It's like, 'We've got to get through all this, and there's no crying about it.' "

HEADLINE: Coming Up Roses In a DowncastYear 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL ONEAL 

 BODY:
THE year 2002 will surely go down as one of the worst in business history.
 Scandal rocked corporate suites and Washington offices, jobs evaporated, the American economy muddled along and Europe and Latin America reeled. Rogues at companies like WorldCom and Enron were bad enough, but even superstar executives like Jack Welch contributed to the staining of corporate America. 
 Payment was coming due, it seemed, for the hubris and excess of the late 1990's. This was not just a down year. The troubles seemed biblical. 
The truth, of course, was much less dire. The economy grew a bit and the stock market, while down over all, provided many opportunities for investors willing to take a risk. Low interest rates led to a refinancing boom that kept consumers in the malls.
Some people in the business world, in fact, had an exceptionally good year, often thriving on the troubles of others. Many of them were lawyers -- working on bankruptcies, defending those accused of corporate malfeasance and filing class-action suits on behalf of shareholders. Among investment bankers, those advising bankrupt companies obviously racked up business.
Other executives, operating under tough conditions, managed to have a good year, too, avoiding the storms in their industry or harnessing them to their advantage.
Money & Business selected about a dozen people who made 2002 a winning year -- or just happened to have fortune smile upon them. Many, though, may find 2003 to be a challenge.

DAVID NEELEMAN -- JetBlue Airways
If the ultimate definition of a good year is to succeed mightily when all those around you failed miserably, Mr. Neeleman had a very good year indeed. As founder and chief executive of JetBlue, Mr. Neeleman, 42, not only brought his upstart carrier public during the worst airline crisis in history, he also managed to double profits, to $34 million, and revenue, to $448 million, in the nine months ended Sept. 30.
Mr. Neeleman's low-cost airline doesn't feel like one. All the seats on its new Airbus 320's are leather and come with satellite television connections. Its customer service draws rave reviews, and its fares give high-cost rivals like United and US Airways fits. Mr. Neeleman's operating margin even outshines that of industry superstar Herb Kelleher, the chairman of Southwest Airlines.
Plenty of airline entrepreneurs have done an Icarus act, falling from the sky as competitors were stirred to action. But Mr. Neeleman is nothing if not tenacious. Now a father of nine, he never finished college at the University of Utah and suffers from attention deficit disorder. Yet he became the co-founder of a charter airline company and sold it to Southwest in 1993 for $128 million in stock. His 8 percent stake in JetBlue is flying at an altitude of $137 million. Pushing it higher will be next year's challenge.

CLIVE CALDER and CLIVE DAVIS -- BMG
It was a great year to be a Clive -- especially if you happened to be doing business with BMG, the music unit of Germany's Bertelsmann.
Two years ago, Strauss Zelnick, then BMG's chief, created a firestorm by ousting Mr. Davis, the legendary founder of Arista Records. Bertelsmann gave Mr. Davis, now 69, his own label, J Records, but the ouster hurt.
Mr. Davis, who made his name shepherding the likes of Bruce Springsteen and Janis Joplin, quickly struck gold with the rhythm-and-blues diva Alicia Keys. In November, BMG, which had by then ousted Mr. Zelnick, embraced Mr. Davis anew, giving him an estimated $50 million for the 50 percent of J it did not already own and installing him as head of the RCA Music Group -- vindication wrapped in a fat paycheck.
But that pales next to the billions that BMG showered on Mr. Calder, the reclusive South African founder of Zomba Music. More than a decade ago, Mr. Calder quietly negotiated a distribution deal with BMG that included a novel twist: in 2002, BMG would be obligated to buy out Mr. Calder at a certain price based on Zomba's revenue in previous years.
Mr. Calder went on to deliver the teen idols Britney Spears and 'N Sync. Revenue soared and BMG's obligation ballooned to an astonishing $2.8 billion by the time Calder's "put" came due this year. Sadly for BMG, Britney isn't what she used to be, and sales are sliding fast. Mr. Calder, meanwhile, is long gone -- trying to figure out where to spend that $2.8 billion.

LAWRENCE F. PROBST III -- Electronic Arts
The year has been the best of times for purveyors of electronic fantasy -- especially Mr. Probst, 52, the chairman of Electronic Arts Inc.
Riding a mighty surge in the sales of computer games and consoles, Electronic Arts almost doubled its revenue, to $2.1 billion, in the 12 months through September 2002, the latest figures available. It posted profits of $237 million for the same period, versus a loss of $8 million in the previous 12 months.
Electronic Arts prospers because its hits, like Madden Football, play on anything, from the Sony PlayStation to Microsoft's Xbox. Its Sims series dominates the PC. This year, Mr. Probst's pricey strategy of buying the rights to produce games based on hit movie series like "Harry Potter" and "The Lord of the Rings" has proved brilliant.
For investors, the company's highly volatile stock has been as harrowing as one of its adventure games. Having almost tripled since early 2000, to a high of around $72, the price has tumbled in December, closing at $51.50 on Friday. Wall Street appears convinced that the growth of games will slow sharply in 2003, although Mr. Probst has been saying publicly that the company will continue to thrive. Nevertheless, insider trading records show that he has cashed in options at a profit of $13.5 million over the past year.

JOHN MACKEY -- Whole Foods Market
Anyone who doubts that yuppies still have plenty of money to spend hasn't seen the lines at the local Whole Foods Market. High prices? So what. Consumers can't seem to get enough of that organic Swiss chard and Amish free-range chicken.
Organic food is hot, especially since the Agriculture Department released national standards in October that define "organic." But Mr. Mackey, 49, the chief executive of Whole Foods, has been driving the bandwagon for years. After starting the chain in 1980, he has been consolidating the industry since 1988 by picking up regional rivals. Now Whole Foods seems to be growing as if it were sneaking in some fertilizer.
For its fiscal year ended in September, revenue grew 18 percent, to $2.7 billion, while earnings shot ahead 25 percent, to $85 million. Sales per square foot dwarf those of traditional supermarkets. Since early April 2001, Whole Foods' shares have sprouted 160 percent, to $52.90 a share, or 38 times earnings, which some analysts say is unsustainable. Mr. Mackey's 1 percent stake is now valued at a cool $30.7 million.

SALLIE L. KRAWCHECK -- Citigroup
Money magazine called her "the Straight Shooter." Fortune called her one of the nation's most powerful businesswomen. Then Sanford I. Weill called and asked Ms. Krawcheck, 37, to help him salvage the reputation of his scandal-ridden Citigroup. Her mission (and she chose to accept it) is to clean up Citi's newly independent retail brokerage unit, to be called Smith Barney. 
Mr. Weill, Citigroup's chairman, plucked Ms. Krawcheck from Sanford C. Bernstein, a small Wall Street research firm known for its staunch independence from the investment banking world. Bernstein has no banking business and, therefore, little incentive to hype stocks to attract investment banking fees. 
Whether Ms. Krawcheck can bring something of Bernstein's culture to Citi -- where conflicts have run deep -- remains to be seen. It may help her cause that the bank has just agreed to the biggest fine, $325 million, in the landmark settlement between regulators and Wall Street. New rules devised to put distance between investment bankers and analysts should also make a difference. In any event, Ms. Krawcheck is certainly being well compensated. Mr. Weill gave her 750,000 options over five years, which, valued conservatively, could be worth more than $11 million.

ELIOT SPITZER, attorney general of New York State
Wall Street's $1.5 billion settlement was the crowning achievement of a remarkable year for Mr. Spitzer. With his dogged pursuit of conflicted analysts like Henry Blodget, formerly of Merrill Lynch, and Jack B. Grubman, formerly of Salomon Smith Barney, Mr. Spitzer, 43, helped expose how the rabid search for investment banking fees corrupts research on Wall Street. 
He took on the investment industry at a time when federal regulators like Harvey L. Pitt, the departing chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, had little appetite for it. Though the S.E.C. and the major stock markets eventually joined in, it was Mr. Spitzer who lit the investigative fire. That bodes well for his Democratic political ambitions.

MICHAEL S. DELL -- Dell Computer
Mr. Dell's rampage through the computer business has gone on for so long that it is easy to take it for granted. Analysts sometimes worry that Dell Computer's low-cost telephone and Internet sales system will eventually run out of gas. They've often predicted that Dell may trip up as it moves into servers, the high-speed machines that power corporate networks and databases. But then Mr. Dell posts another blistering quarter and shows that his company is in full control of its destiny.
In November, Dell said its fiscal third-quarter profits grew 31 percent on a 22 percent increase in sales. Stretching back nine months, sales grew 11 percent, to $25.7 billion, while profits jumped 15 percent, to $1.5 billion. In a stagnant PC market, Dell's growth is coming directly from the hide of competitors like Gateway and Hewlett-Packard. As for servers, Dell's business grew 24 percent in the quarter, nearly five times the industry's pace.
Mr. Dell, 37, is hoping that his new server business will power results next year. Just last month, he entered the market for hand-held PC's, and he is taking aim at Hewlett-Packard's printer business. New forays mean new risks. But Mr. Dell is in the habit of proving doubters wrong. That may explain why Forbes magazine ranks him No. 11 on its 2002 list of richest Americans, with a net worth of $11.2 billion -- up 14 percent from 2001.

CARLETON S. FIORINA -- Hewlett-Packard
Mr. Dell's chief competitor these days is Ms. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. The year started badly for her. She was caught in a bruising and very personal proxy battle with Walter B. Hewlett, son of a Hewlett-Packard founder, over her $19 billion merger plan with Compaq Computer. Ms. Fiorina staked her career on the merger, and she prevailed. In November, Michael D. Capellas, Compaq's former chief executive, left to take the reins at WorldCom, leaving no question of who is in control at H-P. 
Now she faces the stiff challenge of integrating the two sprawling companies profitably, and confronting Mr. Dell. While Dell's worldwide PC shipments grew 23 percent in the third quarter, Hewlett-Packard's fell by almost 5 percent. Dell, the leader in market share, is forcing Hewlett-Packard to discount heavily to stay in the race. H-P's server business faces similar pressure.
The ever-confident Ms. Fiorina, 48, has closed factories and cut jobs to stem PC and server losses. She has crisscrossed the globe to talk to employees about how to make the merger work. So far, investors have been impressed, driving up the stock 54 percent since July 26. But for Ms. Fiorina, the real work is just beginning.

JAMES F. ROTHENBERG -- Capital Research and Management
You may have heard that once-dazzling mutual fund companies like Janus and Putnam Investments lost assets in 2002 like water running down the drain. Through November, they bled about $13 billion each. Wonder where all that money went? Mr. Rothenberg, 56, the president of Capital Research and Management, knows. The 29 American Funds managed by his firm sopped up a good portion of it.
Through November, American Funds raked in $37.7 billion in new assets, according to AMG Data Services. Over all, it trailed Vanguard, which pulled in $42 billion, but in terms of equity funds, American blew away the competition. It grabbed $16.5 billion, while Vanguard's equity offerings came in second, with $10 billion. (The big winner in bond funds was Pimco, which drew almost $26 billion, AMG data shows.)
If you've never heard of Mr. Rothenberg or American Funds, you're not alone. The funds are sold exclusively through investment advisers, and the firm -- wary of hot money -- belongs to the Howard Hughes school of public relations. But its consistent emphasis on long-term value speaks for itself. Among the top 25 fund families, it ranks second in relative 1-year, 5-year and 10-year returns, according to Morningstar Inc.

JEFF BEWKES -- AOL Time Warner
For most executives at AOL Time Warner, 2002 must have seemed like something out of Dante's "Inferno." Earnings restatements, S.E.C. investigations, investor unrest and a plummeting stock price: each presented a new and more painful circle of hell. 
For Mr. Bewkes, however, 2002 was a career-making year. Not only did the HBO cable network he ran for six years continue to blossom into one of the most highly acclaimed television properties in history, but a management shakeup installed him as chairman of AOL Time Warner's entire entertainment division and made him one of the company's top four officers. Now Mr. Bewkes is presiding over the company's crown jewels: HBO, the Turner networks, Warner Music and the movie studios.
Don Logan, the former chairman of Time Inc., also benefited from the management shakeup, joining the AOL Time Warner inner circle. But he has been given responsibility for the tortured AOL division. As Mr. Logan, 58, wrestles with an online property racked by conflict and desperate for a coherent strategy, Mr. Bewkes, 50, will be collecting Emmys at HBO and counting the returns from blockbuster movies like "The Lord of the Rings" and "Harry Potter."

BARRY DILLER -- USA Interactive
Mr. Diller, 60, has his pick of jobs these days. Ever the opportunist, he's the one person most likely to benefit from problems at Vivendi Universal of France, which rivals AOL Time Warner for trouble.
A year ago, Mr. Diller sold his USA cable, television and film assets to a Vivendi joint venture for $11 billion, renamed his company USA Interactive and turned his attention to electronic commerce. The company is now producing more cash than either Amazon.com or eBay. And its brands, like Expedia, Hotels.com, and Ticketmaster, are growing quickly. The Home Shopping Network continues to be a cash cow. 
But Mr. Diller also retained a stake in the Vivendi joint venture, both on his own and through USA. So when the French conglomerate erupted in scandal earlier this year, Vivendi's new chairman, Jean-Rene Fourtou, asked Mr. Diller to oversee the company's entertainment assets -- the same ones Mr. Diller had sold earlier, plus the Universal movie studio and Universal Music.
Now, because a tax twist in Mr. Diller's original deal gives him the power to block any restructuring of the entertainment assets, he has a big say in their future. Many analysts believe that he'll end up running the show. Forbes magazine put Mr. Diller's net worth at $900 million this year. But if Vivendi ends up spinning out Universal, look for that number to jump through the roof.

JEFF BEZOS -- Amazon.com
Wasn't it just two years ago that Ravi Suria, then a Lehman Brothers analyst, famously predicted that Amazon.com would run out of cash in four short quarters? It was a call that helped puncture the Internet balloon and seemed to foretell the end for Mr. Bezos's "e-tailing" colossus.
But a funny thing happened on the way to insolvency. Amazon continued to flourish, as Mr. Bezos, the founder and chairman, cut costs and added new businesses. By the fourth quarter of last year, Amazon began posting thin operating profits. More remarkable was that Amazon stock got a fresh shot of helium while most of Wall Street was given over to chagrined retrenchment. While the stock remains 82 percent off its peak of December 1999, it almost tripled this year, from a low of around $9 a share in January to a 52-week high of $25 in late November. Hurt by reports of gloomy holiday retail sales, it closed on Friday at $18.86.
Many analysts call the stock overvalued, noting that Amazon has yet to prove that it can produce consistent profits. But with sales approaching $4 billion this year and growing at a double-digit clip, few doubt that the company is here to stay. That counts as a major victory for Mr. Bezos, now 38. And oh, yes: the surge in Amazon stock has added around $1.1 billion to his net worth.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Limiting Lawsuits On a National Scale

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH never much cared for lawyers, though he once tried to be one. 
 Rejected by the University of Texas law school, Mr. Bush instead earned an M.B.A. from Harvard and set out for the oil patch. As governor of Texas, Mr. Bush had few political enemies, but he never flinched when his actions drew the enmity of some of the state's wealthiest lawyers. 
 Now, Mr. Bush and Congressional Republicans are poised to back changes in tort law next year, including proposals that would make it harder to win large jury awards for medical malpractice and force many class-action lawsuits out of plaintiff-friendly state courthouses and into federal courts. Other proposals would protect companies facing asbestos-related claims.
The arguments for and against change often take the form of anecdote, with debates over such things as the merits of overweight children suing fast-food restaurants. Corporate America blames trial lawyers for making everything from football helmets to health care premiums more costly. Trial lawyers -- and the Democrats they often support -- argue that lawsuits make products safer and that the Republicans want to allow corporations to evade responsibility when they hurt people.
But it is possible to get some idea of the impact of a new system by looking at Texas, which over the past dozen years has become something of a tort-reform laboratory. The changes Texas made, most of them under then Governor Bush, differ from what Congress is likely to consider, but they demonstrate how dramatic the effect can be on plaintiffs, defendants and insurance companies.
In 1989, before Mr. Bush became governor, the Texas Legislature revamped the state's workers' compensation system, which was in disarray. The insurers were bleeding money, and business groups complained about large premium increases. The new system made it more difficult for workers to hire lawyers. 
Then, in 1995, under Governor Bush, the Legislature passed a series of bills that made it harder to win big punitive-damage verdicts, narrowed the state's primary consumer protection law and limited what deep-pocketed defendants had to pay in multiparty lawsuits.
Immediately after all these measures were passed, payouts plunged for lawsuits, settlements and other claims covered by insurance companies. After 1995, for example, annual payouts by automobile liability insurers fell by more than $500 million, reversing an upward trend in the first half of the decade, according to data reported by insurance companies.
But premiums paid by consumers and businesses didn't drop nearly as fast as insurers' payouts did, and the profits of insurance companies soared. Before the workers' compensation system was changed, for example, insurers had been paying out all of their premium income, and then some, to cover losses. But by 1994, under the new system, insurers were paying out just 40 cents for every $1 collected in premiums. Similarly, after 1995, auto liability insurers went from paying more than 70 cents for every dollar of premium to about 54 cents. 
Over the years, the premiums eventually fell, and insurers' profits moderated. Last year, auto liability insurers were paying 79 cents for every $1 in premiums. Payouts by workers' compensation insurers have also been rising, and total premiums are a half-billion dollars less than a decade ago.
Mr. Bush and state officials have argued that the 1995 changes cut insurance bills by almost $3 billion. The muscle behind that claim originated with a provision that year by a Democratic legislator requiring officials to roll back rates ahead of time to account for tort reform, so that insurance companies did not keep the savings from reform.
But even state officials acknowledge that insurers have most likely kept some benefits. Moreover, insurers overcharged consumers $2.9 billion for auto insurance in the three years after the system was changed, argued D. J. Powers, a former general counsel of the Texas Department of Insurance who is president of the Center for Economic Justice, a consumer-advocacy group based in Austin.
The changes had another effect, other critics say. Trial lawyers and consumer advocates argue that plaintiffs were stripped of much of their ability to seek redress for everything from workplace injuries to consumer fraud. In fact, studies done for the Texas Department of Insurance found that businesses facing lawsuits became more aggressive because of the new laws, making low settlement offers or refusing to negotiate.
"Instead of settling a case, more insurers are telling their counsel to take it to trial," reported one study by the University of Texas conducted for the insurance department two years after the law changed. "Soft-tissue injury cases in auto and premises liability cases are way down in value." 
INSURERS say the changes have weeded out many specious lawsuits and restored fairness to the state civil justice system. They say other factors, like safer cars and workplaces, have contributed to the higher profits as well.
But they now want more changes in the tort laws, arguing that jury awards are still too generous. "There are still certain jurisdictions in Texas that are viewed as judicial hellholes," said Robert P. Hartwig, chief economist of the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group. 
Rick Gentry, the executive director of the Insurance Council of Texas, another industry group, said plaintiffs' lawyers have found creative ways to get around the 1995 laws. Insurers' profits did improve after the changes, he said, "but we're still not where we ought to be."
For the Bush administration, tort-law changes at the federal level makes almost perfect political sense. It unites business groups willing to send millions of dollars to sympathetic politicians to fight plaintiffs' lawyers, often generous patrons of Democrats.
Despite Mr. Bush's long-held views on "junk and frivolous" lawsuits, Karl Rove, his longtime top political adviser, apparently had to persuade Mr. Bush to make tort reform part of his 1994 campaign for governor. 
"I sort of talked him into that one," Mr. Rove is quoted as saying in a coming book, "Bush's Brain: How Karl Rove Made George W. Bush Presidential," by Wayne Slater and James Moore.
Mr. Rove didn't return a call seeking comment, but in an interview, a senior Texas Republican official recalled Mr. Rove's dislike for trial lawyers. "He thinks they're quick-buck artists out to make a lot of money for doing very little," he said.
